PART ONE - ADMINISTRATIVE CODE 
CHAPTER ONE - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE 99 - PEOPLE'S BILL OF RIGHTS 

99.01 - PREAMBLE. 
    The people have inalienable rights that exceed the needs of the City of Huntington and are granted through the individual's ability to reason, right to be free, to question the governors of the City of Huntington and to act as sovereign have by declaration, rights recognized by Council as the basis of American Democracy and our chosen way of life. The essence of American Freedom is founded upon individual liberties, not granted by government, but retained by the sovereign. And therefore, the following actions affect the City of Huntington, council, mayor and its subordinate agencies, boards and committees. 
(Ord. 10-13-03) 
99.02 - THE RIGHT OF FREE SPEECH. 
    The people shall have the right to express their opinion and the City of Huntington shall not attempt to regulate content of speech. The City of Huntington, council, mayor and its subordinate agencies, boards and committees may regulate time, place and manner of speech, but not content. 
(Ord. 10-13-03) 
99.03 - RIGHT TO KEEP AND BEAR ARMS. 
    The people shall have the right to keep and bear arms within the City of Huntington under the laws of the United States of America and the State of West Virginia. 
(Ord. 10-13-03) 
99.04 - RIGHT TO DUE PROCESS. 
(a)  No one shall be compelled to testify against oneself or ones spouse nor be denied the rights of due process under the laws of the United States of America and the State of West Virginia. 
(b)  No person shall be held by the City of Huntington greater than 24 hours without charges being proffered. 
(c)  An individual has a right to be secure in his person from unreasonable searches and seizures and no warrants shall be issued without probable cause supported by oath or affirmation and particularly describing the items to be seized and the places to be searched. 
(d)  No stops, searches or inquiry can be made of any person based upon their race, religion, sex, age or ethnic origin. 
(Ord. 10-13-03) 
99.05 - RIGHT OF PRIVACY. 
(a)  No governmental agency shall invade the privacy of a person located within the City of Huntington by electronic eavesdropping, intercepting Internet transmissions, or by opening correspondence transmitted electronically, lest he be an officer of the law who has obtained a specific warrant for such searches. 
(b)  No law enforcement agency shall seek to invade any telephone, computer transmission or personal correspondence that is private between the sender and receiver without a warrant. 
(1)  Each invasion shall constitute a separate act and the individual perpetrating the act and those directing the invasion shall be equally subject to the penalty as stated in section 99.99. 
(Ord. 10-13-03) 
99.99 - PENALTY. 
    Any violation of Article 99 shall be subject to a fine of up to $500 and/or 30 days in jail. 
(Ord. 10-13-03) 
ARTICLE 101 - CODIFIED ORDINANCES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Codification of ordinances, § 3.15. 
State Law reference- See sectional histories for similar state law; maximum penalty permitted, W. Va. Code, §§ 8-11-1, 8-12-5(57); authority to impose penalties, W. Va. Code, §§ 8-11-1, 8-12-2(11). 

101.01 - DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS. 
(a)  All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the Municipality as revised, recodified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component codes, chapters, articles and sections shall be known and designated as the Codified Ordinances of Huntington, West Virginia, 1986, for which designation "Codified Ordinances" may be substituted. Code, chapter, article and section headings do not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified Ordinances. 
(b)  All references to codes, chapters, articles and sections are to such components of the Codified Ordinances unless otherwise specified. Any component code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the "Traffic Code". Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation "section" followed by the number, such as "Section 101.01". 
101.02 - GENERAL DEFINITIONS. 
    As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless otherwise expressly provided or the context otherwise requires: 
(a)  Council means the legislative authority of the municipality. 
(b)  County means Cabell or Wayne County, West Virginia, as applicable to that portion of the city located therein. 
(c)  Land or lands and real estate or real property include lands, tenements and hereditaments, and all rights thereto and interests therein except chattel interests. 
(d)  Laws of the State includes the Constitution of the State and the Constitution of the United States, and treaties and laws made in pursuance thereof. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(e)  Municipality or City means the City of Huntington, West Virginia. 
(f)  Offense includes every act or omission for which a fine, forfeiture or punishment is imposed by law. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(g)  Owner, when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint owner or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property. 
(h)  Person or whoever includes corporations, societies, associations and partnerships. 
(i)  Personal estate or personal property includes goods, chattels, real and personal, money, credits, investments and the evidences thereof. 
(j)  Preceding, succeeding or following used in reference to any section or sections of an article means next preceding, next succeeding or next following that in which such reference is made. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(k)  Premises, as applied to property, includes land and building. 
(l)  Property or estate embraces both real and personal estate. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(m)  Public place includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance or any other place for the sale of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement. 
(n)  Registered mail includes certified mail. 
(o)  State means the State of West Virginia or any department, division, commission, board, educational or other institution of the State. 
(p)  Street includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways, viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the municipality. 
(q)  Tenant or occupant, as applied to premises, includes any person holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part of such premises alone or with others. 
(r)  Written or in writing includes any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing, engraving, writing or otherwise. But when the signature of any person is required, it must be in his own proper handwriting, or his mark, attested, proved or acknowledged. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
101.03 - RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. 
(a)  General rule. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(b)  Gender and plural. A word importing the singular number only may be applied to several persons or things, as well as to one person or thing; a word importing the plural number only may be applied to one person or thing as well as to several; and a word importing the masculine gender only may be applied to females as well as males. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(c)  Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, or if the last be a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday it shall also be excluded. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-3) 
(d)  Joint authority. Words purporting to give a joint authority to three or more persons confer such authority upon a majority of them, and not upon any less number. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(e)  Exceptions. The rules of construction shall not apply to any law which contains any express provision excluding such construction, or when the subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto. 
101.04 - REPEAL OF REPEALING ACT; EFFECT OF REPEAL. 
(a)  When a law which has repealed another is itself repealed, the former law shall not be revived without express words for that purpose. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-9) 
(b)  The repeal of a law, or its expiration by virtue of any provision contained therein, shall not affect any offense committed, or penalty or punishment incurred, before the repeal took effect or the law expired, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform as far as practicable to the laws in force at the time such proceedings take place, unless otherwise specially provided; and that if any penalty or punishment be mitigated by the new law, such new law may, with the consent of the part affected thereby, be applied to any judgment pronounced after it has taken effect. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-8) 
(c)  The repeal by any provision of the Codified Ordinances of an ordinance validating previous acts, contracts or transactions shall not affect the validity of such acts, contracts or transactions, but the same shall remain as valid as if there had been no such repeal, but no further. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-11) 
101.05 - CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES. 
    When reference is made to any section or group of sections of the Codified Ordinances, such reference shall extend to and include any amendment of or supplement to the section or group of sections so referred to or any section or sections hereafter enacted in lieu thereof; and unless otherwise provided, whenever a reference to a section or group sections is made in any amendment or supplement to any section of the Codified Ordinances hereafter enacted, such reference shall be deemed to refer to the section or sections as the same shall then stand or as thereafter amended. 
    Whenever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a section or an inclusive group of sections, such reference shall be construed to mean a violation of any provision of the section or sections included in such reference. 
    References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized under designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case, action taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is superseded by the Codified Ordinances. 
    If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and the last number or letters in the series are deemed to be included. 
101.06 - ACTS BY AGENT OR DEPUTY. 
    When a section requires that an act be done by an officer or person, it shall be sufficient if it be done by his agent or deputy, unless it be such as cannot lawfully be done by deputation. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-5) 
101.07 - CONFLICTING PROVISIONS. 
    If the provisions of different codes, articles or sections of the Codified Ordinances conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions bearing the latest passage date shall prevail. If the conflicting provisions bear the same passage date, the conflict shall be construed so as to be consistent with the meaning or legal effect of the questions of the subject matter taken as a whole. 
101.08 - SEPARABILITY. 
    Each section of the Codified Ordinances and every part of each section is an independent section and part of a section, and the holding of any section or a part thereof to be unconstitutional, void or ineffective for any cause does not affect the validity or constitutionality of any other section or part thereof. 
101.09 - CHARGES FOR COPIES OF THE CODIFIED ORDINANCES. 
(a)  Purpose. In accordance with Section 3.15 of the Official Charter of the City of Huntington, it is the purpose of Section 101.09 to establish reasonable fees and charges for the provision of access to or copies of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington to avoid the necessity of using general public funds of the city to subsidize special services and benefits to a record requester. 
(b)  Copying fee. A fee of $1 per page for the first page (one side) and $0.50 for every page thereafter (each side) shall be charged for photocopying the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington, such fee to cover the cost of labor, materials and equipment. A hardbound transcript of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington shall cost $250 each. A softbound transcript of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington shall cost $200 each. A copy of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington in electronic format shall cost $75 each. 
(c)  Payment. All fees charged under this section shall be paid to the city clerk unless the requester has established an account, for purposes of billing and payment, with the city. All fees shall be placed in the city's general fund. 
(Ord. of 2-23-09) 
101.99 - GENERAL PENALTY. 
    Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is otherwise provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be fined not more than $500 or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both. Each day any such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
ARTICLE 103 - ELECTIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Election of Mayor, § 2.2; election of council, § 3.3 et seq.; nominations and elections, Art. Eleven, Appx. A. 
State Law reference- Municipal elections, W. Va. Code, § 3-11-2a; municipal voting precincts, W. Va. Code, § 3-1-6; municipal precinct registration records, W. Va. Code, § 3-1-27; absentee voting in municipal elections, W. Va. Code, § 3-3-13; integration of municipal elections with systems of permanent; registration, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-13; special elections, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-15a. 

103.01 - ABSENTEE VOTING REGULATIONS. 
    The provisions of West Virginia Code Article 3-3 are hereby adopted, by reference, by the city as the law to govern and control absentee voting in all elections to be held by the city; provided, however, that the following modifications shall be made to implement the provisions of the State Code so as to develop and provide a complete and satisfactory absentee system for the city: 
(a)  After each and every reference in such article to absentee voting because of absence from the county or being absent from the county, the words "and the City of Huntington" shall be inserted. 
(b)  The words "after regular business hours" in West Virginia Code § 3-3-2 shall mean after 5:00 p.m., local time, whether or not the municipal offices or the city clerk's office regularly closes at that hour. 
(c)  The application for absent voter's ballot set forth in West Virginia Code § 3-3-3, in addition to the requirements therein set forth, shall state that the applicant is or will have been a resident of the city for 60 days next preceding that date of the ensuing election. 
(d)  All references to the clerk of the circuit court of the county shall be interpreted as meaning the city clerk. 
(e)  At any election at which, under state law, the ballot for the election cannot be prepared except within 30 days of the election, the mailing of ballots required under West Virginia Code § 3-3-5 shall commence as promptly as possible after such ballots are available. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-3.1) 
103.02 - VOTER REGISTRATION. 
    The registration of voters and the use of registration books for use in municipal elections shall be governed by the permanent registration laws of the state; and the registration records of Cabell and Wayne Counties are hereby adopted for the several precincts in such counties which are situated within or partly within the limits of the city, as amended and corrected according to law, as the official registration records of the city for municipal elections. No person who is not registered on the permanent registration records of Cabell or Wayne County in a precinct which is wholly or partly within the corporate limits of the city, shall be permitted to vote at a municipal election. 
(1964 Code Sec. 1-13.1) 
103.03 - VOTING MACHINES. 
    Voting machines shall be used in the conducting of all municipal elections unless precluded or prohibited by operation of law. The clerk of the city is authorized and directed to make all necessary arrangements for use of voting machines in the conducting of any such election. 
(1964 Code Sec. 1-13.2) 
ARTICLE 105 - MUNICIPAL VEHICLES AND MOBILE EQUIPMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Central garage and motor pool, § 14.11. 

105.01 - NAME OF CITY TO BE DISPLAYED. 
(a)  All city-owned motor vehicles and mobile equipment shall be plainly marked with the name "City of Huntington" and the number of such motor vehicle or piece of mobile equipment. Such lettering or marking shall be of a conspicuous color, and the letters thereof shall be not less than two inches high and not less than one inch wide and shall follow a general pattern or type of lettering as designated by the mayor. 
(b)  All cruiser cars and other motor vehicles or mobile equipment used by the police department shall also be so marked, except those cars that are operated by the detective bureau and used by that department for detective or secret work, which shall be marked on the inside of the motor vehicle on the instrument panel or other appropriate place plainly visible to persons in such automobile, with lettering similar to that required in subsection (a). 
(c)  All departments shall create a list by the 15th of each month requesting use of city vehicles for carriage of city employees to their residence or some other convenient location within the city limits of the City of Huntington when they are on call and/or duty other than normal working hours. 
(d)  At the determination of the chief of police a city police vehicle may be parked at a specified location to deter criminal activity and encourage a safer community. Upon authorization and placement of a police vehicle, the chief shall inform the mayor as to the location and purpose and expected results. 
(Ord. 1-22-01) 
105.02 - NUMBERS TO BE ASSIGNED. 
    The mayor shall assign a separate number to each motor vehicle and piece of motor equipment owned by the city. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-19) 
105.03 - TO BE USED ON CITY BUSINESS ONLY. 
    No city-owned motor vehicle or piece of mobile equipment shall be used except on business of the city. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-20) 
105.04 - GOING BEYOND CORPORATE LIMITS. 
    No city-owned motor vehicle or piece of mobile equipment shall be taken outside the corporate limits of the city without permission or order for each particular trip so taken from the head of the department to which such motor vehicle or piece of mobile equipment is assigned, except police cars when in fresh pursuit. When such permission is granted, the procedure set out in this section shall be followed. 
    When the motor vehicle or mobile equipment is assigned to the police department, a written record shall be made to the desk sergeant showing time of departure, destination and reason for leaving the city. Upon the return a report shall immediately be made to such desk sergeant of the time of such return. 
    When the motor vehicle or mobile equipment is assigned to the fire department, a written record similar in form to that required for the police department shall be made at the office of the chief of the fire department. 
    When the motor vehicle or mobile equipment is assigned to the department of public works, a written record similar in form to that required for the police department shall be made to the clerk at the city garage. 
    All other persons duly authorized to leave the city in city-owned motor vehicles or mobile equipment who are assigned or work in the City Hall, shall make the report in manner and in form as required by the police department to the clerk at the city engineer's office, if available, and if not available, the report will be made to the police desk sergeant; and upon return the report will be made at the same place as the report was made when leaving. 
    The written records of the departure from the city of city-owned motor vehicles and mobile equipment shall be retained in the office of the head of the department to which such motor vehicle or mobile equipment is assigned for at least 60 days from the date of return from such trip. The head of each department shall be responsible for the proper making of such reports. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-21) 
105.05 - ENFORCEMENT OF ARTICLE. 
    The mayor shall enforce this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-22) 
105.06 - LEAVING CITY VEHICLES UNATTENDED. 
(a)  No person or employee of the city responsible for the care, safeguarding, use or operation of any motor vehicle belonging to the city, or to the possession of which the city is entitled, shall park, place or leave the vehicle unattended overnight upon or in any public street or alley in or out of the city limits, or upon or in any private alley, way or property, either in or out of the city limits, unless such place be designated, specified and described by appropriate regulation, signed by the mayor and filed with the city clerk, as a place authorized by him for the overnight storage of city-owned vehicular equipment. No city vehicle shall be taken outside of the city limits unless approved by a director or the mayor with exception of emergency vehicles answering a summons where life, limb or property of the public is at great risk. 
(b)  No person or employee of the city shall park or place any vehicle or vehicular equipment owned by the city or to the possession of which the city is entitled in any place which unreasonably exposes the equipment to undue risk of theft, pilferage, tampering, vandalism or improper or unauthorized use. 
(c)  No person, firm or corporation shall encourage, aid, direct, assist or otherwise abet any other person in violating any of the provisions of this section. 
(d)  The city employee designated by the mayor, from time to time, to be in charge of the city's motor pool shall keep a continuing and permanent record book assigning and naming the person or persons to whom any vehicle or vehicular equipment was last issued for use by such person or persons in the performance of his or their work assignments. 
(e)  Upon a showing of probable cause that a violation of this section has been committed, the mayor or the city attorney may file an information for a warrant with the municipal court, which court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine the case. 
(f)  Any city employee violating the provisions of this ordinance shall be fined $50 upon the first offense, second offense the employee shall be fined $100 and suspended five days without pay, and upon third offense the employee shall be terminated for gross negligence and will be subject to legal action, both criminal and civil. The city shall have the right to subrogate any and all claims caused while in violation of this ordinance and such violation shall be considered outside the scope of employment. In such instances where there is unauthorized use of a city vehicle, the city may deny insurance coverage to the employee driving the vehicle and can charge the employee reasonable rates for the use of said vehicle to include costs of any repair or recovery of the said vehicle to include legal fees and associated miscellaneous costs by the administration. 
(Ord. 1-22-01) 
ARTICLE 106 - CAPITAL ASSET POLICY 

106.01 - CAPITAL ASSET POLICY. 
(a)  The City of Huntington shall maintain a fixed asset accounting system. The fixed asset system shall maintain sufficient information to permit the following: 
(1)  The preparation of year-end financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. 
(2)  Adequate insurance coverage. 
(3)  Control and accountability. 
(b)  Fixed assets are defined as those tangible assets of the city with (1) a useful life in excess of one year, (2) an initial cost equal to or exceeding $5,000, and (3) which the city intends to hold or continue in use over an extended period of time. If a single item does not meet the threshold amount, but is typically purchased in aggregate by the city, the finance division shall verify which items shall be classified as fixed assets and recorded at the time of purchase or acquisition. Further, some items may be identified as "controlled" assets that, although they do not meet all fixed asset criteria, are to be recorded on the fixed asset system to maintain control. 
(c)  Fixed assets shall be classified as follows: 
(1)  Land. 
(2)  Land improvements. 
(3)  Buildings. 
(4)  Structures and improvements. 
(5)  Machinery and equipment. 
(6)  Furniture and fixtures. 
(7)  Vehicles. 
(8)  Infrastructure. 
(9)  Construction-in-progress. 
(10)  Transmission and distribution. 
(d)  Fixed assets shall be recorded at actual, or if not determinable, estimated purchase price or fair market value at the time of acquisition. The method(s) to be used to estimate such price or market value historical cost shall be established by the finance director. 
(e)  The finance director shall develop administrative guidelines to address the proper purchase, transfer, and disposal of fixed assets. Such assets shall be disposed of in such a manner as will be in the public interest and benefit the city. 
(1)  Disposition of real property and personal property. Disposition of real property and personal property shall be in accordance with section 107.02 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington or any subsequent ordinance in effect at the time of the proposed disposition. 
(f)  The finance director shall verify whether an expense should be recorded as an improvement to a fixed asset or maintenance cost. An improvement of a fixed asset significantly increases its value, life or capacity to serve, and should be capitalized and depreciated over its life. Maintenance restores a fixed asset to its original level of service and should not be capitalized. 
(g)  Depreciation is the allocation of the cost of a fixed asset over its estimated useful life. Depreciation shall be recorded for funded fixed assets using the straight line depreciation method. 
(h)  The following information shall be maintained for all fixed assets: 
(1)  Description (including whether the item was acquired in aggregate). 
(2)  Asset classification (land, building, equipment, etc.) 
(3)  Location. 
(4)  Purchase price/cost, or if not determined: 
A.  Estimated cost/purchase price, 
B.  Estimated fair market value, 
C.  Contract price (including all related charges to place the fixed asset in conditions or in its place for the intended use), or 
D.  Appraised value at the time of acquisition (if obtained by gift/donated). 
(5)  Vendor. 
(6)  Date purchased/acquired. 
(7)  Estimated useful life. 
(8)  Accumulated depreciation. 
(i)  This policy extends to all agencies of the city unless such agency has an approved board policy setting a capitalization threshold amount other than $5,000. 
(Ord. of 7-28-14(2)) 
ARTICLE 107 - PURCHASING AND CONTRACTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Division of purchasing, § 9.7 et seq.; conflict of interest, § 14-10. 
State Law reference- Purchasing, competitive bidding, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-10. 

107.01 - PURCHASING. 
(a)  The director of the division of purchasing shall make all purchases of supplies, materials, equipment and services as authorized by council in the manner prescribed by this section and subject to the limitations imposed by the Charter of the city and general law. 
(b)  The following terms, conditions and procedures shall be followed by the city and suppliers in the procurement of goods and services for the city: 
(1)  The director of the division of purchasing shall initiate the competitive bidding procedures, as set out in this section, sixty days prior to the expiration of any contract which requires the approval of council. Provided, however, that the mayor may waive the 60-day requirement if he finds such waiver to be necessary and in the best interests of the city. 
(2)  All purchases of supplies, materials and equipment and services shall be pursuant to a written requisition from the head of the office, department or agency whose appropriation will be charged therewith; and such supplies, materials, equipment and services shall conform with specifications approved, established and enforced by the mayor. 
(3)  No purchase order shall be issued or contract executed, nor shall any other agreement purporting to obligate the city be entered into without a written approval signed by the director of the division of finance that there is sufficient unencumbered appropriation and allotment balance to cover the obligation. 
(4)  Before the director of the division of purchasing makes any purchase of or contract for supplies, materials and equipment, he shall give ample opportunity for competitive bidding under the general rules and regulations herein prescribed, and such further regulations as council may hereafter prescribe; nothing herein contained shall be construed as excepting individual contracts, purchases or sales from the requirement of competitive bidding, as required by the Charter. All such purchases, or the contracts for such purchases, shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder; provided, however, that any or all bids may be rejected in the manner and form prescribed in this article. 
(5)  "Split-bidding" is prohibited. The practice of "split-bidding" means the device of submitting multiple requisitions for the same supplies, materials, equipment or services where the sum of the cost of the several requisitions is equal to $15,000 or more, and splitting the department's requirements into several requisitions would thereby avoid the necessity for the city to require competitive sealed bids. The practice of split-bidding is hereby declared to be improper, illegal and against the public interest; and the head of the office, department or agency shall state on each requisition that such requisition represents the entire quantity presently known to be required and that the requisition is not a part of a device or scheme to avoid purchasing on competitive bidding or to otherwise evade the established purchasing procedures of the city. 
(6)  The city shall not accept the bid of any vendor or contractor who is in default on the payment of any taxes, licenses, fees or other monies of whatever nature that may be due the city from such vendor or contractor. 
(7)  A bidder, to qualify for an award of contract, shall have available experienced personnel to give adequate service on any equipment on which he submits a bid and shall maintain a supply of repair parts required for the maintenance of such equipment. 
(8)  Any capital expenditures, repairs, professional services or contracts for supplies costing more than $15,000 or any series of capital improvements, repairs, professional services or contracts for supplies constituting essentially a single project and costing in the aggregate more than $15,000 shall be executed by written contract except where such expenditure is authorized by council to be executed directly by the mayor in conformity with the detailed plans, specifications and estimates. All such contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder after such public notice and competitive bidding as prescribed herein and after a public opening of bids as likewise provided herein. The mayor shall have the power to reject all bids and readvertise the same. Any alterations in any contract may be made when authorized by council upon the written recommendation of the mayor, and all contractors under the provisions hereof shall be required to give approved performance and payment bonds secured by a surety company authorized to do business in the state. 
(c)  Notice inviting bids shall be published as a class I legal advertisement. Such notice shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased, shall state where bid blanks and written specifications may be secured, and the time and place for opening bids. Additional notice of such invitations to bid shall be posted on public bulletin boards in the municipal building. 
(d)  Bids shall be submitted sealed to the director of the division of purchasing and shall be identified as bids on the envelope. Such bids shall be opened in public and in the presence of at least three persons, including a representative from the mayor and city clerk's office and at the time and place stated in the public notices. A tabulation of all bids so received shall be posted on bulletin boards in the municipal building for public inspection, and sent to all bidders. This will be attested to by those present at the bid opening. 
(e)  Pursuant to the guidelines herein set out, the mayor shall have and hereby is granted the authority to reject any or all bids, parts of all bids, or all bids for any one or more supplies or contractual services included in the proposed contract. 
(f)  In determining the lowest responsible bidder, as referred to in subsection (b)(4) hereof, in addition to price, the city shall consider the following non-exclusive factors in determining whether a bid is not only the lowest bid but the lowest responsible bid: 
(1)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the services required along with the number of years bidder has been in business, familiarity with the project and bidder's record on similar projects; 
(2)  Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference and whether bidder generally experiences cost overruns; 
(3)  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder and the continuity of the bidder's work force; 
(4)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services; 
(5)  Bidder's bonding record, compliance with Workers' Compensation laws, unemployment laws, federal and state prevailing wage laws, Fair Labor Standards Act, fringe benefit contribution requirements, safety laws and regulations and ordinances relating to the contract or service; 
(6)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service; 
(7)  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies or contractual services to the particular use required; 
(8)  Bidder's compliance with completion details and the ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract; 
(9)  The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid; 
(10)  Whether the bidder's work force is drawn mainly from area residents; 
(11)  The bidder's participation in a bona fide apprenticeship program approved by the U.S. Department of Labor Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training and length of participation in said program; 
(12)  Bidder's involvement in a Drug Screening and Safety Program; 
(13)  Whether bidder furnishes hospitalization and pension benefits to their employees; 
(14)  Whether the bidder has a written non-discrimination policy in place; and 
(15)  Such purchase may be made from a vendor resident in the city if such bid does not exceed the lowest qualifying bid from a nonresident vendor by more than 4% of the latter such bid amount at the time the bid was submitted. A resident vendor is an individual, partnership, association or corporation maintaining an active bona-fide place of business within the city for a minimum of three years and maintaining therein a representative inventory of the commodities on which the bid is submitted, and in the case of a corporation, is duly qualified to do business and is in good standing under the laws of the state. 
All of the above factors, as supported by the accompanying contractor's qualification statement, will be considered by the City of Huntington in determining the "best" most qualified bid. No single criteria will be considered the controlling factor in determining whether a bid is, or is not, the "best" bid. If the recommended bid is not the lowest cost bid, all information as to why the recommended bidder was selected over the lowest bidder shall be presented to city council at the time the contract is on the council agenda for approval. 
(g)  The provisions of subsection (f) shall apply only to contracts for construction, reconstruction, demolition, repair, maintenance, paving or other similar activities which require approval of council exceeding $15,000. No contract, bid or project shall be divided, severed or otherwise altered to avoid the provisions of subsection (f) above. 
(h)  When deemed necessary, bid deposits shall be prescribed and noted in the public notices inviting bids. The deposit shall be in such amount as the director of the division of purchasing determines, and unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to return of the deposits where such have been required. A successful bidder shall forfeit any required deposit upon failure on his part to enter a contract within ten days after the award, if a specified time is not stated in the bid specifications. 
(i)  The mayor is hereby granted the authority to require payment and performance bonds before entering a contract, in such amount as he finds reasonably necessary to protect the best interests of the city. 
(j)  Notwithstanding the procedures as set out in subsections (a) through (i) hereof, the director of the division of purchasing is hereby authorized with prior approval of the department of finance and administration of the state to purchase supplies and equipment for the city pursuant to W. Va. Code, § 8-12-10 when it is deemed that such purchases will result in a substantial saving to the city. 
(k)  Notwithstanding the procedures as set out in subsections (a) through (j) hereof, emergency purchases in the open market may be authorized by the mayor, in writing, for a department to purchase in the open market without filing requisition or estimate, specific commodities for immediate delivery to meet bona fide emergencies arising from unforeseen causes that relate to the health and safety of the public. A report of any such purchase, together with a record of the competitive bids, upon which it was based, shall be submitted at once to the mayor and council by the head of the department concerned, together with a full account of other circumstances of the emergency. 
For the purposes of this subparagraph, a bona fide emergency is hereby defined as a sudden and unexpected or unforeseen combination of occurrence, and circumstances resulting therefrom, which, for the protection of the public health or safety, demand immediate action or remedy, which constitute a pressing necessity, and which were not, and could not have been, reasonably anticipated in the exercise of reasonable judgment. 
(l)  Anything herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding, except for subsection (k) above, no purchasing contract shall be made or entered into by the mayor or by the purchasing officer of the city in any amount in excess of $15,000 without the approval of council of such purchase having been given prior to entering into such purchase contract. 
(m)  Within five days of the making of any emergency expenditures amounting, in the aggregate, to more than $15,000, the mayor shall report, in writing, the fact that such expenditures have been made. Such report shall be filed with the city clerk who shall promptly provide copies of the report to the members of council. Such report shall specify with particularity the amount of each expenditure, and to whom made, and shall be supported by copies of receipts and invoices relating thereto. The mayor shall also specify and describe in the report, with particularity, the facts which caused and constituted the emergency requiring such expenditures to be made. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
107.02 - SALE AND DISPOSAL OF PROPERTY. 
(a)  The mayor may require the director of the division of purchasing to transfer to or between departments supplies, materials and equipment. In the event any such transfer of supplies, materials and equipment shall exceed in value the sum of $15,000, the department head of the department making such transfer shall, through the office of the mayor, obtain advance approval for such transfer from council. The department head of the department making such transfer, when such transfer exceeds the sum of $15,000 shall also report such transfers through the mayor's office to council. When it is determined by the mayor that materials and/or equipment exist which are not needed by any city department, council may authorize the mayor to direct the sale thereof; and the proceeds from any sale or sales shall be deposited in the appropriate fund of the city. 
(b)  The director of the division of purchasing, duly authorized, may obtain competitive, formal or informal quotations for the sale and disposal of surplus, obsolete, unused materials or equipment. 
(1)  In any such event, the director of the division of purchasing shall cause notice of sale to be published as provided in W. Va. Code, § 8-12-18, giving a general description of the items to be sold or where bids are to be received and/or the time and place of the sale. 
(2)  Surplus is to be sold, as prescribed by W. Va. Code, § 8-12-18, to the highest and best bidder with the right retained by the city to reject any or all bids. 
(3)  At the time and place of sale of such surplus, sealed bids shall be submitted to the director of the division of purchasing and shall be identified as bids on the envelope. Such bids shall be opened in public in the presence of at least three persons. Oral bids at a public auction may be considered by the director after giving proper notice of such fact. 
(4)  Depending on the nature of such surplus offered, the director of the division of purchasing may require that cash or a cashier's check in an amount equal to 15% of the price bid shall be deposited by the bidder at the time of making or submitting his bid. The person to whom any such bid is awarded, either by sealed bid or at public auction, shall consummate the purchase within five days from and excluding the day of the award of such bid. Should the successful bidder fail to consummate the purchase within the five-day period specified above, the cash deposit made by such bidder shall be forfeited to the city. 
(Ord. 12-28-09) 
107.03 - ASSISTANCE TO SMALL AND DISADVANTAGED BUSINESSES. 
(a)  As used in this article: 
(1)  "Disadvantaged business" means a small business which is owned or controlled by a majority of persons, not limited to members of minority groups, who have been deprived of the opportunity to develop and maintain a competitive position in the economy because of social disadvantages. 
(2)  "Small business" means a business which is independently owned and which is not dominant in its field of operation or an affiliate or subsidiary of a business dominant in its field of operation. 
(b)  Assistance to small and disadvantaged businesses shall be by solicitation. The director of purchasing shall maintain a bidders list of small and disadvantaged businesses, and shall solicit those firms on such list for each procurement for which they are qualified. 
(Ord. 12-28-09) 
107.04 - APPLICABILITY TO MUNICIPAL AGENCIES. 
    This article shall, except as otherwise provided herein, govern all purchasing transactions of the city, including, but not limited to, the Big Sandy Superstore Arena, the Huntington Municipal Parking Board, the department of development and all other municipal agencies of the city including these sometimes referred to as "enterprise" organizations or as "special revenue accounts". 
(Ord. 12-28-09) 
ARTICLE 109 - OFFICIAL STANDARDS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Computation of time, § 101.03(c). 
State Law reference- Legal holidays, W. Va. Code, § 2-2-1; daylight savings time, W. Va. Code § 5-1-25; seal, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-1(1). 

109.01 - OFFICIAL SEAL. 
    The official seal of the city shall be in the form and design as set forth, delineated and described upon the copy annexed to the official copy of an ordinance adopted November 27, 1972, on file in the city clerk's office, and made a part hereof as fully as though incorporated herein. On such occasions that the same is reproduced other than by impression and/or in black and white, the same shall be reproduced only in the precise colors delineated on such official copy. It shall be unlawful for any person to use, imprint or reproduce such seal in any manner whatsoever without being authorized so to do by council. 
(1964 Code Sec. 1-18) 
ARTICLE 111 - INDEMNIFICATION OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Indemnification of officers, agents and employees, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-7. 

111.01 - PURPOSE. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide authority for the mayor with the concurrence of council by resolution or motion, to indemnify with city funds or provide liability insurance for any officer, agent or employee of the city. 
    It is the intent of this article to provide indemnification and liability insurance coverage as extensive as permitted by W. Va. Code, § 8-12-7, as amended, unless otherwise restricted or limited by this article. 
111.02 - INDEMNIFICATION. 
    The city shall indemnify all of its elected or appointed officers, agents or employees against any and all legal liability, including, but not limited to, expenses, costs, damages, judgments, fines, settlements, court costs, reasonable attorneys fees, and any other amounts actually and personally incurred in connection with, arising from, growing out of, by reason of or in any way connected with, any acts or omissions of the city, or its officers, agents or employees while acting within the scope of their official duties. 
    Such indemnification shall extend to any officer, agent or employee of the city who was or is a party, or is threatened to be made a party, to any proceeding by reason of the fact that such person is or was an officer, agent or employee of the city, without regard to the period of time in which such official duties were performed, and without regard to the fact that the performance of such official duties may have been professional in nature. 
    Such indemnification shall be provided to the officers, agents or employees of the city by the purchase of insurance as provided in section 111.03, or by the expenditure of funds from the general fund of the city as provided in section 111.04. 
111.03 - INSURANCE. 
    The mayor, with the concurrence of council, shall have plenary power and authority to contract and expend public funds for the purchase of one or more policies of public liability insurance, which may include professional liability insurance, providing the city and its officers, agents and employees, insurance coverage for any and all legal liability, including but not limited to, expenses, costs, damages, judgments, fines, settlements, court costs, reasonable attorneys fees, and any other amounts actually and personally incurred in connection with, arising from, growing out of, by reason of or in any way connected with, any acts or omissions of the city, or its officers, agents or employees while acting within the scope of their official duties. 
111.04 - EXPENDITURES FROM GENERAL FUND. 
    If the insurance coverage provided pursuant to section 111.02 is deemed to exclude an act or omission of the city or any of its officers, agents or employees, or if an insurance carrier refuses to provide coverage for the city or any of its officers, agents or employees for any reason, expenditures from the city's general fund shall be made for payment of any and all of the legal liability contemplated by section 111.02. 
111.05 - EXCLUSIONS. 
    No indemnification shall be made under this article to any officer, agent or employee of the city for: any conversion or diversion of public funds; any criminal act as defined by the laws of the United States, any state, municipality or other governmental body; any criminal act which could or does result in civil liability to any third party or the city; any act or omission committed by such officer, agent or employee while the same was insane or mentally incompetent; any amounts in settling or otherwise disposing of a threatened or pending proceeding without approval of the city; any expenses incurred in defending a threatened or pending proceeding which is settled or otherwise disposed of without approval of the city. 
    Provided however, none of the exclusions contained herein shall be interpreted to inure to the benefit of any liability or other insurance carrier of the city, unless specifically contained in the contract of insurance between the city and such carrier. 
111.06 - INDEMNIFICATION BY INDEPENDENT AGENCIES. 
    Any of the independent agencies of the city shall likewise have plenary power and authority to adopt a resolution at a regular or special meeting called for that purpose providing for the expenditure of the public funds of such agency to indemnify its elected or appointed officers, agents or employees for any acts or omissions while acting within the scope of their official duties in the manner and to the extent provided in this article. 
ARTICLE 113 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency services, W. Va. Code, Art. 15-5. 

113.01 - DEFINITION. 
    As used in this article, "emergency services" means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions, other than functions for which the military are primarily responsible, necessary to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from disasters caused by enemy attack, fire, flood or other natural causes. 
(1964 Code Sec. 9-1) 
113.02 - POLICY AND PURPOSE. 
    In view of the possibility of local disasters resulting from enemy attack, fire, flood or other natural causes, and in order to insure that preparations of this city will be adequate to provide for the common defense and to protect the public peace, health and safety, it is hereby found desirable: 
(a)  To create an emergency services agency as authorized by law; 
(b)  To provide for the rendering of mutual aid to other cities within the state and, if necessary and only by compact with the approval of the governor, the neighboring cities and counties of another state; 
(c)  To cooperate with the state government with respect to carrying out emergency services functions. 
(1964 Code Sec. 9-2) 
113.03 - ADVISORY COUNCIL. 
    There is hereby created an emergency services advisory council, which shall consist of five residents appointed by the mayor subject to conformation by council, who shall advise the emergency services director on all matters pertaining to emergency services. The members of the advisory council shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for the reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. 
(1964 Code Sec. 9-3) 
113.04 - DIRECTOR: APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES GENERALLY. 
    The mayor shall appoint a director of emergency services, who shall perform such duties as are imposed upon him by this article, and as are delegated to him when not contrary to the provisions of this article or other resolutions or ordinances of the city. 
(1964 Code Sec. 9-4) 
113.05 - DIRECTOR: POWERS AND DUTIES. 
    The director of emergency services shall coordinate the activities of all organizations for emergency services within the city and shall maintain liaison with and cooperate with the emergency services agencies and organizations within the state and within the state government. The director shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of the city organization for emergency services, subject to the direction and control of the mayor. 
    In performing his duties under this article, the director of emergency services is authorized to cooperate with the state government, with other cities and counties, and with private agencies in all matters pertaining to emergency services within the city and the state. 
    In performing his duties under this article, and to effect its policy and purpose, the director is further authorized and empowered: 
(a)  To make, amend and rescind the necessary orders, rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this article within the limits of the authority conferred upon him, with due consideration of the plans of the state government. 
(b)  To prepare a comprehensive plan and program for emergency services within the city, such plan and program to be integrated into and coordinated with the emergency services plans of the state government and of other cities and counties within the state to the fullest extent. 
(c)  In accordance with such plan and program for emergency services within the City, to procure supplies and equipment, to institute training programs and public information programs and to take all other preparatory steps including the partial or full mobilization of the emergency services organization in advance of actual disaster, to insure the furnishing of adequately trained and equipped forces of emergency services personnel in time of need. 
(d)  To make such studies and surveys of the industries, resources and facilities in the city as may be necessary to ascertain the capabilities of the city in an emergency, and to plan for the most efficient use thereof. 
(e)  On behalf of the city, to enter into mutual aid arrangements with other cities and counties within the state, and also, with the approval of the Governor, with emergency services agencies or organizations of other states, for reciprocal emergency services aid and assistance in case of disaster too great to be dealt with unassisted. 
(f)  To delegate any administrative authority invested in him under this article, and to provide for the subdelegation of any such authority. 
(g)  To cooperate with the Governor and the state division of emergency services and with officials and agencies of other cities and counties within the state, in matters pertaining to the emergency services of the city and state. 
(1964 Code Sec. 9-5) 
113.06 - APPROPRIATIONS AND GIFTS. 
    Whenever the federal or state government or any agency or officer thereof or any other person offers to the city services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds by way of gift, grant or loan, for purposes of emergency services the city, acting with the consent of the Governor and through council, may accept such offer, and upon such acceptance, council may authorize any officer of the city to receive such services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds on behalf of the city, subject to the terms of the offer and the rules and regulations, if any, of the agency making the offer. 
(1964 Code Sec. 9-6) 
113.07 - UTILIZATION OF EXISTING SERVICES AND FACILITIES. 
    In carrying out the provisions of this article, the director of emergency services is authorized to utilize such services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments, offices and agencies of the city as may, in the judgment of council or the mayor, be reasonably provided under circumstances then existing. 
(1964 Code Sec. 9-7) 
113.08 - APPOINTMENT AND AUTHORITY OF PUBLIC FALLOUT SHELTER MANAGERS. 
    The director of emergency services, with the approval of council, shall appoint managers for public shelters. In case of a national emergency, such public shelter managers shall open public shelters, take charge of all stocks of food, water and other supplies stored in the shelters, admit the public according to the community shelter plan and take whatever control measures are necessary for the protection and safety of the occupants. Shelter managers are authorized to use reasonable restraint against those who refuse to cooperate with the routine of shelter living under emergency conditions. No person shall refuse to carry out the orders of a public shelter manager in time of a national emergency. 
(1964 Code Sec. 9-8) 
ARTICLE 115 - PAYMENT OF MUNICIPAL FEES BY THE MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL 

115.01 - INTRODUCTION. 
    It is recognized that the mayor and the members of city council, as municipal civic leaders, should set an example of good citizenship. Part of being a good citizen is keeping current on payment of taxes and fees. Therefore, it is the intent of this council to hold the city's elected leaders to a higher standard and permit internal garnishments of the financial compensation of any elected municipal leader that fall significantly behind on municipal fees. 
( Ord. of 4-13-15(4) ) 
115.02 - MUNICIPAL ARREARAGES. 
(a)  If the mayor or any member of council is found to be in arrears on his or her municipal service fees, refuse service fees, city service fees, franchise fees, and/or any other type of fees owed to the City of Huntington, the finance director, or his/her designee, shall cause a notice of impending garnishment to be sent to the delinquent elected official. The notice shall provide said elected official with a deadline not to exceed two weeks by which the official must respond. The notice shall also direct the official to the person and/or office responsible for receiving the response. If the arrearage is not resolved by the expiration of the deadline provided, the finance director shall withhold from said elected official's regular compensation up to 25% of the gross sum of every payout until such arrearage is brought current. 
(b)  The municipal accounts of the mayor and members of city council may be reviewed for arrearages at any time. However, at a minimum, the finance director, or his/her designee, shall cause the municipal accounts of the mayor and each city council member to be reviewed annually on or before December 31. 
( Ord. of 4-13-15(4) ) 
115.03 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purpose of this section the following definitions shall apply: 
(a)  Arrears or arrearage: A person shall be deemed to be in arrears if he or she has not paid a minimum of two payment periods. 
(b)  Payment period: A payment period is the regular time period wherein fees, taxes or a payment arrangement agreement are due, whether it be a month, a quarter, or a year. 
( Ord. of 4-13-15(4) ) 
115.04 - EXCEPTIONS. 
    This section shall not apply to any elective official who is in a signed payment arrangement agreement with the legal department and is current under the terms of the agreement. 
( Ord. of 4-13-15(4) ) 
CHAPTER THREE - LEGISLATIVE 
ARTICLE 121 - COUNCIL[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- Council generally, Art. Three; action on budget, § 10.6; action on capitol program, § 10.7; recall, Art. Twelve; oath, § 14.14. 
State Law reference- Open meeting law, W. Va. Code, Art. 6-9A; extraterritorial excise of powers, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-19. 

121.01 - SPECIAL MEETINGS OF COUNCIL; NOTICE REQUIRED; SERVICE OF PROCESS. 
    Special meetings of council may be called at any time, upon reasonable notice by the mayor or the chairperson of council, and shall be so called by the chairperson upon the request of a majority of all members of council. The requirement of reasonable notice may be satisfied by delivering to each member of council a written notice of the time, place and purpose of the special meeting in the method provided by law for the service of process in a civil action at least 12 hours prior to the time set for the meeting; or by transmission of such notice to each member of council by facsimile, provided, that, written confirmation of the receipt of the notice by facsimile by each member of council so notified is duly filed in the office of the city clerk at or before the time set for the special meeting; or by verbal communication of the time, place and purpose of the special meeting to each member of council by means of telephone, provided, that, such verbal communication shall be conveyed to each member of council by the city clerk or the assistant city clerk, and further provided, that, the city clerk or the assistant city clerk shall duly attest to such verbal communications by affidavit, in writing and under oath, and shall file such attestation affidavit in the office of the city clerk at or before the time set for the special meeting. The city clerk and the assistant city clerk shall be charged with the enforcement of this section. 
(Ord. 9-24-96)

CHAPTER FIVE - ADMINISTRATIVE 
ARTICLE 131 - MAYOR[10] 

Footnotes:

131.01 - SALE OR TRADE OF CITY PROPERTY BY MAYOR. 
    The mayor shall have authority from time to time, in his discretion, to sell, or trade as part payment on new purchases, any property, other than real estate, belonging to the city which is deemed by him to be surplus or not needed, and which does not exceed $500 in value, at such price as the mayor shall fix and with or without advertising, as he determines to be for the best interest of the city. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-3)

ARTICLE 135 - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS[12]
