135.01 - OFFICIAL MAP OF CITY. 
    A map entitled "Official Map of the City of Huntington, West Virginia, showing triangulation, co-ordinates and bench marks, scale 1 inch-300 feet" is hereby adopted as the official map of the city. This map shall be maintained in the office of the city engineer and shall be open at all times to inspection to anyone interested. 
(1964 Code Sec. 1-15) 
ARTICLE 137 - DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCE[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Charter reference- General provisions, Art. Nine; budget and financial procedures, Art. Ten; Public accessibility of records, § 14-12. 
Cross reference- Purchasing; competitive bidding, Art. 107. 
State Law reference- Supervision of public offices, W. Va. Code, Art. 6-9; collection of moneys, W. Va. Code § 8-13-15 et seq.; financial statements, W. Va. Code § 8-13-23; accounting principles; funds, W. Va. Code, § 8-13-17 et seq.; 

137.01 - REGULATIONS FOR PAYMENT OF MONEY OUT OF CITY TREASURY. 
    No money belonging to the city shall be paid out of the city treasury except upon an order signed by the director of the division of finance and mayor and properly endorsed. 
    The signature of the director and mayor upon such orders, authorizing the payment of such orders by a depository, may be made by means of such mechanical or electrical device as council may select. Such mechanical or electrical device for the making of the signatures of the director and the mayor shall be safely kept in the office of the director so that no one shall have access thereto except the director and the mayor. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-1) 
137.02 - ISSUANCE OF LICENSES AND PERMITS. 
    All applications for permits or licenses shall be approved by the officer required by ordinance to issue the permit or license, but such license or permit shall be issued by such officer only upon payment of the proper fee to the director of the division of finance and presentation of the receipt of the director. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-2) 
137.03 - REVOLVING CONSTRUCTION FUND; REPAYMENT BY ASSESSMENTS. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 8-18-12, there is hereby created a revolving fund in the sum of $25,000 to be utilized by the city in financing improvements to be paid from such fund, upon council, from time to time, determining by ordinance or resolution to pay for such improvements chargeable to such fund. 
    Upon council's determining by ordinance or resolution to pay for the work completed from such unappropriated funds for the cost of which assessments are levied, council shall certify such assessments to the director of the division of finance for collection in accordance with the terms provided in the ordinance or resolution authorizing the improvements. 
    Upon receipt of installments of an assessment for such improvements by the director, he shall, on behalf of the city, credit the same to the fund herein created, all in accordance with the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 8-18-12. 
    The mayor is authorized and empowered to do all acts necessary to set up such fund and allocate the amount herein provided for to the fund. 
(1964 Code Sec. 1-19) 
137.04 - REPORTING PROCEDURES. 
(a)  There shall be included in the report on revenue by source a report of all cash receipts of the Huntington Civic Arena showing the amounts and sources thereof. 
(b)  There shall be included in the budget comparison report a report of all amounts appropriated by council, from time to time, to various line items for the operation of the Huntington Civic Arena, as well as all amounts expended or encumbered of each such line item, as is done for other municipal departments, offices and agencies. 
(c)  In addition to the other reports, there shall be filed during each period described below a profit and loss statement and balance statement for the Civic Arena. 
(d)  Such reports shall be completed and distributed to council and to other appropriate department heads whose departmental budgets are reported in such monthly statements no later than the twentieth day of each calendar month in each fiscal year. 
(Ord. 1-28-91) 
137.05 - APPROPRIATION OF FUNDS. 
    The director of the division of finance shall: 
(a)  Supervise and be responsible for the disbursement of all moneys and have control over all expenditures to ensure that budget appropriations are not exceeded; 
(b)  Approve all proposed expenditures after determining that there is an unencumbered balance of appropriated and available funds within the expenditure line item. The director shall not approve an expenditure unless there is an unencumbered balance of appropriated and available funds within the expenditure line item. 
(c)  Examine and approve all contracts and other documents by which the city incurs financial obligations, having previously ascertained that moneys have been appropriated and allotted and will be available when the obligation becomes due and payable. The administration shall not enter into any contracts or incur any obligations unless funds have previously been appropriated to meet such obligations when they become due. 
(Ord. 1-28-91) 
ARTICLE 141 - POLICE DEPARTMENT[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Charter reference- Chief of Police, § 14.1. 
State Law reference- Appointment of special police, W. Va. Code § 8-10-1; powers and duties, W. Va. Code §§ 8-14-1, 8-14-3; hours of duty; holidays, W. Va. Code, §§ 8-14-2, 8-14-2a; school zone officers, W. Va. Code, § 8-14-5; parking lot or building officers, W. Va. Code, § 8-14-5a; civil service, W. Va. Code, § 8-14-6 et seq.; pension and relief fund, W. Va. Code, Art. 8-22. 

141.01 - ESTABLISHED. 
    There is hereby established a police department of the city, which department shall be composed of such officers, patrolmen and other employees as are designated in this article or may be provided for by council. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-1) 
141.02 - DUTIES GENERALLY. 
    The police department shall have the duty to preserve the public peace of the city, prevent crimes and arrest offenders, protect the rights of persons and properties and enforce all laws and ordinances which may be properly enforced by the police department. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-2) 
141.03 - CONTROL BY MAYOR; PROMULGATION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
    The mayor shall have the active control of the police department and be the executive head thereof. He shall appoint, in the manner provided by law, all employees in the department and shall prescribe and promulgate general rules and regulations governing the operation of the department. All employees of the police department shall be subject to such rules and regulations. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-3) 
141.04 - APPOINTMENTS, REMOVALS, SUSPENSIONS. 
    All appointments, promotions, removals, demotions, suspensions, reinstatements and reductions in the police department shall be made by the mayor, in accordance with the provisions of state law and the Charter of the city. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-4) 
141.05 - CHIEF OF POLICE. 
    There shall be a chief of police, who shall be charged with the duties of managing and controlling the operations of the police department, under such general rules and regulations as the mayor may prescribe. The chief shall have control of the stationing and transfer of all officers and patrolmen in the department and shall have the authority peremptorily to suspend, demote or discharge any subordinate for neglect of duty, disobedience of orders, misconduct or failure to perform his duties properly; provided that such disciplinary action shall be in accordance with state law and the City Charter. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-5) 
141.06 - CAPTAINS. 
    Council shall determine from time to time the number of captains in the police department, who shall perform such duties as may be designated by the chief of police. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-6) 
141.07 - LIEUTENANTS. 
    Council shall determine from time to time the number of lieutenants in the police department, who shall perform such duties as may be designated by the chief of police. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-7) 
141.08 - SERGEANTS. 
    Council shall determine from time to time the number of sergeants in the police department, who shall perform such duties as may be designated by the chief of police. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-8) 
141.09 - CORPORAL. 
    Council shall determine from time to time the number of corporals in the police department who shall perform such duties as may be designated by the chief of police. Officers holding the rank of Officer First Class immediately prior to the passage of this section shall hold the rank of corporal. 
(Ord. 11-12-91) 
141.10 - POLICE OFFICERS. 
    Council shall determine from time to time the number of police officers in the police department, who shall perform such duties as may be designated by the chief of police. 
(Ord. 11-12-91) 
141.11 - OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT OF POLICEMEN PROHIBITED. 
    Members of the police department shall devote their whole time to the business of the department and are expressly prohibited from being employed in or giving their personal attention to any other business or employment; provided, that the chief of police is authorized to exempt from this prohibition members of the department who request permission to engage in off-duty employment which, in the opinion of the chief of police, will not be detrimental to the best interests of the department. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-12) 
141.12 - SALES OF STOLEN PROPERTY RECOVERED BY POLICE; PROPERTY CONFISCATED BY POLICE. 
    Except as otherwise provided, the chief of police shall every two months, sell at public auction all property, of every kind and character, stolen and recovered by the police and to which no claim has been made by anyone entitled to the possession thereof, and all property of every kind and character confiscated by the police, except weapons. None of the property described in this section shall be sold within 30 days after the same has been recovered or confiscated, and no separate item of property having a value of more than $20 shall be sold until the sale thereof has been advertised once each week for two weeks in a newspaper published in the city, the advertisement to contain a description of the property to be sold and the place of sale. The chief of police shall make a full and complete report of all such sales and pay the proceeds thereof to the director of the division of finance and take from him a receipt therefor, and the proceeds are hereby appropriated to the general fund of the city. All weapons shall be disposed of in accordance with the order of the municipal court. 
(Ord. 3-22-82) 
141.13 - EVACUATION AND CONTROL OF CROWDS DURING DISASTERS. 
    In the event of a disaster or imminent disaster, resulting or about to result from enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile action or from fire, flood, earthquake or other natural causes or from crash of aircraft, train wreck, explosion or other like catastrophe, the police officers of the city are authorized to evacuate all or part of the residents from any stricken or threatened area within the city wherein such disaster has occurred or is about to occur, and to take such action as may be necessary to control crowds in such area. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to obey and carry out the lawful order of a police officer assigned to such disaster area. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-16) 
141.14 - POLICEMEN'S READJUSTMENT BENEFIT. 
(a)  Established; funds generally. There is hereby established a benefit fund to be known as the "Policemen's Readjustment Benefit." The funds becoming a part thereof shall be held by the director of the division of finances as all accrued or accruing salary of members of the police department is held, and the same shall be disbursed as and when all other salary disbursements are made. 
(b)  Composition of benefit fund. The benefit fund established by this section shall be constituted and composed of the following: 
(1)  The amounts of pay, based only on the prevailing policemen's basic rate, without any additional amount because of rank, which shall be earned by reason of one day's work or service in the police department rendered as requested or directed by the chief of police by each participating member after the death of a participating member of such department; and 
(2)  In the event the participating member for whose benefit such benefit fund is created, dies from injuries suffered while actually engaged in the performance of his duties in such department, such amount of salary for one month after such death as such member would have received had he lived and performed his duty, which amount shall be payable by the city as a part of such benefit. 
(c)  Contributions to fund by participating members. Each participating member of the benefit fund established by this section shall agree to work or serve, at the prevailing basic rate of pay for policemen, one day in the police department, for and in the place of and after the death of each participating member, as and when directed by the police chief, and to assign an order paid into such fund the amount so earned by such day's work, for disbursement to the beneficiary of the deceased member for whose beneficiary such work or service is performed, and each participating member shall execute and deliver to the director of the division of finance within 30 days after having become a member of such department such form of assignment and consent as may be desired by the city or its disbursing officer for such purpose. 
(d)  Who may participate. The benefit established by this section shall be only for those who are beneficiaries of the active members of the city police department who have agreed to this benefit plan and have executed the agreement and assignment specified in subsection (c) hereof and who have performed prior to such member's death all his duties hereunder in regard to the one day's work or service for the benefit of the beneficiary of every participating member who has predeceased such member, and no member who is drawing retirement or permanent (not temporary) disability pension shall be a participating member of such benefit plan. 
(e)  Beneficiaries; payment of funds. The beneficiary of the plan established by this section shall be only one of the following relationships to the deceased participating member: widow, son, daughter, mother, father, sister or brother. The funds to be paid shall be payable to the widow exclusively, if she is the survivor, otherwise to such other eligible beneficiary as may be approved by the Fraternal Order of Police, Local No. 65. Such payment shall be made personally to the beneficiary and shall not be assignable by any beneficiary or liable for any claim against the estate of the deceased participating member or his beneficiary. The beneficiary shall by acceptance of any payment of the benefit waive any claim for pension from the policemen's pension fund during or for the period such beneficiary, if so entitled hereunder, received the one month's salary provided for in subsection (b) hereof. 
(1964 Code Secs. 27-18 to 27-22) 
141.15 - POLICEMEN'S PENSION OR RELIEF FUND. 
    The administration of the policemen's pension or relief fund and payment made from such fund shall be as provided by council by ordinance. 
(1964 Code Sec. 27-23) 
141.16 - RESERVE POLICE UNIT. 
(a)  The mayor may, for the purposes hereinafter set forth, designate and appoint a Huntington Police Department reserve unit, hereinafter referred to as "reserve" or "reserves." 
(b)  The reserve unit in existence as of the effective date of this ordinance will remain in effect without any further action of Council. 
(c)  Police chief may appoint as members of the reserve bona fide citizens of the City of Huntington, or non-residents as the chief may deem necessary and appropriate, who are of good moral character and who have not been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude. Any person so appointed shall serve at the will and pleasure of the police chief and is not subject to the provisions of article fourteen, chapter eight of the West Virginia Code providing for paid police officers. A member of the reserve may not engage in any political activity or campaign involving any municipal office or from which activity or campaign the candidates therefor appointing the member would directly benefit. 
(d)  Members of the reserves shall not serve as law-enforcement officers, nor carry firearms, but may carry other weapons, provided that the police chief certifies in writing to the mayor that the reserve has met the special training requirements for the weapon as established by the governor's committee on crime, delinquency and corrections. The reserves may be provided with radio communication equipment for the purpose of maintaining contact with the Huntington Police Department or other law-enforcement agencies. The duties of the reserves shall be limited to crowd control or traffic control and direction within the City of Huntington. In addition, the reserves may perform such other duties of a nonlaw-enforcement nature as are designated by the police chief or by a subordinate designated and appointed by the police chief for that purpose. 
(e)  Members of the reserves may be uniformed; however, if so uniformed, the uniforms shall clearly differentiate these members from sworn officers of the Huntington Police Department. 
(f)  After appointment to the reserves but prior to service each member of the reserves shall receive appropriate training and instruction in their functions and authority as well as the limitations of authority. 
(g)  Each member of the reserve shall take the same oath as prescribed by Section five, Article IV of the Constitution of the State of West Virginia, but the taking of the oath does not serve to make the member a public officer. 
(h)  The City of Huntington shall provide for liability insurance of each member of the reserve. 
(i)  A member of the reserve is not an employee of either the Huntington Police Department or City of Huntington for any purpose or purposes, including, but not limited to, the purposes of workers' compensation, civil service, unemployment compensation, public employees retirement, public employees insurance or for any other purpose. A member of the reserves may not receive any compensation or pay for any services performed as a member nor may a member use the designated uniform for any other similar work performed. 
(1964 Code Secs. 27-24 to 27-31; Ord. of 11-23-15(2) ) 
141.17 - POLICE ALARM SYSTEMS; TERMINATIONS AT POLICE COMMUNICATIONS CENTER. 
Editor's note- Former Section 141.17 was repealed by Ordinance 10-27-97, passed October 27, 1997. 
ARTICLE 143 - FIRE DEPARTMENT[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Charter reference- Fire chief, § 14.2. 
State Law reference- Fire protection contracts, W. Va. Code §§ 8-15-3, 8-12-5(56); paid fire departments, W. Va. Code § 8-15-9 et seq.; civil service, W. Va. Code § 8-15-11 et seq.; pension and relief fund, W. Va. Code, Art. 8-22; authority of local fire departments, W. Va. Code Art. 29-3A. 

143.01 - ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION; PURPOSE AND DUTIES. 
    There is hereby established the fire department of the city, which department shall be composed of such officers and firemen as are designated by this article or as may be provided by council. The city fire department shall protect the lives and property of the people of the city in case of fire and shall perform all other activities and duties not inconsistent with this article as may be required by council or the mayor. 
(1964 Code Sec. 11-1) 
143.02 - MAYOR TO CONTROL; RULES GENERALLY. 
    The mayor shall have active control of the fire department and shall be the executive head thereof. He shall appoint, according to law, all officers and firemen of such department and shall prescribe general rules governing the operation of such department. All officers and firemen shall be subject to such rules. 
(1964 Code Sec. 11-2) 
143.03 - VIOLATION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS OR GENERAL OR SPECIAL ORDERS. 
    Violation of any rules and regulations established by the mayor or of the general or special orders of the fire department shall be punished by reprimand, loss of time, suspension or dismissal. Members of the fire department shall take notice of all such violations and shall prefer, or cause to be preferred, charges against the person so violating. Such charges shall be forwarded to the chief of the fire department. The charges shall contain a brief recital of the facts and circumstances of the violation. Any member under suspension or cited for dismissal may avail himself of a hearing as provided by law. Prior charges and the disposition thereof against any person charged with a violation shall be made known to the authority charged with the disposition of the violation. 
(1964 Code Sec. 11-3) 
143.04 - APPOINTMENTS, REMOVALS. 
    All appointments, promotions, removals, transfers, layoffs, suspensions, demotions and reinstatements in the city fire department shall be made by the mayor, in accordance with the provisions of state law and the Charter of the city. 
(1964 Code Sec. 11-4) 
143.05 - CHIEF. 
    There shall be a chief of the city fire department, who shall be charged with the duties of managing and controlling the operations thereof under such general rules and regulations as the mayor may prescribe. Such chief shall have control of the stationing and transfer of all officers and firemen in such department and shall have the authority to peremptorily suspend, demote or discharge any subordinate then under his direction for neglect of duty, disobedience of orders or misconduct; provided, that all procedures prescribed by state law shall be followed in any such action. 
(1964 Code Sec. 11-5) 
143.06 - DEPUTY CHIEF. 
    There shall be not to exceed four deputy chiefs of the fire department who, when on duty, shall be second in command to the chief and shall have authority to act for and in place of the chief in case of absence, illness or other temporary disability of the chief, and shall perform such other duties as may be designated by the chief. 
(Ord. 10-12-93.) 
143.07 - CAPTAIN. 
    There shall be not to exceed 21 captains in the fire department, who shall perform such duties as may be designated by the chief of the fire department. 
(Ord. 8-25-86) 
143.08 - LIEUTENANT. 
    There shall be not to exceed 16 lieutenants in the fire department, who shall perform such duties as may be designated by the chief of the fire department. 
(Ord. 8-25-86) 
143.09 - FIREMEN. 
    There shall be within the fire department such number of firemen as may be required for the normal operation of the department, who shall perform such duties as may be designated by the chief of the fire department. 
(1964 Code Sec. 11-9) 
143.10 - ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT/DRILL MASTER. 
    The administrative assistant and/or drill master shall be appointed by the chief of the fire department and the rank normally shall not exceed that of captain. 
(Ord. 8-25-86) 
143.11 - CERTAIN INCUMBENTS CONTINUED IN OFFICE. 
    Any member of the fire department holding civil service status for any position in the fire department on the effective date of this section, which position is not mentioned in this chapter, shall continue to hold such status until such incumbent vacates such position. 
(1964 Code Sec. 11-10) 
143.12 - PROHIBITED ACTS. 
    False fire alarms. No person shall wilfully do anything creating or tending to create a false alarm of fire. 
    Entering fire lines. No person, except with full and proper authority shall enter within any fire lines which shall be stretched around and about any affected area. 
    Unauthorized riding on fire apparatus. No person, other than with proper authority, shall ride upon any fire apparatus. 
    Tampering with fire apparatus. No person shall in any way tamper with or injure any fire apparatus. 
    Unauthorized opening, etc., of fire hydrants. No unauthorized person shall open, tamper with or injure any fire hydrant. 
(1964 Code Secs. 11-11 to 11-15) 
143.13 - FIREMEN'S READJUSTMENT BENEFIT FUND. 
(a)  Establishment; how held and disbursed. There is established a benefit fund to be known as the firemen's readjustment benefit fund, which shall be held by the director of the division of finance as all accrued or accruing salary of members of the fire department is held and shall be disbursed as and when all other salary disbursements are made. 
(b)  Composition. The firemen's readjustment benefit fund shall be composed of the following: the amounts of pay, based only on the prevailing firemen's basic rate, without any additional amount because of rank, which shall be earned by reason of one day's work or service in the department rendered as requested or directed by the chief of the fire department by each participating member after the death of a participating member of the department; and, in the event the participating member for whose benefit the benefit fund is created, dies from injuries suffered while actually engaged in the performance of his duties in the fire department, such amount of salary for one month after such death as the member would have received had he lived and performed his duty, which amount shall be payable by the city as a part of the benefit fund. 
(c)  Members to agree to contribute; form of assignment. Each participating member of the firemen's readjustment benefit fund shall agree to work or serve, at the prevailing basic rate of pay for firemen, one day in the fire department, for and in the place of, and after the death of, each participating member, as and when directed by the chief of the fire department, and to assign and order paid into such fund the amount so earned by the day's work, for disbursement to the beneficiary of the deceased member for whose benefit such work or service is performed. Each participating member shall execute and deliver to the director of the division of finance within 30 days after having become a member of the fire department such form of assignment and consent as may be desired by the city or its disbursing officer for such purpose. 
(d)  Participating members and beneficiaries generally. The firemen's readjustment benefit fund shall be only for those who are beneficiaries of the active members of the fire department who have agreed to this benefit fund plan and have executed the agreement and assignment specified in subsection (c) hereof and who have performed prior to such member's death all his duties hereunder in regard to the one day's work or service for the benefit of the beneficiary of every participating member who has predeceased such member. No member who is drawing a retirement or permanent disability pension shall be a participating member of the benefit fund plan. The beneficiary of the benefit fund shall be only one who is in the following relationship to the deceased participating member: widow, son, daughter, mother, father, sister or brother. 
(e)  Payments; waiver of pension. The firemen's readjustment benefit fund shall be payable to the widow exclusively, if she is the survivor, otherwise to such other eligible beneficiary as may be approved by the International Association of Fire Fighters Local No. 289. Such payment shall be made personally to the beneficiary and shall not be assignable by any beneficiary or liable for any claim against the estate of the deceased participating member or his beneficiary. The beneficiary shall, by acceptance of any payment of the benefit fund, waive any claim for pension from the firemen's pension or relief fund during or for the period such beneficiary, if so entitled hereunder, receives the one month's salary provided for in subsection (b) hereof. 
(1964 Code Secs. 11-16 to 11-20) 
143.14 - FIREMEN'S PENSION OR RELIEF FUND. 
    The administration of the firemen's pension or relief fund and payments made from such fund shall be as provided by council by ordinance. 
(1964 Code Sec. 11-21) 
143.15 - SECURITY KEY VAULT SYSTEM REQUIRED FOR CERTAIN BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES. 
(a)  A key vault system, or such other high security system, which, in the opinion of the fire marshal, is designed to give emergency services agencies immediate access to locked buildings, structures, elevators and other secured areas, shall be installed in a conspicuous and accessible location in all multi-family dwellings containing four or more units, commercial buildings and structures, governmental buildings and structures, and all buildings and structures or portions of buildings and structures used for gathering together 50 or more persons for purposes of deliberation, worship, entertainment, eating, drinking, amusement, awaiting transportation, or any other building or structure classified as an assembly occupancy under state and federal Fire Codes, built and constructed within the corporate boundaries of the city. The owner of each dwelling, building and structure described herein shall provide, install and replace the high security system required by this section. 
(b)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $100, nor more than $500. The fire marshal, or his designee, shall have plenary power and authority to enforce this section in the municipal court or such other court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 10-24-94) 
ARTICLE 147 - HUMAN RELATIONS COMMISSION[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference- Human Rights Art., W. Va. Code, Art. 5-11; authority to prohibit housing discrimination, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-9. 

147.01 - DECLARATION OF POLICY. 
    Equal opportunity in the areas of employment, public accommodations, and the sale, lease, rental and financing of housing accommodations is hereby declared to be a human right or civil right of all persons without regard to race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability or familial status. The denial of these rights of properly qualified persons by reason of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, veteran status, or familial status is contrary to the principles of freedom and equality of opportunity and is destructive to a free and democratic society. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.02 - DEFINITIONS. 
    When used in this article: 
(a)  "Person" means one or more individuals, partnerships, associations, organizations, corporations, labor organizations, cooperatives, legal representatives, trustees, trustees in bankruptcy, receivers and other organized groups of persons. 
(b)  "Commission" means the Huntington Human Relations Commission. 
(c)  "Employer" means any person employing 12 or more persons within the city and includes an agent of such person, the State of West Virginia and its agencies. Provided, that such terms shall not be taken, understood or construed to include a private club, which, in fact, is not open to the public. 
(d)  "Employee" shall not include any individual employed by his parents, spouse or child, or in the domestic service of any person. 
(e)  "Labor organization" includes any organization, which exists for the purpose, in whole or in part, for collective bargaining or for dealing with employers concerning grievances, terms or conditions of employment, or for other mutual aid or protection in relation to employment. 
(f)  "Employment agency" includes any person regularly undertaking with or without compensation to procure, recruit, refer or place employees. A newspaper engaged in the activity of advertising in the normal course of its business shall not be deemed to be an employment agency. 
(g)  "Discriminate" or "discrimination" means to exclude from, or fail or refuse to extend to, a person equal opportunities because of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, veteran status, or familial status and includes "to separate" or "segregate". 
(h)  "Unlawful discriminatory practices" includes only those practices specified in section 147.08. 
(i)  "Place of public accommodations" means any establishment or person, as defined herein, excluding the city and any of its affiliated boards and commissions, or any political or civil subdivision thereof, which offers its services, goods, facilities or accommodations to the general public, but does not include any accommodations which are in their nature private. 
(j)  "Housing accommodations" means any building or portion thereof which is used or intended for use as the residence or sleeping place of one or more persons. Nothing contained in this definition or this article shall apply to the rental of a room or rooms in a rooming house occupied by the owner as a place of residence and containing no more than four rented rooms, or rooms to be rented. 
(k)  "Real property" includes real estate, lands, leaseholds, commercial or industrial buildings and any vacant land offered for sale or rent on which the construction of a housing accommodation, commercial or industrial building is intended, and any land operated as a trailer camp or rented or leased for the use, parking or storage of mobile homes or house trailers. 
(l)  "Real estate broker" includes any person, firm or corporation who, for a fee, commission or other valuable consideration, or by reason of a promise or reasonable expectation thereof, lists for sale, sells, exchanges, buys or rents, or offers or attempts to negotiate a sale, exchange, purchase or rental of real estate or an interest therein, or collects or offers or attempts to collect rent for the use of real estate or solicits for a prospective purchaser, or assists or desists in the procuring of prospects or the negotiation or closing of any transaction which does or is contemplated to result in the sale, exchange, leasing, renting or auctioning of any real estate, or negotiates, offers or attempts or agrees to negotiate a loan secured or to be secured by mortgage or other encumbrance upon transfer of any real estate for others, or any person who, for pecuniary gain or expectation of pecuniary gain, conducts a public or private competitive sale of lands or any interest in lands. In the sale of lots, the term "real estate broker" also includes any person, partnership, association or corporation employed by or on behalf of the owner or owners of lots or other parcels of real estate at a stated salary, or upon a commission, or upon a salary and commission, or otherwise, to sell such real estate, or any parts thereof, in lots or other parcels, and who shall sell or exchange, or offer or attempt or agree to negotiate the sale or exchange of any such lot or parcel of real estate. A newspaper engaged in the activity of advertising in the normal course of its business shall not be deemed to be a real estate broker. 
(m)  "Real estate salesman" includes any person who, for compensation, valuable consideration or commission, or other thing of value, or by reason of a promise or reasonable expectation thereof, is employed by and operates under the supervision of a real estate broker to sell, buy or offer to buy or negotiate the purchase, sale or exchange of real estate, offers or attempts to negotiate a loan secured or to be secured by a mortgage or other encumbrance upon or transfer of real estate for others, or to collect rents for the use of real estate, or to solicit for prospective purchasers or lessees of real estate, or who is employed by a licensed real estate broker to sell or offer to sell lots or other parcels of real estate, at a stated salary, or upon a commission, or upon a salary and commission, or otherwise, to sell real estate, or any parts thereof, in lots or other parcels. 
(n)  "Purchaser" includes any occupant, prospective occupant, lessee, prospective lessee, renter, prospective renter, buyer or prospective buyer. 
(o)  "Owner" shall include the owner, lessee, sublessee, assignee, manager, agents or other person having the right to sell, rent or lease any housing accommodation or real property within the city or any agent of any of these. 
(p)  "Age" means 40 or above. 
(q)  "Sexual orientation" means actual or perceived heterosexuality, homosexuality, bisexuality, or gender-related identity, appearance, or behavior of an individual, with or without regard to the individual's assigned sex at birth. 
(r)  "Rooming house" means a house or building where there are one or more bedrooms which the proprietor can spare for the purpose of giving lodgings to such persons as he chooses to receive. 
(s)  For the purpose of this article, a person shall be considered to be blind only if his central visual acuity does not exceed 20/200 in the better eye with correcting lenses, or if his visual acuity is greater than 20/200 but is occasioned by a limitation in the field of vision such that the widest diameter of the visual field subtends an angle no greater than 20 degrees. 
(t)  "Disability" means a person who: 
(1)  Has a mental or physical impairment which substantially limits one or more of such person's major life activities; "major life activities" includes functions such as caring for one's self, performing manual tasks, walking, seeing, hearing, speaking, breathing, learning and working; 
(2)  Has a record of such impairment; or 
(3)  Is regarded as having such an impairment. 
For the purposes of this article "disability" does not include persons whose current use of or addiction to alcohol or drugs prevents such individual from performing the duties of the job in question or whose employment, by reasons of such current alcohol or drug abuse, would constitute a direct threat to property or the safely of others. 
(u)  "Veteran status" means a person who has served in the active military, naval or air service, and was discharged or released under conditions other than dishonorable. 
(v)  "Familial status" means one or more individuals (who have not attained the age of 18 years) being domiciled with: 
(1)  A parent or another person having legal custody of such individual or individuals; or 
(2)  The designee of such parent or other person having such custody, with the written permission of such parent or other person. The protections afforded against discrimination on the basis of familial status shall apply to any person who is pregnant or is in the process of securing legal custody of any individual who has not attained the age of 18 years. Nothing in this definition restricts advertisements of dwellings which are intended and operated for occupancy by older persons and which constitute housing for older persons. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.03 - CONTINUANCE; STATUS, POWERS AND OBJECTS. 
    The commission shall encourage and endeavor to bring about mutual understanding and respect among all racial, religious and ethnic groups within the city; and shall strive to eliminate all discrimination in employment and places of public accommodations by virtue of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability or veteran status, and shall strive to eliminate all discrimination in the sale, purchase, lease, rental or financing of housing and other real property by virtue of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, or familial status. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.04 - COMPOSITION, APPOINTMENT AND TERMS OF MEMBERS; EXPENSES. 
    The commission shall be composed of 11 members, all residents of the city and broadly representative of the groups protected by this article to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of council, provided that in the event that any vacancy on the commission is not filled by the mayor within 90 days of the occurrence thereof, the council shall, within 60 days, take such action as is necessary to fill such vacancy. No member shall hold office in any political party. 
    The appointment of the present commission members under the term of the former ordinance shall continue until the expiration of their terms or until they resign. All subsequent appointments shall be for terms of three years each, except members shall be eligible for reappointment. 
    No member of the commission shall receive any salary or compensation for his services as such; but each member shall be reimbursed for any reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of commission services, not to exceed allowances as outlined in city policies or the amount allocated for commission expenses in the city budget. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.05 - ORGANIZATION; PERSONNEL. 
    As soon as practical after establishment of the commission, the mayor shall call a meeting of the commission to be convened at the city building. The commission shall at such a meeting organize by electing one of its members as chair of the commission and one as vice-chair thereof for a term of one year or until their successors are elected and qualified. At such meeting the commission shall also elect from its membership such other officers as may be found necessary and proper for its effective organization. Annually thereafter, as soon as practical after the anniversary date of the establishment of the commission, the commission shall elect a chair and a vice-chair from its membership and other officers as may be necessary and proper to its organization. The commission shall meet not less often than quarterly. 
    The commission may appoint such staff and personnel as may be necessary to fulfill the purposes of the commission, and provide for payment of such staff and personnel within the allowances allocated in the city budget. The commission shall comply with all personnel rules, regulations and ordinances imposed by the city. 
    Special meetings may be called by the chair upon written notice thereof mailed to each member not less than seven calendar days prior to the called meeting. Any four members of the commission or a majority of the actively serving commissioners shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Minutes of the commission's meetings shall be kept. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.06 - ASSISTANCE TO COMMISSION; LEGAL SERVICES. 
    The commission, through the mayor, may call upon other officers, departments and agencies of the city government to assist in its hearings, programs and projects. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.07 - POWERS; FUNCTIONS; SERVICES. 
    The commission is hereby authorized and empowered: 
(a)  To cooperate and work with federal, state and local government officers, units, activities and agencies in the promotion and attainment of more harmonious understanding and greater equality of rights between and among all racial, religious and ethnic groups in the city. 
(b)  To enlist the cooperation of racial, religious and ethnic units, community and civic organizations, industrial and labor organizations and other identifiable groups of the city in programs and campaigns devoted to the advancement of tolerance, understanding and the equal protection of the laws of all groups and peoples. 
(c)  To receive, investigate and pass upon complaints alleging discrimination in employment or places of public accommodations, because of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability or veteran status, and complaints alleging discrimination in the sale, purchase, lease, rental and financing of housing accommodations or real property because of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, veteran status, or familial status and to initiate its own consideration of any situations, circumstances or problems, including therein any racial, religious or ethnic group tensions, prejudice, disorder or discrimination reported or existing within the city relating to employment, places of public accommodations, housing accommodations and real property. 
(d)  To hold and conduct public or private hearings on complaints, matters and questions before the commission and, in connection therewith, relating to discrimination in employment, or places of public accommodations, housing accommodations or real property and during the investigation of any formal complaint before the commission relating to employment, places of public accommodations, housing accommodations or real property to: 
(1)  Issue cease and desist orders against any person found, after a public or private hearing, to have violated the provisions of this article or the rules and regulations of the commission; 
(2)  Apply to the Circuit Court of Cabell County to issue subpoenas and subpoenas duces tecum upon the concurrence of at least five members of the commission; administer oaths and take the testimony of any person under oath; and make reimbursement for travel and other reasonable and necessary expenses in connection with such attendance; 
(3)  Furnish copies of hearing records to parties involved therein upon their payment of the reasonable costs thereof to the commission; 
(4)  To enter into conciliation agreements on behalf of the city; 
(5)  To apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for enforcement of any conciliation agreement or consent order by seeking specific performance of such agreement or consent order, on behalf of the city; 
(6)  To apply to any court of competent jurisdiction, or any federal, state or local agency, for injunctive or other relief, on behalf of the city, in any matters falling within the scope of the commission's functions, upon the concurrence of four members of the commission. 
(e)  To recommend to the mayor and council policies, procedures, practices and legislation in matters and questions affecting human relations. 
(f)  To prepare a written report on its work, functions and services for each year ending on June 30 and to deliver copies thereof to the mayor on or before December 1 next thereafter. 
(g)  To do all other acts and deeds necessary and proper to carry out and accomplish effectively the objects, functions and services contemplated by the provisions of this article, including the promulgation of rules and regulations implementing the powers and authority hereby vested in the commission. 
(h)  To create such advisory agencies and conciliation councils within the city as in its judgment will aid in effectuating the purposes of this article; to study the problem of discrimination in all or specific fields or instances of discrimination because of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, veteran status, or familial status; to foster, through community effort or otherwise, goodwill, cooperation and conciliation among the groups and elements of the population of the city and to make the recommendations to the commission for the development of policies and procedures, and for programs of formal and informal education, which the commission may recommend to the appropriate city agency. Such advisory agency and conciliation councils shall be composed of representative residents serving without pay. The commission may itself make the studies and perform the acts authorized by this subsection. It may, by voluntary conferences with parties in interest, endeavor by conciliation and persuasion to eliminate discrimination in all stated fields and to foster goodwill and cooperation among all elements of the population of the city. 
(i)  To "accept contributions from any person" to assist in the effectuation of the purposes of this section and to seek and enlist the cooperation of private, charitable, religious, labor and civic and benevolent organizations for the purposes of this section. 
(j)  To issue such publications and such results of investigation and research as in its judgment will tend to promote goodwill and minimize or eliminate discrimination; however, the identity of the parties involved shall not be disclosed. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.08 - UNLAWFUL DISCRIMINATORY PRACTICES. 
    It shall be an unlawful discriminatory practice, unless based upon a bona-fide occupational qualification: 
(a)  For any employer to discriminate against an individual with respect to compensation, hire, tenure, terms, conditions or privileges of employment on the basis of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, or veteran status. Provided, that it shall not be unlawful discriminatory practice for an employer to observe the provisions of any bona-fide pension, retirement, group or employee insurance, or welfare benefit plan or system not adopted as a subterfuge to evade the provisions of this subsection (a). 
(b)  For any employer, employment agency or labor organization, prior to the employment or admission to membership, to: 
(1)  Elicit any information or make or keep a record of or use any form of application or application blank containing questions or entries concerning the race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, or veteran status of any applicant for employment or membership, except for such forms which shall be kept separate from the application blanks for the administration of any bona-fide affirmative action plan that is in accordance with state and federal laws and regulations; 
(2)  Print or publish or cause to be printed or published any notice or advertisement relating to employment or membership indicating any preference, limitation, specification or discrimination based upon race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, or veteran status; or 
(3)  Deny or limit, through a quota system, employment or membership because of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, or veteran status. 
(c)  For any labor organization because of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, or veteran status of any individual to deny full and equal membership rights to any individual or otherwise to discriminate against such individuals with respect to hire, tenure, terms, conditions or privileges of employment or any other matter, directly or indirectly, related to employment. 
(d)  For an employer, labor organization, employment agency or any joint labor-management committee controlling apprentice training programs to: 
(1)  Select individuals for an apprentice training program on any basis other than their qualifications as determined by objective criteria which permit review; 
(2)  Discriminate against any individual with respect to his right to be admitted to or participate in a guidance program, an apprenticeship training program, on-the-job training program, or other occupational training or retraining program; 
(3)  Discriminate against any individual in his pursuit of such programs or to discriminate against such a person in the terms, conditions or privileges of such programs; 
(4)  Print or circulate or cause to be printed or circulated any statement, advertisement or publication; or to use any form of application for such programs; or to make any inquiry in connection with such program which expresses, directly or indirectly, discrimination or any intent to discriminate, unless based upon a bona-fide occupational qualification. 
(e)  For any employment agency to fail or refuse to classify properly, refer for employment, or otherwise to discriminate against any individual because of his race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, or veteran status. 
(f)  For any person, being the owner, lessee, proprietor, manager, superintendent, agent or employee of any place of public accommodations, to: 
(1)  Refuse, withhold from or deny to any individual because of his race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, or veteran status either directly or indirectly, any of the accommodations, advantages, facilities, privileges or services of such place of public accommodations; 
(2)  Publish, circulate, issue, display, post or mail, either directly or indirectly, any written or printed communication, notice or advertisement to the effect that any of the accommodations, advantages, facilities, privileges or services of such place shall be refused, withheld from or denied to any individual on account of race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, age, blindness, disability, or veteran status or that the patronage or custom thereat of any individual, belonging to or purporting to be of any particular race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, sex, sexual orientation, veteran status, or age or who is blind or disabled is unwelcome, objectionable, not acceptable, undesired or not solicited. 
(g)  For any person, employer, employment agency, labor organization, owner, real estate broker, real estate salesman or financial institution to: 
(1)  Engage in any form of threats or reprisal, or to engage in, or hire, or conspire with others to commit acts or activities of any nature, the purpose of which is to harass, degrade, embarrass or cause physical harm or economic loss, or to aid, abet, incite, compel or coerce any person to engage in any of the unlawful discriminatory practices defined in this section. 
(2)  Willfully obstruct or prevent any person from complying with the provisions of this article, or to resist, prevent, impede or interfere with the commission or any of its members or representatives in the performance of duty under this article. 
(3)  Engage in any form of reprisal or otherwise discriminate against any person who has opposed any practices or acts forbidden under this article or because he has filed a complaint, testified or assisted in any proceeding under this article. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.09 - DISCRIMINATORY PRACTICES; INVESTIGATIONS, HEARINGS, PROCEDURES AND ORDERS. 
    Any individual claiming to be aggrieved by an alleged unlawful discriminatory practice shall make, sign and file with the commission a verified complaint, which shall state the name and address of the person, employer, labor organization, employment agency, owner, real estate broker, real estate salesman or financial institution alleged to have committed the unlawful discriminatory practice complained of, and which shall set forth the particulars thereof and contain such other information as may be required by the commissioner's rules and regulations. The commission upon its own initiative shall, in like manner, make, sign and file such complaint. Any employer, whose employees, or some of them, hinder or threaten to hinder compliance with the provisions of this article, shall file with the commission a verified complaint, asking for assistance by conciliation or other remedial action, no hearings, orders or other actions shall be held, made or taken by the commission against such employer. Any complaint filed pursuant to this article must be filed within 180 days after the alleged act of discrimination. 
    After the filing of any complaint, or whenever there is reason to believe that an unlawful discriminatory practice has been committed, the commission shall make a prompt investigation in connection therewith. In connection with such investigation the director or his/her designated representative or the commission's legal staff shall have authority to request the commission, or the chair acting in the name of the commission, to apply to the Circuit Court of Cabell County, West Virginia to issue subpoenas and subpoenas duces tecum upon the concurrence of at least five members of the commission. 
    If it is determined after such investigation that no probable cause exists for substantiating the allegations of the complaint, the commission shall, within ten days from such determination, cause to be issued and served upon the complainant written notice of such determination; and the complainant or his attorney may, within ten days after such service, file with the commission a written request for a meeting with the commission to show probable cause for substantiating the allegations of the complaint. If it is determined after such investigation or meeting that probable cause exists for substantiating the allegations of the complaint, the commission shall immediately endeavor to eliminate the unlawful discriminatory practices complained of by conference, conciliation and persuasion. The members of the commission and its staff shall not disclose what has transpired in the course of such endeavors. Provided, that the commission may publish or release the terms of settlement or conciliation when the complaint has been conciliated or settled. 
    In case of failure so to eliminate such practice or in advance thereof, if in the judgment of the commission circumstances so warrant, the commission shall cause to be issued and served a written notice, together with a copy of such complaint as the same may have been amended, in the manner provided by law for the service of summons in civil actions, requiring the person, employer, labor organization, employment agency, owner, real estate broker, real estate salesman or financial institution named in such complaint, hereinafter referred to as respondent, to answer the charges of such complaint at a public or private hearing before the commission in the county where the respondent resides or transacts business at a time and place so specified in such notice; provided, however, that such written notice shall be served at least 30 days prior to the time set for the hearing. The commission or its chair shall delegate the power and authority to conduct the hearing to a hearing examiner(s) who may be an individual commissioner; a panel of commissioners; a hearing examiner, who shall be an attorney duly licensed to practice law in West Virginia; a panel of hearing examiners; or a panel composed of any combination of commissioners and hearing examiners. 
    The case in support of the complaint shall be presented before the commission by one of its attorneys or agents, but no one presenting the case in support of the complaint shall counsel or advise the commission, commissioner or hearing examiner who hears the case. The respondent may file a written, verified answer to the complaint and appear at such hearing in person or otherwise, with or without counsel, and submit testimony and evidence. Except as provided in this article, all of the pertinent provisions of W. Va. Code, Art. 29A-5 shall apply to and govern the hearing and the administrative procedures in connection with and following such hearing, with like effect as if the provisions of such W. Va. Code, Art. 29A-5 were set forth in extenso in this section. 
    If, after such hearing and consideration of all of the testimony, evidence and record in the case, the commission finds that a respondent has engaged in or is engaging in any unlawful discriminatory practice as defined in this article, the commission shall issue and cause to be served on such respondent an order to cease and desist from such unlawful discriminatory practice and to take such affirmative action, including but not limited to, hiring, reinstatement or upgrading of employees, with or without back pay, admission or restoration to membership in any respondent labor organization, or the admission to full and equal enjoyment of the services, goods, facilities, or accommodations offered by any respondent place of public accommodation, and the sale, purchase, lease, rental or financial assistance to any complainant otherwise qualified for the housing accommodation or real property denied in violation of this article, as in the judgment of the commission, will effectuate the purposes of this article, and including a requirement for report of the manner of compliance, payment of expenses and lost wages of any witness called by the complainant or commission, payment to the complainant of reasonable attorney fees, expert witness fees, and legal costs, and payment to the commission of its costs in conducting the hearing; and any other legal or equitable relief as the commission deems appropriate. Such order shall be accompanied by findings of fact and conclusions of law as specified in W. Va. Code, § 29A-5-3. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.10 - ENFORCEMENT OF CEASE AND DESIST ORDERS. 
    In the event any person fails to obey a lawful cease and desist order of the commission, the commission may seek an order of a court of competent jurisdiction for its enforcement in a proceeding as provided in this section. Such proceeding shall be initiated by the filing of a petition in such court, together with a written transcript of the entire record of the hearing before the commission. Notice of the filing of such petition, together with a copy thereof, shall be served upon the respondent in the manner provided by law for the service of summons in civil actions. No hearing shall be held on such petition within 20 days of the date of service thereof on the respondent. The court may grant such temporary relief or restraining order as it deems just and proper and shall make and enter upon the pleadings, testimony and proceedings set forth in such transcript an order enforcing, modifying and enforcing as so modified, or setting aside in whole or in part the order of the commission. All such proceedings shall be heard and determined by the court. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.11 - JUDICIAL REVIEW. 
    Judicial review of a final decision of the commission shall be by a certiorari as set forth in W. Va. Code, §§ 53-3-1-53-3-6, or in such other manner as may be allowed under the laws of the state. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.12 - ADOPTION OF WEST VIRGINIA FAIR HOUSING ACT. 
    The city adopts, by reference, the provisions of West Virginia Senate Bill 162, passed March 5, 1992, a copy of which is available for review in the city clerk's office, with the following modifications: 
Article II, Human Rights Commission. Section 5-11-3 Definitions, subsection (b) is amended by substituting the term "Huntington" for the term "West Virginia"; in subsection (c) thereof by inserting the phrase "Huntington Human Relations Commission" before the term "Commission"; in subsection (d) thereof by substituting the term "City" for the term "State"; in subsection (j) thereof by substituting the term "City" for the term "State"; and further modifying said Senate Bill No. 162, in Article IIA of the West Virginia Fair Housing Act, Section 5-11A-1 by substituting the term "City of Huntington" for the term "West Virginia"; in Section 5-11A-2, Declaration of policy, by substituting the term "City of Huntington" for the term "State of West Virginia"; and in Section 5-11A-3(a) thereof by substituting the term "Huntington" for the term "West Virginia" in line 2. 
And further modifying said Senate Bill No. 162 by substituting the term "City of Huntington" for the term "State" wherever any such reference therein is made to the term "State". 
And by substituting the term "Commission's Attorney" for the term "Attorney General" wherever said term appears in said Act. 
And by substituting the term "Hearing Examiner" for "Administrative Law Judge" wherever said term appears in said Act. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of this article or code to the contrary, the city hereby adopts the provisions of the West Virginia Human Rights Act, W. Va. Code, Ch. 5, Art. 11 and the West Virginia Fair Housing Act, W. Va. Code, Ch. 5, Art. 11-A, in total. Such provisions shall supersede any contrary language or definitions contained in this article. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
147.99 - PENALTY. 
    Any person who willfully resists, prevents, impedes or interferes with the commission, its members, agents or agencies in the performance of duties pursuant to this article or willfully violates a final order of the commission, shall be fined not less than $100 nor more than $500, or imprisoned not exceeding 30 days, or both; but seeking judicial review of an order shall not be deemed to be such willful conduct. 
(Ord. of 12-23-13(1)) 
ARTICLE 149 - TRI-STATE TRANSIT AUTHORITY[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
State Law reference- Urban mass transportation systems, W. Va. Code, Art. 8-27. 

149.01 - CREATED IN CONJUNCTION WITH CABELL COUNTY. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of W. Va. Code, Art. 8-27, the city, in conjunction with the County Court of Cabell County, as joint participating government, does hereby create and establish an urban mass transportation authority to be known as "The Tri-State Transit Authority." 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-27) 
149.02 - POWERS, DUTIES, RESPONSIBILITIES AND RIGHTS. 
    The Tri-State Transit Authority shall be a public corporation, expressly invested with all of the powers and charged with all of the duties and responsibilities, and subject to all of the rights of the participating governments, as authorized and provided by W. Va. Code, Art. 8-27. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-28) 
149.03 - BOARD; MEMBERS. 
(a)  Pursuant to the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 8-27-5, the management and control of the Tri-State Transit Authority, its operations, business and affairs shall be lodged in a board consisting of five members, to be known as members of the board of the Tri-State Transit Authority, and who shall be appointed for three-year terms by governing bodies of the participating governments; provided, however, the initial terms of the members shall be as follows: 
(1)  Two members for terms of one year each, expiring April 3, 1973; 
(2)  One member for a term of two years, expiring April 3, 1974; 
(3)  Two members for terms of three years, expiring April 3, 1975. 
(b)  The members shall be appointed as follows: 
(1)  By the County Court of Cabell County: 
A.  One member for an initial one-year term, and for the three-year term thereafter upon the expiration of such initial one-year term. 
B.  One member for an initial three-year term, and for the three-year term thereafter upon the expiration of such initial three-year term. 
(2)  By the mayor subject to approval by council: 
A.  One member for an initial one-year term, and for the three-year term thereafter upon the expiration of such initial one-year term. 
B.  One member for an initial three-year term, and for the three-year term thereafter upon the expiration of such initial three-year term. 
(3)  Jointly by the County Court of Cabell County and the mayor subject to approval by council: One member for an initial two-year term, and for the three-year term thereafter upon the expiration of such initial two-year term. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-29) 
149.04 - VOTING POWER UPON BOARD DETERMINED. 
    The city and the County Court of Cabell County, and any such other local governments admitted to participation under the provisions of the statutes hereinbefore set forth and described, shall each have such voting power upon such board as provided by W. Va. Code, § 8-27-5. The number of votes to which each participating government shall be entitled for the balance of the fiscal year 1971-72 is hereby determined to be one vote for each $500 contributed by such participating government at the time of the organization of the Tri-State Transit Authority, to be voted in the same manner and in the same percentages as set out in section 149.05. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-30) 
149.05 - PERCENTAGE OF VOTING POWER ALLOTTED TO MEMBERS. 
    The city and the County Court of Cabell County, each being represented by more than one member on such board, and under the provisions of the statutes aforesaid, each participating government being entitled to one vote for each $500 contributed to the Tri-State Transit Authority, as such contributions are determined at the end of the preceding fiscal year, the two members appointed by the city shall each have 40% of the voting power of the city; the two members appointed by the County Court of Cabell County shall each have 40% of the voting power of the county; and the one member appointed jointly by the city and the County Court of Cabell County shall have 20% of the voting power of the city and 20% of the voting power of Cabell County. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-31) 
149.06 - FISCAL YEAR. 
    The fiscal year of such authority shall be from July 1 to June 30. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-32) 
149.07 - REFERENCES TO STATUTES. 
    All references to the statutes of the state, as herein set forth and described, shall include such statutes as presently existing, and as they may from time to time hereafter be amended. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-33) 
ARTICLE 151 - FEDERAL-STATE ADVISORY COMMISSION[18]

151.01 - CREATION. 
    There is hereby created a federal-state advisory commission, which shall consist of not more than ten members to be appointed by the mayor subject to approval by council, and who shall serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-39) 
151.02 - DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES. 
    The federal-state advisory commission shall research and explore all federal and state programs in the area of federal and state relations, and shall advise council in all areas relating to the availability and the securing of funds for the development of municipal projects and other municipal needs and requirements from such sources, which shall include, but not be limited to, federal agencies, state agencies, foundations and other public or private sources. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-40) 
151.03 - MAYOR OR DESIGNATED REPRESENTATIVE TO BE EX-OFFICIO MEMBER OF COMMISSION. 
    In addition to the members hereinbefore provided for, the mayor, or his designated representative, shall be a member ex-officio of the federal-state advisory commission, with all of the powers and privileges, including the right to vote, of the other members of such commission. 
(1964 Code Sec. 2-41)

153.03 - CIVIC ARENA DIRECTOR TO BE EX-OFFICIO MEMBER OF COMMISSION.

ARTICLE 161 - CIVIC ARENA DEPARTMENT[23] 

Footnotes: 
--- (23) --- 
Cross reference- Director ex-officio member of Arts and Cultural Advisory Commission, § 153.03. 

161.01 - CREATION. 
    There is hereby created a department to be designated and known as the Huntington Civic Arena Department, which shall be constituted as a department unit of the city. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8.1-1; Ord. 2-27-95) 
161.02 - PURPOSE. 
    The civic arena department is hereby created for the purpose of operating the civic arena and such other projects or public facilities as council may, from time to time, designate by ordinance. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8.1-2; Ord. 2-27-95) 
161.03 - DIRECTOR. 
    There shall be a civic arena director who shall be the head of the civic arena department, and who shall be appointed by the mayor. The director shall be in charge of all facilities operated by the civic arena department, and shall perform all duties and exercise all powers which shall be conferred upon him by ordinance or resolution of council, and except as may be otherwise provided, shall: 
(a)  Schedule and book events in conjunction with the operation and maintenance of the civic arena; 
(b)  When authorized by the mayor, appoint and remove subordinates in such Department; 
(c)  Assume all responsibility for the efficiency, discipline and good conduct of the department; 
(d)  Enter into rental contracts, subject to the rental and box office schedule as council may authorize by ordinance or resolution; 
(e)  Negotiate and enter into, subject to the approval of council, straight percentage rental contracts which may not require rental or box office guarantees when, in his opinion, it would be in the best interest of the city so to do; 
(f)  Reject the utilization, rental or use of the civic arena by any individual, group, organization or event that, in his professional judgment, is not in the best interest of the city; 
(g)  Promulgate rules and regulations for the maintenance, use and operation of the facility. Such rules and regulations shall be subject to the approval of council and may include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  No individual organization or group of any kind whatever shall be granted free usage of any facility operated by the civic arena. 
(2)  No literature of any kind shall be distributed or placed in such facility or on the grounds thereof without the written consent of the director. 
(3)  No contributions or donations shall be made or solicited or announcements regarding same in such facilities or the grounds thereof without the prior written permission of the director. 
    The mayor, with the approval of council by ordinance, may employ and designate a private firm, corporation or other entity specializing in entertainment management and promotions, and with such other qualifications as the mayor may require, to serve as the director of the civic arena. 
(Ord. 2-27-95) 
161.04 - CREATION OF CONVENTION AND VISITORS BUREAU. 
    There is hereby created a convention and visitors bureau under the control of the civic arena department to be partially funded by the city. This bureau shall fully cooperate with the Huntington Chamber of Commerce and other civic organizations, and shall actively promote tourism and perform all duties and exercise all powers necessary to attract, schedule and book conventions in the city. Such bureau shall consist of 15 members to be appointed by the mayor subject to approval by council. 
(Ord. 7-26-82; Ord. 2-27-95) 
161.05 - CIVIC ARENA ADVISORY BOARD. 
    There is hereby created a board which shall be known as the Civic Arena Advisory Board of the City of Huntington, consisting of five members, all of whom shall be appointed by the mayor subject to approval by council. In addition to the five members so appointed, the mayor of the city shall be an ex-officio member of the board. One member shall be appointed for a term of one year; one member for a term of two years; one member for a term of three years; one member for a term of four years, and one member for a term of five years. 
    The board is hereby vested with the authority to advise the civic arena director and the mayor in operating, maintaining and controlling the civic arena. 
(Ord. 7-26-82; Ord. 2-27-95) 
ARTICLE 163 - HUNTINGTON COMMUNICATIONS BOARD 

163.01 - GUIDELINES. 
(a)  To provide the citizens of the City of Huntington information through public access channel(s) and the Huntington Communications Board shall: 
(1)  Provide televised coverage of all city council meetings; 
(2)  Provide opportunity for local schools and governmental agencies to air informational news, sporting, award, social and art events via the public access channel(s) and, if available, provide equipment for the production of such programs; 
(3)  Enhance public awareness and solicit sponsorships for such programs; 
(4)  Advance social awareness and education within the City of Huntington; 
(5)  Insure that programming on the public access channel(s) reflects the conscience of the citizens of the City of Huntington; 
(6)  Provide equal opportunity to organizations seeking to air programs on the public access channel(s); 
(7)  Maintain records and/or copies of programming that has aired on the public access channel(s); 
(8)  Seek opportunities to provide information regarding the community to the public; and 
(9)  Maintain an account and list of sponsors. 
(b)  The Huntington Communications Board shall begin with an initial group of no less than five individuals chosen by the mayor with the advice and consent of council. The board shall have the right to add more members who shall be approved by council. At no time shall the board exceed 11 members. 
(1)  Members shall serve terms for a period of two years and may be reappointed. 
(2)  Members shall attend at least 60% of all meetings or forfeit their appointment. 
(3)  Members shall elect a chairperson and secretary annually. 
(4)  The secretary shall submit a record of all meetings to include attendance and voting records to the mayor and city clerk. 
(5)  The city attorney or the assistant city attorney shall be a permanent member of the board. 
(c)  The board shall have the right to cause sponsor's names to be published before, after and during breaks at council meetings when televised on public access channel(s). 
(d)  The board shall accept no less than $20 publishing fee per individual sponsor and a $50 publishing fee for business sponsorships. The board shall not guarantee when such recognition for sponsorship will be aired. The board may seek by resolution of council any adjustment to the sponsorship fee. The board may accept fees for an annual basis, based upon 24 schedule council meetings. 
(e)  The board shall not allow any advertisements to be aired on public access channel(s) and shall comply with all federal, state and local laws. 
(f)  The board shall seek out methods to improve the communication information systems within the City of Huntington and may negotiate on behalf of the City of Huntington. 
(g)  The director of administrator and finance shall establish accounts and maintain monies for the board. The mayor shall oversee the disbursement of funds by the board without the approval of council for any amount not exceeding $4,999. Any amount over $4,999, the board, with the mayor's approval, must seek authorization from council. 
(h)  The board must comply with all government regulations when seeking to enter into contracts. Further, the mayor shall act as contracting authority for the board with the advice and consent of council. 
(i)  The board shall establish a schedule where they have at least one meeting each month and shall publish a list of meeting dates in the city clerk's office. All meetings shall be conducted pursuant to the Open Meetings Law. 
(j)  The board shall conduct its meetings pursuant to Robert's Rules of Order and shall encourage the public to speak towards issues it addresses. 
(k)  The board shall adopt its own administrative rules and shall provide a copy of said rules to each member and to the city clerk for inspection by the public. 
(Ord. 8-27-01) 
ARTICLE 165 - MUNICIPAL PARKING BOARD[24] 

Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to establish off-street parking, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-12; public works projects, W. Va. Code, § 8-16; vehicle parking facilities, W. Va. Code, § 8-16-4a et seq. 

165.01 - CREATION; MEMBERSHIP; TERM; FILLING VACANCIES; REMOVAL OF MEMBERS. 
    There is hereby created a board which shall be known as the municipal parking board of the city consisting of seven members who shall be appointed by the mayor subject to approval by council. Members of the board shall be residents of the city, at least four of whom have been such residents for at least five years prior to their appointment to the board. At least four members of the board shall be freeholders of real property within the city. The persons now serving on such board by appointment under prior ordinance shall continue to serve under their original appointment; the person to be appointed to fill the term expiring on June 27, 1970 under the prior ordinance and the two new appointments to be made under this amendment shall be appointed for terms expiring June 27, 1970.
