Following the expiration of the term of each of the original appointees, his successor shall be appointed to serve for a term of three years. All appointees shall continue to serve until their successors have been appointed and qualified. All appointments to fill vacancies for the unexpired term of any member shall be for the period of such members' term. Any member of the board shall be eligible for reappointment and any member may be removed from the board for misfeasance, malfeasance or nonfeasance. 
(1964 Code Sec. 22-206) 
165.02 - OFFICERS; PERSONNEL. 
    The members of the municipal parking board shall elect one of their number as chairman and the director of the division of finance shall be ex-officio treasurer of the board. Necessary secretarial and other personnel shall be obtained by the board through the regular personnel procedures of the city upon request made to the mayor. 
(1964 Code Sec. 22-207) 
165.03 - COMPENSATION. 
    The members of the municipal parking board and the director of the division of finance acting as ex-officio treasurer shall serve without compensation; provided, however, that the members and such director shall be reimbursed for expenses incurred for the benefit of the board if such expenditures have been authorized by the board prior to being incurred and if duly verified vouchers for such expenditures are presented to the board for reimbursement. 
(1964 Code Sec. 22-208) 
165.04 - EXPENDITURES. 
    At least 45 days prior to the beginning of each fiscal year, the municipal parking board shall prepare and submit to council for approval a budget for the ensuing fiscal year. The board shall not expend any money or incur any liability or enter into any contract which by its terms involves the expenditure of money, for any purpose, in excess of the amount appropriated for the general budget classification of such expenditure in the budget approved by council without first obtaining a formal resolution of council authorizing such expenditure, liability or contract. 
(1964 Code Sec. 22-209) 
165.05 - SALE OF REVENUE BONDS. 
    All necessary preliminary expenses actually incurred by the municipal parking board in the making of surveys or estimates of cost and of revenues, employment of engineers or other employees, the giving of notices, the taking of options and all other expenses of whatsoever nature necessary to be paid prior to the issue, sale and delivery of the revenue bonds herein provided for, shall be paid by the city upon proper application therefor and by resolution or resolutions adopted by council from time to time, all to be reimbursed and repaid out of the proceeds of the sale of such revenue bonds, as provided by W. Va. Code § 8-16-6. All expenses of the board, including compensation paid to employees, reimbursement of expenses and other necessary expenditures herein provided for, shall be paid solely from funds received by the board from revenues collected or from the proceeds received from the sale of revenue bonds under the terms and provisions of W. Va. Code, Art. 8-16; and nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize or permit the city or the board to make any contract or to incur any obligation of any kind or nature, except such as shall be paid solely from the proceeds from the sale of such revenue bonds and from the revenues collected by the board, and such bonds shall not in any respect be corporate indebtedness of the city, but shall be paid solely from funds authorized for their payment by the aforesaid provisions of the West Virginia Code. 
(1964 Code Sec. 22-210) 
165.06 - POWERS AND DUTIES GENERALLY. 
(a)  The authority, power and jurisdiction of the municipal parking board shall be limited to the acquisition, construction, equipment, providing for, administration, operation, maintenance and leasing of off-street parking within the city except as provided below. The authority to lease shall include the right of the board to act as lessor, in accordance with W. Va. Code, § 8-16-4, and as lessee, in accordance with W. Va. Code, Art. 8-16. 
    Subject to limitations imposed upon it by this article and general law, the board shall have power to take all steps and proceedings and to make and enter into all contracts and agreements necessary or incidental to the performance of its duties in the execution of its powers under this article and as provided by general law; provided, however, that no contract involving an expenditure or receipt of more than $2,500 shall be entered into or executed prior to approval by council. 
    The board shall be bound by and subject to all of the covenants, agreements and provisions of this article authorizing the issuance of revenue bonds to finance off-street parking and the provisions of W. Va. Code, Art. 8-16, and such covenants, agreements and provisions shall be enforceable by the holders of such revenue bonds. 
(b)  In addition to any other powers which it has, the municipal parking board shall: 
(1)  Have the power to regulate and control on-street parking meters; 
(2)  Have control of the parking meter attendants; and 
(3)  Have the power to regulate and control all parking on public streets, alleys and right-of-ways. 
(1964 Code Sec. 22-211; Ord. 2-26-07) 
165.07 - MUNICIPAL PARKING BOARD DIRECTOR. 
(a)  The mayor shall appoint and the Huntington Municipal Parking Board shall approve a director of the municipal parking board. The director may be removed from the position by the mayor. The director shall serve under the supervision of the mayor and/or his or her designee and shall be responsible for the overall operation of the huntington municipal parking board. 
(b)  Said director shall be responsible for the financial operation of the Huntington Municipal Parking Board and shall submit an operating budget to the city council for approval consistent with all other city departmental budget submissions each calendar year. It will be the director's responsibility to operate the Huntington Municipal Parking Board within the said budget. Further, the director shall be responsible for submitting to the mayor, the director of finance, council and the Huntington Municipal Parking Board a financial report each month outlining all income and expenditures for the Huntington Municipal Parking Board. 
(Ord. 2-27-06) 
ARTICLE 167 - REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION[25] 

Footnotes: 
--- (25) --- 
Charter reference- City Planning Commission, Art. Eight. 
State Law reference- Municipal-county planning commissions, W. Va. Code, § 8-24-13; regional planning and development, W. Va. Code, Art. 8-25. 

167.01 - ESTABLISHMENT. 
    The city and the county courts of Cabell and Wayne Counties hereby agree to participate in the establishment of the Cabell-Wayne-Huntington Regional Planning Commission, to be governed by the provisions of this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 25-18) 
167.02 - MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION. 
    The Cabell-Wayne-Huntington Regional Planning Commission shall consist of 12 members, four from each participating jurisdiction. The planning commission of each county and the city planning commission shall recommend and the county court and council shall appoint from the membership of the respective planning commissions three members, and a member of the county court to be appointed by each county court and a member of council to be appointed by council. The terms of the representatives shall be coextensive with their terms of office to which they were elected or to which they were appointed. 
    The commission shall not appoint the two members from each participating jurisdiction from the general public as provided by the statute unless approved by each of the county and city planning commissions. 
    Any vacancy in membership shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointments. 
    All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(1964 Code Sec. 25-19) 
167.03 - ORGANIZATION; RULES OF PROCEDURE; STAFF; FINANCES. 
    The regional planning commission shall elect its president and vice-president from among its members. The term of the president and vice-president shall be one year. The vice-president shall have the authority to act as president of the commission during the absence or disability of the president. The regional planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting, but it shall meet at least once in the months of January, April, July and October. All meetings of the regional planning commission, during which any official action is taken, shall be open to the public and all records of the commission shall be public records. 
    The regional planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract, through its individual political jurisdictions, with the state department of commerce, city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be in accordance with the purpose for which such funds are appropriated. 
    The regional planning commission shall adopt an annual budget, to be submitted for approval or modification by each participating government. Each shall contribute to the financing of the commission on a prorata basis. 
    Each of the participating jurisdictions shall have the right to determine what portion of the recommendation of the regional planning commission they desire to accept or reject for their particular jurisdiction. 
(1964 Code Sec. 25-20) 
167.04 - POWERS AND DUTIES. 
    From and after the time when the regional planning commission has organized and selected its officers and has adopted its rules of procedure, then such commission shall have powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in W. Va. Code, Art. 8-25. 
(1964 Code Sec. 25-21) 
ARTICLE 169 - SANITARY BOARD[26] 

Footnotes: 
--- (26) --- 
State Law reference- Composition of Board, W. Va. Code, § 16-13-18; publication of financial statement, W. Va. Code, § 16-13-18a; powers and duties, W. Va. Code, § 16-13-3 et seq. 

169.01 - CREATION; MEMBERS. 
    There is hereby created a sanitary board to consist of three members. The mayor is hereby designated as a member of the board and the mayor shall be the chairman of said board. Council, as governing body as defined by W. Va. Code, § 16-13-1 et seq., shall appoint the two other members of the board. The persons so selected and the terms of their respective offices and all other matters relating thereto shall be in accordance with the provisions of state law. 
(Ord. 12-22-97) 
169.02 - SEWERAGE COLLECTION SYSTEM SUPERVISION; EXPENDITURES; REVENUE. 
    The construction, acquisition, improvement, custody, operation and maintenance of the municipal sewerage treatment or collection system or other works that may be constructed or required under the provisions of law and of this article shall be under the supervision and control of the sanitary board. All necessary preliminary expense actually incurred by the board in the making of surveys, estimates of costs and revenues, employment of engineers, attorneys or other employees, the giving of notices, taking of options, and all other expense of whatsoever nature necessary to be paid prior to the issue and delivery of the revenue bonds, may be paid out of the general fund of the city not otherwise appropriated, in the manner provided in W. Va. Code, § 16-13-4; provided, however, that the funds of the city from which such payments are made shall be fully reimbursed and repaid by the board out of the first proceeds of the sale of revenue bonds. 
(Ord. 3-12-01) 
169.03 - RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
    The further regulation and control of the sanitary board, except in so far as the board is given authority by law to organize itself and establish its own by-laws, rules and regulations, is hereby reserved and may be set forth from time to time by council by proper ordinance, within the terms of state law. 
(Ord. 3-11-35) 
169.04 - COMPENSATION; SECRETARY AND TREASURER. 
    Until the further order of council the members of the sanitary board shall receive compensation in the amounts and under the circumstances as may from time to time be determined by council. The board is hereby directed to select a secretary and treasurer pursuant to W. Va. Code § 16-13-18. The bond of the treasurer is hereby fixed at $5,000. Such bond shall be given by a recognized surety company, and the cost of the premium thereof shall be paid by the board as part of its expenses. 
(Ord. 3-12-01) 
169.05 - CERTAIN CONTRACTS SUBJECT TO APPROVAL BY COUNCIL. 
    The custody, administration, operation and maintenance of the sewage disposal system of the city are hereby placed under the supervision and control of the Huntington Sanitary Board, to be exercised in accordance with the provisions of W. Va. Code, Ch. 16, as amended, and the ordinances of the city enacted thereto. 
    The Huntington Sanitary Board shall have the power to take all necessary steps and procedures to make and enter into all contracts or agreements necessary or incidental to the performance of its duties and the execution of its powers under this article; provided, that any purchase or purchases relating to the financing, construction, acquisition, maintenance, enlargement, improvement, or renovation of any such works in excess of $25,000 shall be approved by council; provided, that nothing herein shall be construed to require the approval of the payment of ongoing expenses including, but not limited to, wages and utility bills. 
(Ord. 3-12-01) 
169.06 - CONSTRUCTION, ACQUISITION, IMPROVEMENT AND EQUIPMENT SUPERVISION. 
    The construction, acquisition, improvement and equipment of the sewage disposal system of the city, and all matters pertaining thereto, are likewise hereby placed under the supervision and control of the Huntington Sanitary Board in compliance with W. Va. Code § 16-13-2, as amended. 
(Ord. 1-13-97) 
169.07 - REMOVAL AND REPLACEMENT OF APPOINTED MEMBERS; POWERS OF COUNCIL. 
(a)  Council shall, by a majority vote after proper notice and hearing, remove any appointed member of the sanitary board, except for the mayor, upon a finding that such member has violated any of the provisions of this article, or for reasonable and just cause, as determined by a majority vote of council. 
    For the purpose of this subsection, "reasonable and just cause" shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  The continued failure to attend meetings of the board; or 
(2)  The failure to diligently pursue the purposes and objectives for which the sanitary board was created; or 
(3)  The failure to perform any directive or duty prescribed by law, order of council, order of the public service commission of the state, or the order of any court of competent jurisdiction; or 
(4)  The commission of any other malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance while sitting as a member of the board. 
(b)  Council shall, by a majority vote after proper hearing, appoint a member to replace any member removed pursuant to subsection (a) hereof immediately after such removal is final, or as soon thereafter as practicable. 
(Ord. 1-13-97) 
ARTICLE 183 - MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[27] 

Footnotes: 
--- (27) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal development authorities, W. Va. Code, Art. 7-12. 

183.01 - ESTABLISHED; AUTHORITY. 
(a)  There is hereby created, pursuant to the authority of W. Va. Code, § 7-12-1 a municipal development authority, which shall be named the "Huntington Municipal Development Authority", for the purposes stated in the preamble to Ordinance 8-11-86 as well as the purposes stated in W. Va. Code, § 7-12-2. 
(b)  The Huntington Municipal Development Authority shall have all of the rights, powers, and authority granted by the aforesaid statutes, either expressly or by implication, in carrying out its duties and responsibilities or in exercising its rights, powers and authority. 
(Ord. 8-11-86) 
183.02 - MEMBERSHIP. 
(a)  The management and control of the Huntington Municipal Economic Development Authority, its property, operations, business and affairs shall be lodged in a board consisting of 15 persons appointed by council, who shall be known as members of the authority. At least one member of the authority shall also be a member of council appointed to represent council on the board of the authority. In addition, council shall appoint three members of the authority to represent business, three members to represent industry and three members to represent labor. In addition to the ten members thus selected and appointed, the then serving mayor of the city, shall, if he so requests, and if the by-laws of the authority so provide, be entitled to be appointed to membership on the authority, and the authority may, in its by-laws, provide for the appointment of not more than four additional members to the board of the authority to represent such other persons, firms, unincorporated associations and corporations residing in, maintaining offices in, or having economic interests in the city, as the case may be; provided, however, that in no event shall the number of members of the authority exceed 15 unless hereafter authorized by duly adopted and appropriate resolution of the governing body of the municipality. 
(b)  All members of the board of the authority shall be citizens and bona fide residents of the city. 
(Ord. 8-11-86) 
183.03 - POWERS AND RIGHTS. 
(a)  As contemplated by W. Va. Code, § 7-12-8, the Huntington Municipal Development Authority shall be a body corporate, with all of the powers and rights invested in or granted to the authority, either expressly or by necessary implication, including the power to take and hold title to property of every kind, character and description, and to pledge, obligate and otherwise deal in and with such property as the authority may own or acquire, from time to time; provided, however, that the indebtedness of the authority, if any, shall not, under any circumstances, constitute an indebtedness of the governing body of the municipality or of the city, a municipal corporation; and provided, further, that the rights of creditors of the authority shall be solely against the authority as a corporate body and shall be satisfied only out of property held by the authority in its corporate capacity. 
(b)  In the event the board of the authority shall so determine, the authority may lease or sell all of its property and equipment on such terms and conditions as the authority may fix and determine. Such sale or lease shall be approved by council. Upon the dissolution of the authority, all of its assets and property shall revert to and become the property of the city. 
(Ord. 8-11-86) 
183.04 - EMPLOYEES UNDER WORKERS' COMPENSATION ACT. 
    All employees of the authority eligible thereto shall be deemed to be within the Workers' Compensation Act of West Virginia, and premiums on their compensation shall be paid by the authority as required by law. 
(Ord. 8-11-86) 
183.05 - PURPOSE. 
    It is the purpose of this article to provide for the promotion, development and advancement of the business, prosperity and economic welfare of the city, its residents and its industrial complex, and this article shall be liberally construed as giving to the authority full and complete power reasonably required to give effect to the purposes hereof. 
(Ord. 8-11-86) 
ARTICLE 187 - CABLE TELEVISION ADVISORY BOARD[28] 

Footnotes: 
--- (28) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions generally, Art. 190. 
State Law reference- Cable television systems, W. Va. Code, Art. 5-18 et seq. 

187.01 - CREATION; MEMBERS; TERMS; DUTIES. 
    There is hereby created a board which shall be known as the cable television advisory board of the city consisting of five members, two of which shall be appointed by the mayor, two of which shall be appointed by the council and one of which shall be jointly appointed by the mayor and the council. All members shall be appointed to the board for a term of three years and shall hold their respective positions on the board until their successors have been appointed and have qualified. 
    The board is hereby vested with the authority to advise the mayor and the council as to all matters involving all cable television franchises granted to cable television operators who are operating or seek to operate a cable television system within the corporate boundaries of the city. The board shall further serve as the liaison and duly authorized representative of the city in matters requiring communication and interaction with the West Virginia Cable Television Advisory Board and the Federal Communications Commission including, but not limited to, consumer complaints regarding cable television service and rates within the city. The board shall perform such other duties as requested by the mayor and the council, and shall report to the mayor and the council at least once every 30 days regarding any and all matters before it. 
(Ord. 10-24-94) 
ARTICLE 190 - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS GENERALLY[29] 

Footnotes: 
--- (29) --- 
Charter reference- Appointments, § 2.1. 

190.01 - MEMBERS APPOINTED; TERM. 
(a)  In accordance with Section 2.1 of the City Charter, the mayor shall appoint all members of boards and commissions, subject to council approval, unless otherwise provided by general law. 
(b)  When the term of a member of a board or commission expires, the position shall be vacant until a successor is appointed. 
(c)  Beginning with the year 1992, each board or commission shall conduct a review of its mission every five years. If, in the opinion of a majority of the members, the board or commission has fulfilled its mission and useful purpose, it shall make a recommendation to the mayor and council that the board or commission should be dissolved. 
(d)  For every board or commission created after October 1, 1991, the ordinance creating such board or commission shall contain a provision dissolving the body five years after its creation unless prior action is taken by council. 
(Ord. 8-26-91) 
190.02 - ATTENDANCE REQUIREMENT. 
(a)  If any member of any board or commission of the city which has been appointed or reappointed in conformance with the Charter and/or this section and regardless of whether such member was appointed by the mayor or council, absence himself or herself from 40% or more of the regularly scheduled meetings by the board or commission in any 12-month period, his or her office, position or appointment shall become vacant and such vacancy shall be filled in accordance with applicable law. 
(b)  Beginning January 1, 2000, all boards and commissions shall be required to conduct a review of the attendance of its members and submit to the mayor and council annually a report indicating those members whose attendance has failed to meet the requirement as set forth in subparagraph (a) above. Said annual report shall be due no later than the second regularly scheduled meeting of council each February for the preceding calendar year. All persons who are identified as being in violation of subparagraph (a) above shall be removed from the board or commission to which they were appointed so that said vacancy may be filled. 
(Ord. 10-26-98) 
190.03 - RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT AND QUARTERLY REPORTING. 
(a)  All boards, authorities and agencies of the City of Huntington are to comply with the residency requirement as specified in the Official Charter of the City of Huntington. 
(b)  All boards, authorities and agencies of the City of Huntington are to report quarterly to the city council with the attendance records and status of residency of each member. 
(c)  The chairman/president of each board, agency or authority shall certify to the city clerk of any individual that fails to meet the 40% attendance requirement. 
(d)  The city clerk shall inform the appointing authority (mayor or chairman of council) of said individual who has not met the 40% attendance requirement and the appointing authority shall inform the individual by letter of their removal. 
(e)  For the purposes of section 190.03, each board, agency or authority shall inform the city clerk, on an annual basis, of their regularly scheduled meetings. Only these meetings shall be used to compute the 40% attendance requirement. 
(Ord. 8-9-04) 
CHAPTER SEVEN - JUDICIAL 
ARTICLE 191 - MUNICIPAL COURT[30] 

Footnotes: 
--- (30) --- 
Charter reference- General provisions, Art. Five. 
State Law reference- General rights of appeal, W. Va. Code, § 8-24-1; costs for crime victims reparation fund, W. Va. Code, § 14-2A-4; costs for funding training academies, W. Va. Code, § 30-29-4. 

191.01 - AMOUNT OF COSTS TO BE IMPOSED; DISPOSITION. 
    In every case where a fine or jail sentence is imposed and not suspended by the municipal judge, for a violation of the laws or ordinances of the city, the judge shall also require the person so fined or sentenced to pay costs in the sum of $65 with the exception of the charge of overtime parking, in which cases the costs imposed shall be in the sum of $8. 
(Ord. of 8-10-81; Ord. of 4-9-12(1); Ord. of 6-12-17(1) ) 
191.02 - WORKING OUT FINES, ETC. 
    Any person who may be committed for fines, penalties or costs, and who may not be able to discharge the same, shall be required to perform public work to the amount of such fines, costs or penalties, at the rate of $10 per day. In the event any such person has partially so discharged a fine, penalty or cost, and thereafter desires to discharge the remainder in cash, he shall be permitted to do so, and shall be given credit upon the whole amount of the fines, costs or penalties for the number of days of such work. 
191.03 - APPOINTMENT OF COUNSEL FOR INDIGENTS. 
(a)  The municipal court at any time upon request, and upon the filing of an affidavit of indigency as hereinafter provided, shall appoint counsel who shall be reasonably competent in the practice of criminal law to represent an accused of a violation of a municipal criminal ordinance if: 
(1)  There is a present intention on the part of the prosecuting authorities to seek confinement of the accused on that charge; or 
(2)  The judge of the municipal court feels there is a reasonable possibility that he will impose incarceration if the accused is found guilty. 
    In the event an indigent accused is not awarded an attorney, the judge of the municipal court shall inform him at his arraignment that he cannot be incarcerated as a result of the proceedings. 
(b)  This section prohibits the incarceration of indigents after the initial arraignment, unless appointed an attorney; however, incarceration of indigents will be permitted for not longer than 24 hours, or 48 hours on the weekend, if the accused indigent presents an immediate threat of harm to himself or others. 
(1964 Code Sec. 23-56; Ord. 2-14-83) 
191.04 - DETERMINATION OF INDIGENCY ELIGIBILITY; FALSE STATEMENT PROHIBITED; PENALTIES. 
(a)  In determining whether a person is a needy person, the municipal court shall consider such factors as his net worth and the liquidity of his assets, his disposable income, and the number and ages of his dependents, and may consider such other factors as it may deem pertinent and material; but the fact that the accused has been released on bond shall not be determinitive of the question of eligibility. The court shall advise such person of the penalties for giving false information and of the possibility of a civil suit for recovery of moneys advanced under sections 191.03 to 191.06 for his defense. 
(b)  If any attorney willfully gives false information to the court with respect to his services or expenses, he shall be fined a sum not to exceed $500 or may be incarcerated for a period not to exceed 30 days or both. 
(1964 Code Sec. 23-57) 
191.05 - RECOVERY OF AMOUNTS ADVANCED; OFFENSE OF MAKING FALSE STATEMENTS; PENALTIES. 
(a)  Any person charged with violating a municipal ordinance, who appears in municipal court as an indigent, shall be required to furnish information of his financial status and sign an affidavit stating that he is in fact unable to afford an attorney. 
(b)  To the extent that such person is financially able to pay for counsel furnished him under sections 191.03 to 191.06, without undue hardship, the municipal court may order that he make such payment. If such person willfully gives false information to the court with respect to his income or sources, or obligations, he shall be fined not more than $500 or incarcerated not more than 30 days, or both. 
(1964 Code Sec. 23-58) 
191.06 - COMPENSATION FOR ATTORNEYS FOR SERVICE. 
(a)  In each case in which an attorney is assigned under the provisions of sections 191.03 to 191.06 to perform legal services for a needy person, he or she shall be compensated for actual and necessary services rendered at the rate of $20 per hour for work performed out of court and at the rate of $25 per hour for work performed in court; but the compensation for services shall not exceed $300. 
(b)  The attorney shall present to the municipal court a voucher for such services and expenses certifying the same to have been actually performed or incurred, which shall be forwarded to the director of the division of finance with an order of the municipal court approving payment of the amount of the voucher or of such lesser sum to which the municipal court believes the attorney to be entitled. Vouchers submitted more than six months after the last date of service shall be rejected. 
(Ord. 3-9-98) 
191.07 - MUNICIPAL COURT CLERK. 
    Effective July 1, 2004, the Municipal Court Clerk for the City of Huntington will be authorized to perform arraignments. 
(Ord. 7-12-04) 
CHAPTER NINE - EMPLOYMENT PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE 200 - WORKING CONDITIONS FOR NON-CONTRACTUAL EMPLOYEES[31] 

Footnotes: 
--- (31) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted December 22, 2014, amended article 200 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article 200, §§ 200.01-200.14, pertained to similar subject matter. See Comparative Section Table for complete derivation. 
Charter reference- Residency requirement, § 14.3; bonds, § 14.5; loss of qualification, § 14.9; conflict of interest, § 14.10; salary limitation, § 14.13; oath, § 14.14. 

200.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
(a)  Years of service. The term "years of service" as set forth and contained in all pertinent sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs and provisions of article 200 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington shall hereafter read "continuous and uninterrupted years of service to the City of Huntington." No benefit of any kind, type or nature shall hereafter be conferred upon any employee of the City of Huntington for service rendered to another employer, whether public or private, and regardless of whether such service was rendered prior or subsequent to the employee's employment with the City of Huntington. 
(b)  Work week. The work week shall consist of five consecutive eight-hour working days and shall begin on Monday. Any work performed in excess of 40 hours per week shall be subject to the current compensatory time and overtime policy. 
(c)  Non-contractual employees. Non-contractual employees shall include all professional and administrative positions not covered under a collective bargaining agreement. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.02 - CLASSIFICATION OF NON-CONTRACTUAL EMPLOYEES. 
    The mayor, or his/her designee, shall cause to be created and maintained a classification plan assigning each non-contractual position to a class. Each class specification shall be identified by a letter and number which will correlate to a pay grade range within the compensation plan. The mayor, or his/her designee, shall cause to be created and maintained job descriptions which outline the duties, authority, responsibilities, qualifications for each position in each class. The most current classification plan and correlating job descriptions shall be maintained in the human resources office and shall be available for inspection during normal office hours. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.03 - COMPENSATION PLAN. 
(a)  There shall be a pay grade designated by city council for each class within the classification plan, as well as a designated pay range for each position recognized within that class. Within each such pay range, there shall be four pay steps labeled A, B, C, and D. The most current compensation plan shall be maintained in the human resources office and shall be available for inspection during normal office hours. 
(b)  Non-contractual employees shall be paid at the A rate for the first six calendar months of continuous employment; at the B rate for the next 12 calendar months of continuous employment; at the C rate for the next 12 calendar months of continuous employment; and thereafter at the D rate. All in-grade positions shall be subject to the approval of the mayor who may, for outstanding previous experience or education, initially start an employee at a rate higher than A. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.04 - PROBATIONARY PERIOD. 
    New employees shall be considered probationary for a period of six months from their date of hire. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.05 - LONGEVITY. 
    All non-contractual employees shall receive longevity payments commencing on the employee's fourth anniversary. Employees who have previously terminated their employment for any reason and return as an administrative employee or employees who have retired from positions covered by collective bargaining agreements and return as administrative employees shall not transfer longevity time to an administrative position. 
    Longevity shall be based upon the following rates per month, per years of service: 
(a)  $5 per month after four years of service. 
(b)  $6 per month after ten years of service. 
(c)  $7 per month after 20 years of service. 
    Computation of longevity increments in all cases shall be computed as to time of service on the employment anniversary date. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.06 - INSURANCE. 
    The city shall provide an employer-sponsored health care plan. The most current version of the plan shall be maintained in the human resources office and shall be available for inspection during normal office hours. The city shall have the flexibility to modify insurance benefits. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.07 - PAID HOLIDAYS. 
    Recognizing the close and mutually-dependent working relationship between non-contractual employees and those employees within the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) trade union, the official paid holidays for non-contractual employees shall be the same as those listed in the most current AFSCME collective bargaining agreement. A copy of the most current AFSCME collective bargaining agreement shall be maintained in the human resources office and shall be available for inspection during normal office hours. 
    In addition to the holidays granted in this section, employees shall receive two personal leave days with pay each calendar year, which days may be taken at any time during said year with the permission and approval of the department head. Carryover of personal leave and days shall not be permitted under any circumstances. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.08 - VACATION. 
    All non-contractual employees of the City of Huntington shall be entitled to ten working days vacation leave with pay each year accrued on an anniversary year basis. 
    Employees shall be eligible for five working days after six months of service, which is included in the ten days earned during the first year of service. Vacation leave shall not be advanced to employees except with the approval of the mayor. 
    Each employee who has completed five years of continuous employment with the city shall thereafter receive five days annual vacation leave in addition to the leave provided for above, for a total of 15 days. 
    Each employee who has completed 15 years of continuous employment with the city shall receive 20 working days annually as vacation leave. 
    Vacation leave shall be used at the rate of not less than one-half day at a time and shall be used in the anniversary year following that in which it has been accrued. Vacation leave shall be scheduled only by approval of the respective department heads and shall be scheduled on an anniversary year basis so as to avoid any backlog of leave in the month of December. Carry-over will not be permitted without the permission of the mayor and must be taken within the following anniversary year. 
    An employee who is laid off, discharged, retired or separated from the service of the employer for any reason prior to taking his vacation, shall be compensated in cash for the unused vacation he has accumulated at the time of separation, which compensation shall be prorated on a monthly basis, based on the employee's employment anniversary date. 
    Employees who have previously terminated their employment for any reason and return as an administrative employee or employees who have retired from positions covered by collective bargaining agreements and return as administrative employees shall not transfer vacation rights to an administrative position. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.09 - SICK LEAVE. 
    Any employee contracting or incurring any sickness or disability which renders such employee unable to perform the duties of his /her employment shall receive sick leave with pay. Each employee shall be eligible for paid sick leave after 60 days of probationary service with the employer. 
    All full-time non-contractual employees shall be entitled to sick leave with pay for absence due to illness or injury of the employee. Sick leave may be used in the event of illness or death of the employee's mother or stepmother, father or stepfather, spouse, son or stepson, daughter or stepdaughter, upon approval of the department head and authorization by the mayor. 
    After the initial 60 days of probationary employment, an employee shall be granted one day paid sick leave for each month of employment. After completing the probationary period, the employee shall be credited with the appropriate sick leave from the date of employment. An additional four hours sick leave for each month of employment (not to exceed 48 hours per year) shall be credited to the employee and used only in cases of prolonged illness or non-work-related injury confirmed by a physician and extending at least 80 hours or longer, and for retirement. Under certain extenuating circumstances, the 80-hour requirement may be relaxed upon the approval of the mayor. Such credited accumulation may not be used until all regularly accrued sick leave provided for in the first sentence of this section has been used. After completing the probationary service with the employer, the employee shall be credited with the appropriate sick leave from the date of employment. 
    An employee may not utilize paid sick leave in excess of 40 hours per year to care for an ill or injured family member (parent, spouse, or child, including step relations) when it does not qualify as a Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) event. In the event of catastrophic illness that does qualify as an FMLA event, use of additional sick leave may be granted with the approval of the mayor. 
    Upon retirement at the age of 60 years or older, or the employee completing 20 or more years of service, or upon disability retirement, an employee shall be granted additional working days. This proviso shall not be interpreted to mean that an employee is entitled to payment of vacation leave for his/her net accumulated sick leave upon separation of employment with the city, other than those individuals who retire at the age of 60 years or older, or who have completed 20 years of service, or upon disability retirement. 
    Employees may elect to apply up to 75 of the maximum 140 days toward hospitalization coverage. Eligible employees shall receive one month of family hospitalization coverage for each 40 hours of accumulated sick time. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.10 - FUNERAL LEAVE. 
    The city shall pay employees for time lost up to three consecutive working days while arranging for or attending the funeral of a member of the immediate family. "Immediate family" shall include a father, stepfather, mother, stepmother, sister, stepsister, sister-in-law, brother, brother-in-law, stepbrother, grandparents, grandchildren, wife, husband, child, stepchild, mother-in-law and father-in-law. In the case of the death of an employee's relative such as a niece, nephew, aunt or uncle, the employee shall be given one day paid leave of absence to attend funeral services. This section is to be interpreted so that when the event arises the employee receives the time off at the time of bereavement, and shall not be interpreted to give an employee the right to any additional days off, i.e., if a person is regularly scheduled for a vacation or other time off, he/she shall not be entitled to added days off. Said leave in all cases shall be the working days immediately following the death. The mayor, on a case-by-case basis and in his/her discretion, may grant up to a total of three additional days of leave without pay, of which, said three days may include non-working days, as circumstances so warrant. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.11 - INJURY LEAVE. 
(a)  Option 1. An employee who is injured while on the job may elect to receive a percentage of his/her regular pay in an amount equal to the current Workers' Compensation rate for all time lost resulting from such injury for a period of 45 working days following the date of the injury, provided, that, the employee signs a written agreement to reimburse the city all monies received in excess of his/her base wage resulting from the combination of injury pay from the city and Temporary Total Disability (TTD) benefits from Workers' Compensation. Except for the initial three days of the injury leave, the employee shall receive 100% of his/her regular pay. In no event shall an injured employee receive, from a combination of injury pay and Workers' Compensation payments, an amount which would exceed 100% of his/her regular pay for any day while on injury leave. Any employee receiving greater than 100% of his/her base wage as a result of injury pay shall be indebted to the city in the amount in excess of 100%. Such excess shall be repaid immediately upon notification to the employee of said excessive payment by the city or by payroll deduction. 
(b)  Option 2. Alternatively, the employee may elect to receive 100% of his/her regular pay for the first three days of injury leave, and thereafter, the city shall pay the employee 30% of his/her base wage for the period that he/she is considered to be temporarily or totally disabled under the Workers' Compensation statute up until such time as he/she receives his/her first benefit from the Workers' Compensation Commission. 
(c)  No election. If the employee does not make an election of Option 1 or Option 2, then Option 2 shall automatically be in force. 
    The injured employee shall remain on "Pay Status" until his/her return to employment. "Pay status" includes all pay and benefit entitlements. 
    The city shall have the right to require the employee to submit to a medical examination by a doctor designated by the city and qualified to diagnose and evaluate the injury in question. If such examination establishes the ability of the employee to return to work and said employee fails and refuses to do so, then the city may terminate all pay requirements hereunder. In the event such examination shall conclusively establish no injury, it is understood and agreed that all pay received by the employee hereunder shall be repaid to the city. 
    Employees on injury leave or receiving Workers' Compensation benefits shall be considered to be on "Pay Status" not exceeding 12 months without a review by the mayor. 
    Employees shall not be involved in any gainful employment while on injury leave. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.12 - MILITARY SERVICE. 
    Employees who are connected with one or more branches of the Armed Forces, Reserve or National Guard, shall be entitled to a leave of absence as set forth by state or federal law. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.13 - JURY DUTY AND SUBPOENAS. 
    Any employee selected for jury duty or subpoenaed to appear in any court or other public body shall be granted leave with pay for such time as is required to fulfill such duty. The employee shall reimburse the city the total of all compensation received from the court in which he/she was selected for jury duty. In the event an employee is subpoenaed to appear as a witness in a criminal case or as a party to or subpoenaed to appear as a witness on a civil case, he/she may be granted leave with pay. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.14 - PARENTING LEAVE. 
    In the case of either natural birth or adoption, parenting leave, without pay, not to exceed a period of six months shall be granted at the request of an employee; said leave at the discretion of the mayor may upon request of the employees be extended for an additional period not to exceed six months. An employee who has been granted parenting leave shall be entitled to use accrued sick leave for the period she is unable to work for medical reasons as certified by a licensed physician. An employee shall not earn sick leave while she is on parenting leave. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
200.15 - LEAVE WITHOUT PAY. 
    Leave of absence without pay may be granted by the mayor, but such leave shall be limited to a maximum of 30 calendar days in any calendar year; provided that employees who have received or anticipate receiving, military leave in the same calendar year shall not be granted leave without pay. 
(Ord. of 12-22-14(1)) 
ARTICLE 202 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[33] 

Footnotes: 
--- (33) --- 
Charter reference- Residency requirement, § 14.3; bonds, § 14.5; loss of qualification, § 14.9; conflict of interest, § 14.10; salary limitation, § 14.13; oath, § 14.14. 

202.01 - WORKERS' COMPENSATION; SELF-INSURED STATUS. 
    As long as the city has elected to pay compensation and expenses directly under the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 23-2-9, council shall appropriate each year sufficient funds in an amount to pay into the West Virginia Workers' Compensation Fund the city's proper proportion of the expenses of the Workers' Compensation Commissioner in administering the fund, the required amounts into the surplus fund for the coverage of catastrophe and second injury liability, and to pay all workers' compensation benefits anticipated to be payable that year. In addition to the appropriation of such moneys, council shall authorize all other necessary procedures to insure that all workers' compensation payments shall be paid promptly to its employees or fatally injured employees' dependents and shall direct the purchase of excess insurance for the purpose of indemnifying the city against losses per accident in excess of a specific retention level to be determined by council, and, for the purpose of indemnifying the city against annual losses in the aggregate, in excess of a retention level to be determined by council. 
    If at any time the city determines that it is no longer in the best interest of the city, its employees, or the residents to continue to pay compensation and expenses directly under the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 23-2-9, the city shall immediately advise the West Virginia Workers' Compensation Commissioner that it has elected to discontinue paying such compensation and expenses directly as to future claims and shall immediately begin paying into the Workers' Compensation Fund the premiums required to comply with the provisions of W. Va. Code, §§ 23-2-1 and 23-2-5. In the event the city elects to discontinue paying such compensation and expenses directly, it shall, nevertheless, remain liable to and shall pay such compensation and expenses directly in claims arising prior to the election to resume payment of such premiums into the Workers' Compensation Fund. 
(Ord. 10-25-82) 
202.02 - DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN. 
    Council hereby adopts a deferred compensation program and its attendant investment options and hereby establishes the city deferred compensation plan for the voluntary participation of all eligible city employees, elected officials and independent contractors. The mayor is hereby authorized to execute for the city, individual participation agreements with each employee requesting same, and to act as the administrator of the plan representing the city, and to execute such agreements and contracts as are necessary to implement the program. It is implicitly understood that other than the incidental expenses of collecting and disbursing the employee's deferrals and other minor administrative matters, there is to be no cost or contribution by the city to the program. 
(Ord. 10-15-91) 
202.10 - RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT FOR CITY EMPLOYEES. 
(a)  All personnel employed or appointed to the City of Huntington by the council or the mayor after July 1, 2002, whether hourly or salaried, whether full-time or part-time, and whether appointed in the classified civil service or the unclassified positions of the city, must be bona-fide residents of the City of Huntington, Cabell and Wayne Counties, West Virginia, except at the time of appointment or employment when they need not be residents of the City of Huntington, Cabell and Wayne Counties, West Virginia, but shall establish residence in the City of Huntington, Cabell and Wayne Counties, West Virginia, within 90 days of being appointed or employed by the city. 
(b)  All officers and employees of the City of Huntington employed after July 1, 2002 by the city are hereby required as a condition of their continued employment to have their place of abode in the City of Huntington, Cabell and Wayne Counties, and to be bona-fide residents therein, except as otherwise provided by this section. A "bona-fide resident," for the purpose of this section, means a person having a permanent domicile within the City of Huntington, Cabell and Wayne Counties, and one which has not been adopted with the intention of again taking up or claiming a previous residence acquired outside the City of Huntington, Cabell and Wayne Counties, limits. The use of a post office box or nonpersonal residence for mailing purposes shall not be considered a bona-fide resident. 
(c)  Provided, that nothing herein shall be construed as to prevent persons who were originally employed or appointed prior to July 1, 2002 and have not left the service of the City of Huntington for more than 30 consecutive days from being employed in another position with the City of Huntington, promoted or reappointed due to their residency outside the City of Huntington. 
(d)  Failure of any officer, employee or appointee in the classified civil service or the unclassified positions of the City of Huntington to comply with the provisions of this section shall result in immediate discharge from the city service. 
(e)  Upon request of application for employment the mayor or his designee shall provide a copy of the following letter to each applicant that they must complete prior to receiving consideration for employment. 
"I ____________ understand that if I am employed/appointed to any position by the City of Huntington that I must be a permanent resident of the City of Huntington within ninety (90) days of such appointment and must maintain permanent residence within the Municipality of the City of Huntington as a condition of my continued employment. I understand that failure to establish or maintain such residency within the City of Huntington will result in my immediate dismissal for cause and such residency is a condition of my continued employment. 
Signature _____ " 
(f)  (1)  The mayor or mayor designee shall insure by the 89th day of employment by the City of Huntington that the employee shall have a permanent residence within the municipality of the City of Huntington or shall be dismissed at the end of his 90th day. 
(2)  Failure to dismiss an employee who has failed to establish residency within the City of Huntington by the mayor shall result in forfeiture of his compensation (wages/salary) until such time as appropriate action is taken. 
(g)  Upon the effectiveness of this ordinance (July 1, 2002) the City of Huntington shall be in compliance with section 14.3 of the Charter of the City of Huntington. 
(Ord. 2-11-02) 
202.20 - EMPLOYEE TRAINING. 
(a)  Statement of policy. It is the policy of the City of Huntington that every employee be entitled to a working environment free from any kind of unlawful harassment or discrimination regardless of its form or manner. Harassment is unlawful and hurts other employees. Harassment and discrimination can be destructive to employee morale as well as to the city's reputation and can be extremely costly in terms of lost productivity, lost employees, and out-of-pocket expense. Any incident of harassment or discrimination contributes to a general atmosphere in which all persons who share the victim's protected status suffer the consequences and have no legitimate purpose related to the business of the city. 
(b)  Definitions. 
    "Discriminate" shall mean to unlawfully segregate, separate or treat individuals differently based on race, color, sex, gender identity or expression, transgender status, religion or religious beliefs, age, disability, handicap, ethnic, national, or Appalachian regional origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, sexual preference, marital status, parental status, familial status, military discharge status, lawful source of income, housing status, or political affiliation. 
    "Diversity training" shall include, but is not limited to, race, color, sex, gender identity or expression, transgender status, religion or religious beliefs, age, disability, handicap, ethnic, national, or Appalachian regional origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, sexual preference, marital status, parental status, familial status, military discharge status, lawful source of income, housing status, or political affiliation. 
    "Harassment" consists of knowingly pursuing a pattern of conduct that is intended to annoy, seriously alarm or terrorize another person and that serves no lawful purpose. The conduct must be such that it would cause a reasonable person to suffer substantial emotional distress. Harassment includes, but is not limited to, sexual harassment. 
(c)  Training mandated. 
(1)  The division of human resources shall develop and/or cause to be provided relevant training to increase employees' knowledge of awareness of laws and regulations, as well as the city's policies relating to diversity, discrimination, and harassment in the workplace. 
(2)  The training shall include instruction on what harassment, bullying, and discrimination are, how to prevent them, what the repercussions are, and the complaint process. The training shall also include sensitivity training. 
(3)  Each employee shall receive training in diversity and harassment every two years. 
( Ord. of 1-25-16(2) ; Ord. of 1-25-16(3) ) 
ARTICLE 203 - APPOINTMENTS 

203.01 - DUTIES OF CITY CLERK. 
(a)  The city clerk shall maintain a list of all members of boards, agencies, associations, authorities or other entities to include both permanent and temporary groups as to their names, numbers and the dates of their terms of appointment and such list shall be made available to the public during normal working hours. 
(b)  The city clerk shall inform council members 30 days prior to the expiration of any appointment. 
(c)  Upon any appointment by council or the mayor and approval by council the clerk shall prepare a certificate of appointment for that individual which shall state the board, agency or authority and the term of office and shall be presented to the individual when the oath of office is taken in front of either the city clerk or chairman of said board or other authority that may legally administer the oath of office. 
(Ord. 4-23-01) 
203.02 - PERSONNEL COMMITTEE. 
(a)  There shall be a standing committee of council titled "Personnel Committee". 
(b)  They shall solicit nominations from all council members on any appointment. 
(c)  They may also seek and receive applications and recommendations from the general public, the mayor or other government agency or institution. 
(1)  Solicitations and/or recommendations shall at a minimum contain the name of the individual, address, phone number, occupation and past community experience. 
(2)  It may include recommendations on other pertinent facts that the committee and/or council may consider in its deliberations. 
(d)  The committee shall review all applicants and may, at is discretion, conduct personal interviews or request other information from applicants at its sole discretion. 
(e)  The personnel committee shall not consider any individual for appointment who is not resident of the municipality of the City of Huntington. 
(f)  The personnel committee shall recommend a nominee to council at least five working days prior to the meeting of council at which the nominee is to be considered for appointment. 
(Ord. 4-23-01) 
203.03 - APPOINTMENTS BY COUNCIL. 
(a)  Council shall appoint by a majority vote. 
(b)  If a nominee's appointment fails, council shall instruct the committee to provide another nominee five working days prior to the next council meeting. 
(c)  Council may by a two-thirds vote of the members present, remove any appointee of the governing body prior to the expiration of their term for any reason, such appointment shall be considered at will. 
(Ord. 4-23-01) 
203.11 - APPOINTMENTS BY THE MAYOR. 
(a)  The mayor shall present appointments to council for confirmation when required and shall state by letter that the individual is qualified, a resident of the City of Huntington and that all appropriate rules, regulations and ordinances have been followed with the appointment. 
(b)  The mayor may recommend to the personnel committee individuals for appointment to any organization, where the appointing authority is vested in council and the committee shall give such consideration to his recommendation as it deems appropriate and may call upon the mayor to state his recommendations to council in an executive session or upon the floor of council. 
(c)  The mayor shall forward the name of the individual to be confirmed to the personnel committee at least 15 working days prior to the council meeting to which the nomination is to be confirmed so council may do its due diligence. 
(d)  The mayor shall furnish any information that he feels shall be pertinent to the confirmation to the personnel committee and upon his discretion may provide the same to all council members. 
(Ord. 4-23-01) 
203.20 - VETO PROCEDURES. 
(a)  At the request of three members of council, an order shall be drafted by the city attorney that shall be presented to council vetoing any appointment not subject to confirmation by council and shall be presented to the floor of council within 30 days of said appointment by the mayor in accordance with the Official Charter of the City of Huntington. 
(b)  The personnel committee shall interview the appointed individual after said order has been prepared. They may interview any council member, the mayor or other individual that might provide information to be considered upon a vote. Such interviews shall be held in executive session. 
(c)  (1)  The personnel committee shall not consider any of the following in its deliberations or recommendations: 
A.  Racial or ethnic origin. 
B.  Sexual orientation. 
C.  Marital status. 
D.  Religious affiliation. 
E.  Political affiliation. 
F.  Pending or past civil litigation. 
G.  Hearsay testimony. 
(2)  The personnel committee shall consider the following: 
A.  Past bad acts either admitted to by the individual or convictions. 
B.  Alleged bad acts that they have received direct testimony. 
C.  Education. 
D.  Attitude. 
E.  Residency. 
F.  Other qualifications relating to the duties of the job. 
(d)  The personnel committee shall provide to the mayor, at least three days prior to the council meeting that a veto order is to be considered, an explanation of the committee's concerns. 
(e)  The personnel committee shall make a written recommendation to council supporting or rejecting the proposed veto. The committee may at is discretion provide reasons for its recommendation. 
(f)  Veto shall be stated to have passed upon a roll call vote where two-thirds ( 2/3 ) majority of council members present, provided that a quorum is present, shall vote yea on the order. 
(Ord. 4-23-01) 
203.30 - MULTIPLE BOARD APPOINTMENTS. 
(a)  No individual shall be appointed to more than two boards, commissions, authorities, agencies or other entities with the exception of the mayor or council members. 
(b)  Any appointed member of a board, commission, authority, agency or other entity who is currently serving on multiple entities by appointment shall be allowed to finish their appointed terms, but shall not be reappointed to multiple entities unless they be the mayor or council members. 
(Ord. 4-23-01) 
ARTICLE 204 - REINSTATEMENT AND REHIRING OF CITY EMPLOYEES 

204.01 - PURPOSE. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide parameters where collective bargaining agreements and state code are silent concerning layoffs and reinstatement to City of Huntington employees. 
(Ord. 5-12-03) 
204.10 - REHIRING. 
(a)  An individual may be rehired to any department within one year of lay-off. The individual may not be rehired and/or reinstated if the employee was terminated for cause. 
(b)  An individual who is laid off from employment with the City of Huntington shall be afforded equal status, time in grade and service with the city if they are rehired and/or reinstated within the one-year period. 
(c)  If an individual was laid off from employment with the City of Huntington desires to return to work for the city and there has been a break of one year or greater, then the individual must submit an application for employment as a new hire and must meet all prerequisites for employment upon the new hire date. 
(Ord. 5-12-03) 
PART THREE - TRAFFIC CODE 
CHAPTER ONE - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE 301 - DEFINITIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Speed race defined, § 335.04. 
State Law reference- See sectional histories for similar state law. 

301.01 - MEANING OF WORDS AND PHRASES. 
    The following words and phrases when used in this Traffic Code shall, for the purpose of this Traffic Code, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this article. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-1. 
301.02 - AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLE. 
    "Authorized emergency vehicle" means vehicles of the fire department, duly chartered rescue squad, police department, ambulance service, state, county or municipal agency and such privately owned ambulances, tow trucks, wreckers, flag car services, vehicles providing road service to disabled vehicles, service vehicles of a public service corporation, postal service vehicles, snow removal equipment, Class A vehicles of firefighters, Class A vehicles of members of ambulance services, and Class A vehicles of members of duly chartered rescue squads, and all other emergency vehicles as are designated by the agency responsible for the operation and control of these persons or organizations. Class A vehicles are as defined by W. Va. Code, § 17A-10-1. Agency authorization and emergency equipment are defined in W. Va. Code, § 17C-15-26. Agencies responsible for issuing authorization for emergency vehicle permits may promulgate such regulations that are necessary for the issuance of permits for emergency vehicles. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-6. 
301.03 - BICYCLE. 
    "Bicycle" means every device which does not have a motor attached and which is propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels either of which is more than 20 inches in diameter. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-8. 
301.04 - BUS. 
    "Bus" means every motor vehicle designed for carrying more than seven passengers and used for the transportation of persons; and every motor vehicle, other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-13. 
301.05 - BUSINESS DISTRICT. 
(a)  "Business district" means the territory contiguous to and including a street or highway when within any 600 feet along such highway there are buildings in use for business or industrial purposes, including but not limited to hotels, banks or office buildings, railroad stations, and public buildings which occupy at least 300 feet of frontage on one side or 300 feet collectively on both sides of the street or highway. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-45. 
(b)  "Central business district" means all streets and portions of streets within the area bounded on the west by Sixth Street, on the south by the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad main line right-of-way, on the east by Thirteenth Street and on the north by the Ohio River. 
(1964 Code Sec. 22-1) 
301.06 - CONTROLLED-ACCESS HIGHWAY. 
    "Controlled-access highway" means every highway, street or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the same except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street or roadway. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-41. 
301.07 - CROSSWALK. 
    "Crosswalk" includes: 
(a)  That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the street or highway measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway; and 
(b)  Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-43. 
301.08 - DRIVER. 
    "Driver" or "operator" means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-31. 
301.081 - ELECTRIC PERSONAL ASSISTIVE MOBILITY DEVICE. 
    "Electric personal assistive mobility device" or "EPAMD" means a self-balancing, two nontandem-wheeled device, designed to transport only one person, with an electric propulsion system with average power of 750 watts (one horse power), whose maximum speed on a paved level surface, when powered solely by such a propulsion system while ridden by an operator who weighs 170 pounds, is less than 20 miles per hour. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-66. 
301.09 - EXPLOSIVES. 
    "Explosives" means any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is commonly used or intended for the purpose of producing an explosive and which contains any oxidizing and combustive units or other ingredients in such proportions, quantities or packing that an ignition by fire, by friction, by concussion, by percussion or by detonator of any part of the compound or mixture may cause such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the resultant gaseous pressures are capable of producing destructive effects on contiguous objects or of destroying life or limb. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-24. 
301.10 - FLAMMABLE LIQUID. 
    "Flammable liquid" means any liquid which has a flash point of 70 degrees Fahrenheit, or less, as determined by a tagliabue or equivalent closed-cup test device. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-25. 
301.11 - GROSS WEIGHT. 
    "Gross weight" means the weight of a vehicle without load plus the weight of any load thereon. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-26. 
301.12 - INTERSECTION. 
    "Intersection" includes: 
(a)  The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two streets or highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different streets or highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict; and 
(b)  Where a street or highway includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided street or highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. In the event such intersecting street or highway also includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of two roadways of such streets or highways shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-42. 
301.13 - LANED ROADWAY. 
    "Laned roadway" means a roadway which is divided into two or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-39. 
301.14 - MOPED. 
    "Moped" means every motorcycle or motor-driven cycle unless otherwise specified in this Traffic Code, which is equipped with two or three wheels, foot pedals to permit muscular propulsion and an independent power source providing a maximum of two brake horsepower. If a combustion engine is used, the maximum piston or rotor displacement shall be 50 cubic centimeters regardless of the number of chambers in such power source. The power source shall be capable of propelling the vehicle, unassisted, at a speed not to exceed 30 miles per hour on a level road surface and shall be equipped with a power drive system that functions directly or automatically only, not requiring clutching or shifting by the operator after the drive system is engaged. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-5a. 
301.15 - MOTORCYCLE. 
    "Motorcycle" means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-4. 
301.16 - MOTOR-DRIVEN CYCLE. 
    "Motor-driven cycle" means every motorcycle having a piston displacement of more than 50 cubic centimeters but not more than 150 cubic centimeters, or with not more than five brake horsepower. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-5. 
301.17 - MOTOR VEHICLE. 
    "Motor vehicle" means every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails, except motorized wheelchairs. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-3. 
301.18 - OWNER. 
    "Owner" means a person who holds the legal title of a vehicle or in the event a vehicle is the subject of an agreement for the conditional sale or lease thereof with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the conditional vendee or lessee, or in the event a mortgagor of a vehicle is entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor shall be deemed the owner for the purpose of this Traffic Code. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-32. 
301.19 - PARK. 
    "Park" when prohibited, means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-54. 
301.20 - PARKING AREA. 
    "Parking area" means lots, areas or other accommodations for the parking of vehicles off the street or highway and open to public use with or without charge. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-60. 
301.201 - PASSENGER VAN. 
    "Passenger van" means any van or other motor vehicle owned by any agency, business or other legal entity and operated for the purpose of transportation of children under the age of 18 years, other than a van utilized for private use, taxicab, bus or school bus. Passenger vans include, but are not limited to, vehicles used by daycare centers, after-school centers and nursery schools; provided, that the term "passenger van" does not include any van or other motor vehicle which is utilized for the specific purpose of transporting children to medical facilities for the purpose of medical or dental treatment and which loads and unloads the children on private property, making no stops for loading or unloading along public roads or highways. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-64. 
301.21 - PEDESTRIAN. 
    "Pedestrian" means any person afoot or any person using a wheelchair. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-30. 
301.22 - PERSON. 
    "Person" means every natural person, firm, copartnership, association or corporation. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-29. 
301.23 - POLE TRAILER. 
    "Pole trailer" means every vehicle without motive power designed to be drawn by another vehicle and attached to the towing vehicle by means of a reach, or pole, or by being boomed or otherwise secured to the towing vehicle and ordinarily used for transporting long or irregularly shaped loads such as poles, pipes, trusses or structural members capable, generally, of sustaining themselves as beams between the supporting connections. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-17. 
301.24 - POLICE OFFICER. 
    "Police officer" means every officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-33. 
301.25 - PRIVATE ROAD OR DRIVEWAY; PRIVATE PROPERTY. 
(a)  "Private road" or "driveway" means every way or place in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not by other persons. 
(b)  "Private property" means real estate in private ownership without regard to the manner in which it is used. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-36. 
301.26 - RAILROAD. 
    "Railroad" means a carrier of persons or property, upon cars, other than streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-21. 
301.27 - RAILROAD SIGN OR SIGNAL. 
    "Railroad sign" or "signal" means any sign, signal or device erected by authority of a public body or official or by a railroad and intended to give notice of the presence of railroad tracks or the approach of a railroad train. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-49. 
301.28 - RAILROAD TRAIN. 
    "Railroad train" means a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto, operated upon rails, except streetcars. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-22. 
301.29 - RESIDENCE DISTRICT. 
    "Residence district" means the territory contiguous to and including a street or highway not comprising a business district when the property on such street or highway for a distance of 300 feet or more is in the main improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-46. 
301.30 - RESIDENTIAL STREET. 
    "Residential street" means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way, whether publicly or privately maintained, located within any subdivision, development or other similar area used primarily for residential purposes when any part thereof is open to the common use of those living in such area for the purpose of vehicular travel. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-62. 
301.31 - RIGHT-OF-WAY. 
    "Right-of-way" means the privilege of the immediate use of the street or highway. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-51. 
301.32 - ROADWAY. 
    "Roadway" means that portion of a street or highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. In the event a street or highway includes two or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" as used herein shall refer to any such roadway separately but not to all such roadways collectively. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-37. 
301.33 - SAFETY ZONE. 
    "Safety zone" means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-44. 
301.34 - SCHOOL BUS. 
    "School bus" means every motor vehicle owned by a public or governmental agency and operated for the transportation of children to or from school, or privately owned and operated for compensation for the transportation of children to or from school. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-7. 
301.35 - SCHOOL GROUNDS. 
    "School grounds" includes the land on which a school is built together with such other land used by students for play, recreation or athletic events while attending school. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-55. 
301.36 - SEMITRAILER. 
    "Semitrailer" means every vehicle with or without motive power, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so contructed that some part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-16. 
301.37 - SIDEWALK. 
    "Sidewalk" means that portion of a street or highway between the curb lines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of pedestrians. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-38. 
301.38 - STOP. 
    "Stop" when required, means complete cessation from movement. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-52. 
301.39 - STOP, STOPPING OR STANDING. 
    "Stop", "stopping," or "standing," when prohibited, means any stopping or standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-53. 
301.40 - STREET OR HIGHWAY; ALLEY. 
(a)  "Street" or "highway" means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel (W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-35), and shall also include, but not be limited to, all public streets and highways within the city, the municipal parking garage and any and all other city parking lots and facilities. 
(b)  "Alley" means a street or highway intended to provide access to the rear or side of lots or buildings in urban districts and not intended for the purpose of through vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. 9-27-93) 
301.41 - THROUGH STREET OR THROUGH HIGHWAY. 
    "Through street" or "through highway" means every street or highway or portion thereof at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting streets or highways is required by law to stop before entering or crossing the same and when stop signs are erected as provided in this Traffic Code. 
State Law reference- W. Va. Code, § 17C-1-40. 
301.42 - TRAFFIC.
