(c)  Revocation of permit. A mobile food vendor permit shall be revoked by the permit administrator if: 
(1)  Four violations of this article have occurred within a 12-month period. 
(2)  A mobile food service vehicle is operated in an unlawful manner so as to constitute a breach of the peace or otherwise threaten the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(d)  Reinstatement. 
(1)  Suspended permit. An operator may reinstate a suspended mobile food vendor permit by taking such actions as may be necessary to correct a mobile food service vehicle's noncompliance and paying a reinstatement fee of $500 to offset the city' cost of enforcement measures, inspections and compliance verifications. 
(2)  Revoked permit. An operator whose mobile food vendor permit has been revoked may apply for a new permit after 12 months from the date of revocation, provided the operator has taken such actions as may be necessary to correct a mobile food service vehicle's noncompliance. The operator shall pay a permit reinstatement fee of $500 to offset the city's cost of enforcement measures, inspections and compliance verifications. 
(3)  No permit will be issued to any person who intends to operate the same mobile food service vehicle for which the operator's permit is currently suspended or has been revoked within the preceding 12 months. 
(e)  Notice. Notice of the suspension or revocation of a mobile food vendor permit shall be issued to the operator in writing by the permit administrator. 
(Ord. of 4- 9-18(2) ) 
710.08 - APPEALS. 
(a)  Filing. The denial, suspension or revocation of a mobile food vendor permit by the permit administrator may be appealed by filing a written notice of appeal, establishing the grounds for the appeal, with the mayor or designee no later than ten business days following receipt of the notice of denial, suspension or revocation. 
(b)  Mayor's review. When an appeal is filed with the mayor as set forth herein, the mayor or his designee may request such additional information from the operator and the permit administrator as may be deemed necessary. At the mayor or designee's discretion, the appeal may be decided based on the written information and documentation submitted, or a hearing may be scheduled with the operator and the permit administrator. The mayor's decision shall be issued in writing, based on a written summation of the pertinent facts, and shall be final. The mayor may reverse the denial, suspension or revocation of a permit, or may reduce the waiting period required for reinstatement of a revoked permit if it is determined that the operator has taken reasonable steps to mitigate the violations leading to the revocation and to prevent future violations. 
(c)  Refunds. There shall be no refund of an application fee for a mobile food vendor permit that has been denied. There shall be no refund of a reinstatement fee for a suspended or revoked permit unless the mayor or his designee determines on appeal that the permit administrator acted in error in suspending or revoking the permit. 
(Ord. of 4- 9-18(2) ) 
710.09 - MISCELLANEOUS. 
(a)  In case of conflict between this ordinance or any part hereof, and the whole or part of any existing ordinance of the city, the provision that establishes the higher standard shall prevail. 
(b)  If any section, subsection, clause, provision or portion of this ordinance is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such holding shall not affect any other section, subsection, clause, provision or portion of this article. 
(Ord. of 4- 9-18(2) ) 
ARTICLE 713 - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Trespass, § 533.02. 
State Law reference- Solicitation of charitable funds, W. Va. Code, Art. 29-19; obtaining money by false premises, W. Va. Code, § 61-3-24 et seq. 

713.01 - CREATION; NUMBER, QUALIFICATIONS AND TERM. 
    For the purpose of authorizing, regulating, restricting and controlling the public begging or soliciting of moneys or other form of financial assistance, or the sale or offer for sale of anything of value for or in behalf of any charitable, religious, patriotic, social, benevolent, fraternal or philanthropic organization or purpose in the city, there is hereby created a public solicitations commission, consisting of three members, who shall be over the age of 21 years, residents of the city and who shall be selected in the manner provided in this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-1) 
713.02 - MEMBERSHIP. 
    The mayor shall select three members having the qualifications set forth in section 713.01 to serve on the public solicitations commission as members thereof. Each member shall be subject to the approval of council. At the expiration of the term of any such member by death, resignation or removal, the mayor shall designate his successor in office. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-2) 
713.03 - COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS. 
    Members of the public solicitations commission shall serve without compensation. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-3) 
713.04 - MEETINGS. 
    The public solicitations commission shall meet in regular session at least once each month, and shall meet more often, if necessary, to carry out and to perform the duties imposed upon the commission by this article and other city ordinances. The secretary of the commission shall give notice to each member of the commission, by United States mail or verbally, of the time and place of each meeting of the commission. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-4) 
713.05 - QUORUM. 
    Two members of the public solicitations commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-5) 
713.06 - CHAIRMAN; SECRETARY. 
    The chairman of the public solicitations commission shall be elected by and from the membership of the commission. The city clerk shall act as secretary of the commission. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-6) 
713.07 - RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
    The public solicitations commission shall have the power to prescribe rules and regulations for the carrying out of purposes of the commission expressed in section 713.01. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-7) 
713.08 - PERMIT REQUIRED. 
    No person shall solicit money or any other form of financial assistance, or shall sell or offer for sale anything of value, for or in behalf of any charitable, religious, patriotic, social, benevolent, fraternal or philanthropic organization or purpose in the city unless such person shall first obtain a permit to solicit or sell such thing of value for such purpose, which permit shall be issued under the terms and regulations stated in this article. 
(Ord. 8-31-81) 
713.09 - SECRETARY TO RECEIVE PERMIT APPLICATIONS. 
    The mayor shall take and receive applications for permits required by section 713.08. When an applicant files with the commission an application on a form approved by the commission, the applicant shall therein answer, under oath, all of the questions contained in the form and shall furnish to the commission all such information as may be of assistance to the commission in determining whether a permit is granted to such person. The failure or refusal to file an application and furnish the information shall constitute sufficient grounds for the commission to deny the applicant such permit. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-9) 
713.10 - APPLICATION TO BE SWORN TO; INFORMATION TO BE CONTAINED IN APPLICATION. 
    Applications for permits required by this article shall be sworn to and shall contain the following information: 
(a)  The name of the organization applying for a permit and the address of its headquarters. 
(b)  The names and addresses of its principal officers and managers. 
(c)  The purposes for which the permit is desired and the use to be made of any receipts therefrom. 
(d)  The names and addresses of the persons by whom the receipts are to be disbursed. 
(e)  The names and addresses of the persons who will be in direct charge of such sale or solicitation. 
(f)  An outline of the method to be used in such solicitation or sale. 
(g)  The amount of moneys expected to be realized from the solicitation or sale. 
(h)  The amount of wages, fees, commissions, expenses or emoluments to be expended or paid in connection with such solicitation or sale, together with the manner in which the wages, fees, commissions, expenses or emoluments are to be expended and to whom they are to be paid. 
(i)  A full statement of the character and extent of the charitable, religious, patriotic, social, benevolent, fraternal or philanthropic work now being done by the applicant organizations. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-10) 
713.11 - GRANT OR REFUSAL OF PERMIT; FEE; TERM AND RENEWAL. 
    The public solicitations commission shall determine from the application provided for in section 713.10 and from such facts as may be developed in connection with the application, whether or not a permit is granted the applicant, and its decision shall be noted in the minutes of the commission. If the decision of the commission is that a permit is granted, the director of the division of finance, upon receipt of a fee of $1, shall issue to the applicant a permit for the period designated in the minutes, which shall be for a period not longer than three months; provided, that the commission may renew and extend such permit for a period not to exceed three months. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-11) 
713.12 - PERMIT CONDITIONS. 
    The public solicitations commission may impose such conditions and terms to a permit issued under this article as to it may deem reasonable. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-12) 
713.13 - PERMITS NONTRANSFERABLE; USE OF SOLICITORS AND REPRESENTATIVES BY PERMITTEE. 
    Any permit issued pursuant to this article shall be nontransferable; provided, that this shall not prevent any permittee from using any number of solicitors and representatives as is reported to and approved by the public solicitations commission. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-13) 
713.14 - PERMIT REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION. 
    Any permit issued pursuant to this article may be revoked or suspended by the public solicitations commission upon noncompliance on the part of the holder with the terms of the permit or evidence of fraud or misrepresentation committed by the licensee or his agents in and about the solicitation, sale or offer for sale for purposes set forth in section 713.01 or if, in the opinion of the commission, any practice pursued or any act committed in the solicitation or disposition of the proceeds is unfair, unjust or inequitable. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-14) 
713.15 - CARDS FOR INDIVIDUAL SOLICITORS AND REPRESENTATIVES. 
    The director of the division of finance shall furnish any permittee with cards for the use of individual solicitors or representatives in such quantity as directed by the public solicitations commission in its minutes, upon payment by the permittee of $0.15 for each card. Such cards shall state that the bearer is licensed by the city to make the solicitation or sale described thereon. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-15) 
713.16 - DISPOSITION OF FEES; PAYMENT OF EXPENSES. 
    All fees paid to the director of the division of finance by virtue of this article shall be deposited in the general fund. The operating expenses required in the administration of this article shall be paid by the director of the division of finance from the general fund of the city. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-16) 
713.17 - APPEAL FROM ACTION OF SOLICITATIONS COMMISSION. 
    An applicant for a permit under the provisions of this article may appeal from any action of the public solicitations commission to council, provided, that notice of such appeal shall be filed with the city clerk within 14 days of the date of the action appealed from. No formal method of procedure shall be necessary for making such appeal. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-17) 
713.18 - EXEMPTION OF CERTAIN SOLICITATIONS. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to prevent or forbid any pastor, priest, rabbi, rector, minister of the gospel or the governing body of any church, or the members or officers of any established society, association or corporation that is organized exclusively for charitable, religious, patriotic, social, benevolent, fraternal or philanthropic purposes, not operated for profit in which none of the net earnings of such organization inure to the pecuniary benefit of any person, shareholder or individual, from conducting a private solicitation among the members thereof, and nothing contained in this article shall grant the public solicitations commission the right to prevent or prohibit any pastor, priest, rabbi, rector, minister of the gospel or the governing body of any church from making a public solicitation. 
(1964 Code Sec. 8-18) 
713.99 - PENALTY. 
Editor's note- See Section 101.99 for general Codified Ordinances penalty. 
ARTICLE 717 - COMMERCIAL SOLICITATIONS AT RESIDENCES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Trespass, § 533.02; charitable solicitations, Art. 713; license taxes, § 739.11. 
State Law reference- Solicitation of charitable funds, W. Va. Code, Art. 29-19; obtaining money by false premises, W. Va. Code, § 61-3-24 et seq. 

717.01 - RESIDENTIAL SOLICITATION A NUISANCE. 
    Except as provided by section 713.08, the practice of going in and upon private residences in the city by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants and transient vendors of merchandise, not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant of such private residences, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, or for the purpose of disposing of or peddling or hawking the same is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Ord. 8-31-81) 
717.99 - PENALTY. 
    Whoever perpetrates a nuisance as described and prohibited in section 717.01 shall be fined not less than $75, or more than $200. 
(Ord. 7-13-81) 
ARTICLE 721 - SECURITY DEVICES 

721.01 - SECURITY REQUIREMENTS; EXEMPTIONS. 
    Except as hereinafter specifically exempted, all existing and future buildings in the city used by any person for the purpose of conducting, managing or carrying on any business, when not occupied by a watchman, maintenance personnel or other authorized persons during the period that such building is closed to business, shall be so secured as to prevent unauthorized entry in accordance with specifications for physical security of exterior accessible openings as provided in sections 721.05 and 721.06. Provided, that existing buildings used for residential purposes shall not be subject to this article; however, any multiunit building constructed for this purpose after July 9, 1979 shall be subject to the terms, modifications, requirements and penalties of this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-77) 
721.02 - ENFORCEMENT OF PROVISIONS; RIGHT OF ENTRY. 
    The chief of police is hereby authorized and directed to enforce the provisions of this article; and upon presentation of proper credentials, the chief of police or his duly authorized representative may, with the consent of the occupant or pursuant to a lawfully issued warrant, enter at reasonable times any building or premises used for business purposes for the purpose of inspecting the physical security of exterior accessible openings of such building or premises. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-78) 
721.03 - RESPONSIBILITY FOR COMPLIANCE. 
    Responsibility for compliance with the specifications set forth in sections 721.05 and 721.06 shall be as follows: 
(a)  As to buildings occupied by a business establishment which does not share the exterior openings of such building with any other business establishment, the person operating such business shall be responsible. 
(b)  As to buildings occupied by two or more business establishments which share the same exterior openings of such building, the owner of such building or his agent having charge, care or control of such building shall be responsible. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-79) 
721.04 - INSPECTION; NOTICE. 
    The chief of police shall inspect or cause to be inspected the accessible exterior openings of every building subject to the provisions of this article and if he shall find accessible exterior openings in any such building which do not comply with the specifications set forth in sections 721.05 and 721.06 hereof, he shall give notice in writing to the person responsible, as designated in section 721.03 hereof, setting forth the deficiencies which are to be corrected and the period of time within which such corrections shall be completed. Failure to comply with such notice within the period of time specified shall be a violation of this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-80) 
721.05 - SECURITY MEASURES; LOCKING DEVICES. 
    All exterior openings of any building used for business purposes and subject to the provisions of this article and not otherwise protected by photoelectric, ultrasonic or other intrusion-detection devices approved by the chief of police, shall be secured as provided in this section. 
(a)  Front doors. All front doors of any such building or premises shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Tempered glass doors, wood or metal doors with tempered glass panels and solid wood or metal doors shall be secured as follows: 
A.  A single door shall be equipped with a double cylinder dead lock that unlocks from both the outside and inside by key; with a cylinder dead lock that unlocks from the outside by key and the inside by turnpiece, handle or knob; or with a dead locking latch having a guarded bolt that unlocks from the outside by key and the inside by turnpiece, handle or knob. 
B.  On double doors, the active leaf shall be equipped with a type of lock as prescribed for single doors above and the inactive leaf shall be equipped with flush bolts at the head and foot. 
(2)  Doors with glass panels not of tempered glass and doors that have nontempered glass panels adjacent to the door frame shall be secured as follows: 
A.  A single door shall be equipped with a cylinder dead lock that unlocks from both the outside and the inside by a key. 
B.  On double doors, the active leaf shall be equipped with a cylinder dead lock that unlocks from both the outside and the inside by a key and the inactive leaf shall be equipped with flush bolts at the head and foot. 
(3)  Rolling overhead doors that are not controlled or locked by electric power operation shall be equipped on the inside with the following protective devices: 
A.  Manually operated doors shall be provided with slide bolts on the bottom bar. 
B.  Chain operated doors shall be provided with a cast iron keeper and pin for securing the hand chain. 
C.  Crank operated doors shall be provided with a means for securing the operating shaft. 
(4)  A solid overhead, swinging, sliding or accordion garage-type door shall be secured with a cylinder lock, padlock and/or metal slide bar, bolt or crossbar on the inside when not otherwise controlled or locked by electric power operation. If a padlock is used, it shall be of hardened steel shackle, with a minimum four-pin tumbler operation. In the event that this type of door provides the only entrance to the front of the building, a cylinder lock or padlock may be used on the outside. 
(5)  Metal accordion grate or grill-type doors shall be equipped with a metal guide track at the top and bottom and a cylinder lock and/or padlock with hardened steel shackle and a minimum four-pin tumbler operation. 
(6)  Outside hinges on all front doors shall be provided with nonremovable pins. Such hinge pins may be either welded, flanged or secured by a screw. 
(b)  Rear, side and basement doors. All accessible rear, side and basement doors of any building or premises shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  All doors of the types listed below shall comply with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section for front doors: 
A.  Tempered glass doors or wood or metal doors with tempered glass panels. 
B.  Metal doors. 
C.  Rolling overhead doors. 
D.  Solid overhead, swinging, sliding or accordion garage-type doors. 
E.  Metal accordion grate or grill-type doors. 
(2)  Doors with glass panels and doors that have glass panels adjacent to the door frame shall be secured as follows: 
A.  The glass panel shall be covered with iron bars of at least one-half inch round or one inch by one-fourth inch flat steel material spaced not more than five inches apart; 
B.  Iron or steel grills of at least one-eighth inch material of two-inch mesh; 
C.  If the door or glass panel barrier is on the outside, it shall be secured with rounded head flush bolts on the outside; or 
D.  If the remaining portion of a door panel exceeds eight inches by twelve inches, excluding door frame, is of wood but not of solid core construction, or is less than one and three-eighths inches thick, such portion shall be covered on the inside with at least 16-gauge sheet steel attached with screws. 
(3)  Wood doors not of solid core construction or with panels therein less than one and three-eighths inches thick shall be covered on the inside with at least 16-gauge sheet steel attached with screws. 
(4)  Locking devices. 
A.  A single door shall be equipped with either a double cylider dead lock that unlocks from both the outside and inside by key; with a cylinder dead lock that unlocks from the outside by key and the inside by turnpiece, handle or knob; with a dead locking latch having a guarded bolt that unlocks from the outside by key and the inside by turnpiece, handle or knob; or with an approved slide bar bolt, crossbar and/or padlock. If a padlock is used, it shall be of hardened steel shackle with a minimum four-pin tumbler operation. 
B.  On double doors, the active leaf shall be equipped with a type of lock as prescribed for single doors above and the inactive leaf shall be equipped with flush bolts at the head and foot. 
(5)  Outside hinges on all rear, side and basement doors shall be provided with nonremovable pins. Such hinge pins may be either welded, flanged or secured by a screw. 
(c)  Roof doors. All doors that exit onto the roof of any such building or premises shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Doors with glass panels and any glass panels that are adjacent to the door frame shall be protected as follows: 
A.  The glass portion shall be covered with iron or steel grills of at least one-eighth inch material of no more than two-inch mesh securely fastened. 
B.  If the door or glass panel barrier is on the outside, it shall be secured with rounded head flush bolts on the outside. 
C.  If the remaining portion of a door panel exceeds eight inches by twelve inches, excluding the door frame, and is of wood but not of solid core construction or is less than one and three-eighths inches thick, such portion shall be covered on the inside with at least 16-gauge sheet steel attached with screws. 
(2)  Wood doors not of solid core construction or with panels therein less than one and three-eighths inches thick shall be covered on the inside with at least 16-gauge sheet steel attached with screws. 
(3)  All roof doors shall be provided with a lock that will permit the door to be opened from the inside without the use of a key or any special knowledge or effort. 
(4)  Outside hinges on all roof doors shall be provided with nonremovable pins. Such hinge pins may be either welded, flanged or secured by a screw. 
(d)  Glass windows. The chief of police, with the advice and assistance of the chief of the fire department, shall determine the extent of protection, if any, that will be required for accessible glass windows at the side or rear of such building. Glass windows shall be deemed accessible if they are less than 18 feet above ground. In making his determination, he shall consider whether the side of the building fronts on a street; the area, the location and the contents thereof; and whether such openings are protected by intrusion detection devices. 
(1)  The chief of police may require side and rear glass windows with panes exceeding 96 square inches in area with the smallest dimension exceeding six inches to be protected in the following manner: 
A.  Inside or outside iron bars of at least one-half inch round or one-inch by one-fourth inch flat steel material spaced not more than five inches apart securely fastened; or 
B.  Inside or outside iron or steel grills of at least one-eighth inch material of two-inch mesh securely fastened. If such barrier is on the outside, it shall be secured with rounded head flush bolts on the outside. 
(2)  If the side or rear window is of the type that can be opened, it shall, where applicable, be secured on the inside with either a glide bar, bolt, crossbar and/or padlock with hardened steel shackle and a minimum four-pin tumbler operation. 
(3)  Outside hinges on all side and rear glass windows shall be provided with nonremovable pins. Such hinge pins may be either welded, flanged or secured by a screw. 
(e)  Accessible transoms. All exterior transoms exceeding eight inches by twelve inches on the side and rear of any such building or premises shall be protected by either of the following: 
(1)  Outside iron bars of at least one-half inch round or one-inch by one-fourth inch flat steel material spaced no more than five inches apart; or 
(2)  Outside iron or steel grills of at least one-eighth inch material, but not more than two-inch mesh. Such barrier shall be secured with rounded head flush bolts on the outside. 
(f)  Roof openings. All exterior openings on the roof of any such building or premises shall be protected as follows: 
(1)  Glass skylights shall be provided with: 
A.  Iron bars of at least one-half inch round or one-inch by one-fourth inch flat steel material under the skylight and securely fastened; or 
B.  A steel grill of at least one-eighth inch material of two-inch mesh under the skylight and securely fastened. 
(2)  Hatchway openings shall be secured as follows: 
A.  If the hatchway is of wooden material, it shall be covered on the inside with at least 16-gauge sheet steel attached with screws. 
B.  The hatchway shall be secured from the inside with a slide bar or slide bolts. The use of a crossbar or padlock is unauthorized unless approved by the chief of the fire department. 
C.  Outside hinges on all hatchway openings shall be provided with nonremovable pins. Such hinge pins may be either welded, flanged or secured by a screw. 
(3)  Air duct or air vent openings exceeding eight inches by twelve inches shall be secured by covering the same with either of the following: 
A.  Iron bars of at least one-half inch round or one-inch by one-fourth inch flat steel material spaced no more than five inches apart and securely fastened; or 
B.  A steel grill of at least one-eighth inch material of two-inch mesh and securely fastened. If the barrier is on the outside it shall be secured with rounded head flush bolts on the outside. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-81) 
721.06 - SECURITY MEASURES; INTRUSION-DETECTION DEVICES. 
    If it is determined by the chief of police that the security measures and locking devices prescribed in section 721.05 do not adequately secure the building, he may require the installation and maintenance of photoelectric, ultrasonic or other intrusion-detection devices. In making such determination, he shall consider whether: 
(a)  The business establishment has experienced a high incidence of burglary in the past; or 
(b)  The type of merchandise and its inventory value require added security protection. 
    If he determines that such installation is required, notice in writing shall be given to the responsible person designated in section 721.03 specifying the installation to be made and the period of time within which such installation shall be completed. Unless an appeal is filed in accordance with section 721.07, failure to comply with such notice within the time specified shall be a violation of this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-82) 
721.07 - APPEAL FROM INTRUSION-DETECTION DEVICE REQUIREMENTS. 
    Within ten days after receipt of written notice from the chief of police requiring the installation and maintenance of photoelectric, ultrasonic or other instrusion-detection devices, the person responsible for compliance therewith may appeal in writing to the mayor. In filing the appeal, the appellant shall set forth the specific grounds wherein it is claimed there was an error or abuse of discretion by the chief of police or wherein the issuance of such written notice was not supported by proper evidence. Upon receipt of such appeal, the mayor shall, in his discretion, hear both sides of the contested issue and any evidence of the dispute. The mayor may then affirm, reverse or modify the decision of the chief of police. If such decision is affirmed or modified by the mayor, the appellant shall be given written notice thereof by the chief of police setting forth the installation to be made and the period of time within which the same shall be completed. In no event shall the period be less than that originally granted the appellant. Failure to comply with such notice within the time specified shall be a violation of this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-83) 
721.99 - PENALTY. 
    Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this article shall be fined not more than $500 or be imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-84) 
ARTICLE 725 - OIL AND GAS WELLS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Business and occupation tax, § 765.03. 
State Law reference- Oil and gas, W. Va. Code, Ch. 22B. 

725.01 - PERMIT REQUIRED FOR DRILLING OR SHOOTING. 
    No person shall drill any well for oil or gas, shoot or torpedo any well or use any explosives in connection with the drilling or operation of any well within the city without first obtaining the permission of council, as provided by this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 24-1) 
725.02 - FILING OF APPLICATION; FEE; CONTENTS OF APPLICATION. 
    Any person desiring to obtain permission to drill for oil or gas shall, before actual drilling is begun, file a written application, accompanied by a filing and inspection fee of $100 with the director of the division of finance at least ten days before the application shall be acted upon by council. Such application shall state the following: 
(a)  The name of the applicant, the person for whom the well is to be drilled, the name of the driller of the well, the owner of the land upon which the well is to be drilled and the name of the lessee, if any. 
(b)  The location of the well and its proximity to any street, alley, dwelling house or other building, as shown upon a blueprint attached to the application. 
(c)  The names of all the owners of property within a radius of 300 feet of the well location, as shown on the blueprint. 
(d)  The nature and character of the machinery and equipment to be used in the drilling of the well. 
(e)  The streets and alleys, if any, necessary to be crossed, traversed or used in laying pipelines for transporting and marketing the oil or gas. 
(f)  Any additional information that the director of public works may require. 
(1964 Code Sec. 24-2) 
725.03 - REFERENCE TO COMMITTEE OF APPLICATION TO DRILL WELL; REPORT OF FINDINGS. 
    Upon the filing of the application provided for in section 725.02, it shall be immediately referred to a committee composed of the director of public works, the chief of the fire department and the health officer, who shall make a complete and thorough investigation and report their findings to council. 
(1964 Code Sec. 24-3) 
725.04 - SEPARATE APPLICATION REQUIRED FOR PERMIT TO SHOOT WELL; CONTENTS; INVESTIGATION. 
    Any person desiring to torpedo or shoot any oil or gas well, or use explosives of any kind or character in connection with the drilling or operation of such well, shall first make a separate application to council for permission to so use such explosives. The application shall set forth the kind, character and amount of the explosives, the location where the same is to be used, the date and time that the explosives are to be used and the name of the person using the same. Council, upon receiving the application, shall forthwith determine whether the torpedoing or shooting of the well or the use of explosives, set out in the application, will be safe to persons or property, and may grant the applicant a permit to use explosives as requested in the application. 
    All explosives used pursuant to such permit shall be under the direct supervision of the chief of the fire department. 
(1964 Code Sec. 24-4) 
725.05 - CONSIDERATION BY COUNCIL. 
    Council, in acting upon an application for the drilling, shooting or torpedoing of any well within the city, shall, before the permit is granted, take into consideration the location of the well, the probable danger of drilling in such location, the danger to inhabitants and property nearby and the use of explosives in and around the well and may, in its discretion, reject the permit for the drilling or shooting of such well if the same would probably become a menace to the safety and health of the inhabitants and property in the vicinity of the operation. 
(1964 Code Sec. 24-5) 
725.06 - BOND. 
    No permit to drill, shoot or torpedo any oil or gas well shall be issued until the applicant has filed with council a bond in a sum deemed sufficient by council, with the surety thereon from an approved surety company licensed to do business in the city, which bond shall be conditioned that the applicant and surety thereon shall save harmless the city and any and all persons from damage of every kind and character occasioned by the drilling or shooting of the well or the use of explosives in connection therewith. 
(1964 Code Sec. 24-6) 
725.99 - PENALTY. 
Editor's note- See section 101.99 for general Codified Ordinances penalty. 
ARTICLE 726 - BUSINESS REGISTRATION 

726.01 - BUSINESS REGISTRATION REQUIRED. 
(a)  No person, corporation, partnership or firm engaging in business shall engage in that business within the city without first registering with the finance director of the city and providing the following information: 
(1)  The name, business address and mailing address of the company, individual, partnership or firm; 
(2)  The telephone number of the company or individual; 
(3)  The type of business in which such person is engaged; 
(4)  Such other information as the finance director may require; and 
(5)  The name and position of the person providing the information. 
(b)  The provisions of section 101.99 of the Administrative Code providing a fine and imprisonment for violations of ordinances shall be applicable to any violations hereof. 
(c)  A renewal registration shall be required as of July 1 of each year beginning with the year next succeeding the date of initial registration by a business enterprise. 
(Ord. 4-27-87) 
726.02 - PAST DUE B&O TAXES. 
(a)  Current and/or full payment of any previous B & O tax owed is a condition precedent to the issuance of a business renewal license. 
(b)  The finance director shall have the authority to enter into an agreement with any individual, corporation, partnership, or firm engaging in business within the City of Huntington to remedy past due B & O taxes and issue upon said agreement a business license. If such monthly payments become delinquent for a period of 60 days, such license may be automatically revoked. Interest on the outstanding B & O taxes shall be in accordance with article 787 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 3-25-02; Ord. of 11-12-13(1)) 
726.03 - DEFINITIONS OF OCCURRENCE AND FINES. 
(a)  Any business operating without a valid business registration shall be subject to a fine of up to $500 per occurrence. 
(b)  Operating at any time during a specified date shall be considered an occurrence and as such operating on different dates shall be considered separate offenses. 
(Ord. 3-25-02) 
726.99 - PENALTY. 
Editor's note- See section 101.99 for general Codified Ordinances penalty. 
ARTICLE 727 - RUMMAGE SALES 

727.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
(a)  "Occupant" or "occupants" means any person or persons living or residing in a specific residence. The owner of a residence shall be considered its occupant if such residence is vacant. 
(b)  "Residence" means any building or structure used or designed to be used as a place for normal living activities. 
(c)  "Residential area" means any area within the corporate limits of the city that is zoned R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4 or R-5. 
(d)  "Rummage sale" means any sale of household goods, junk, clothing or similar matter held outdoors or partially outdoors on a noncommercial premises. 
(Ord. 10-13-87) 
727.02 - RUMMAGE SALES PROHIBITED. 
    Subject to the provisions of section 727.03, rummage sales are hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. 10-13-87) 
727.03 - EXCEPTIONS; PERMIT REQUIRED. 
    Any occupant may apply for a permit to hold a rummage sale in his or her residence in a residential area. The application for the rummage sale shall be submitted on a form provided by the office of the mayor. If the application is found not to be contrary to the public interest, the mayor or his designee shall provide the applicant with a permit. The permit shall not be denied without good cause. 
    The permit shall state with particularity the location and duration of the sale. A permit may be denied if the mayor determines that a sale in a particular area would be a public nuisance or would impede traffic flow on any street. 
    Under no circumstances shall a rummage sale held within the city limits extend for more than 48 consecutive hours. No more than one sale shall be allowed at any one location during any one calendar month. 
(Ord. 10-13-87) 
727.99 - PENALTY. 
    The occupant of a residence holding an illegal rummage sale shall be fined not more than $150 or imprisoned not more than three days, or both. Each day that a violation continues shall be considered a separate violation. 
(Ord. 10-13-87) 
CHAPTER THREE - TAXATION AND SERVICE CHARGES 
ARTICLE 735 - LICENSE TAX ADMINISTRATION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted May 13, 2013, repealed the former Art. 735, §§ 735.01-735.15, 735.99X, and enacted a new Art. 735 as set out herein. The former Art. 735 pertained to similar subject matter. See Comparative Section Table for complete derivation. 
Charter reference- Taxing powers preserved, § 6.1; finance director to collect taxes, § 9.5. 

735.01 - LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS; PURPOSE. 
    Council hereby finds that in order to provide essential municipal services, city revenue needs require the imposition of the following license tax upon the businesses and commercial ventures listed in this article. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.02 - DEFINITIONS. 
(a)  Except where otherwise defined in this article, businesses, occupations, trades, commercial ventures and terms of art used herein have those meanings given them in the West Virginia Code, as amended and in force on January 1, 1970. 
(b)  Except as otherwise defined in this article, terms, phrases, occupations, trades, commercial ventures and terms of art used in sections of this article other than those referred to in subsection (a) hereof shall have the meaning given to them in the West Virginia Code, as amended and currently in force and, when there is more than one such meaning, they shall have the meaning given in the sections of the West Virginia Code imposing any West Virginia State Tax Department Business Registration Certificate correlative to the city's license tax. 
(c)  "Person" includes, wherever the context will permit, not only natural persons, but all other legal entities such as partnerships, corporations, business trusts and the like. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.03 - PAYMENT AND TERM OF LICENSE. 
    Except as otherwise specified in this article, the entirety of any license tax designated as an annual tax shall be billed on or about June 1 in each year, and shall be paid on or before July of the same year. All annual licenses provided for by this article shall be issued for a term of one year beginning on July 1 and ending on the next succeeding June 30. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.04 - TAX TO CONSTITUTE DEBTS DUE THE CITY. 
    The tax provided for in this article shall constitute debts due to the city and may be collected by the finance director by an appropriate action in either the Circuit Courts or Magistrate Courts of West Virginia, and the penalties imposed by article 735.99 hereof. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.05 - APPLICABILITY; NONTRANSFERABILITY. 
    Except where otherwise expressly provided herein, the tax provided for herein apply to any person undertaking the herein described activities, trades or professions for any part, no matter how small, of a given time period in which the tax is imposed. Except where otherwise expressly provided herein, the licenses provided for in this article are not transferable; that is, the payment by one person of a license tax provided for in this article shall not exempt or excuse a purchaser from, a successor to, or assignee of, any such person for the payment of the prescribed tax for the maintenance or possession of a particular licenses for the conducts of a particular activity. The licenses provided for herein are nontransferable personal privileges. The tax provided for in this article apply only to persons engaging in the specified acts, having the specified ownership, or carrying on the specified operation or conduct of a trade or business where the foregoing are located within the geographic limits of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.06 - IMPOSITION OF ANNUAL MUNICIPAL BUSINESS LICENSE AND TAX THEREON. 
(a)  No person required to obtain a business registration certificate from the West Virginia State Tax Commissioner pursuant to W. Va. Code, § 11-12-1, et seq. shall engage in or prosecute any business activity in the City of Huntington without first obtaining a Huntington Annual Municipal Business License and paying the tax thereon. 
(b)  The Huntington Municipal Business License Tax hereby levied shall be $20 for each Huntington Municipal Business License. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.07 - ACTS PROHIBITED. 
    Whenever a license tax is imposed by this article, no person shall engage in the activity or occupation upon which the tax is levied, without first paying the tax and acquiring the license provided for under this article. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.08 - EFFECT OF LICENSE. 
    In any case in which a license is required by this article, the issuance of the license shall be deemed a prerequisite to the lawful conduct of the activity for which the license is required. Issuance of any license under this article shall not, however, make valid or legal any act not otherwise valid or legal or not otherwise authorized by other provisions of law. Nothing in this article shall authorize any act, activity or ownership not otherwise lawful. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.09 - DUTIES AND POWERS OF FINANCE DIRECTOR. 
(a)  The finance director shall have the power to promulgate such rules, regulations, procedures, applications and forms not inconsistent with the provisions hereof and to administer and issue business licenses, collect taxes and enforce the provisions of this ordinance. The application may contain questions on or blanks for any information reasonably deemed necessary by the finance director. The finance director is expressly authorized to require applicants to have, and to provide evidence of, a valid and existing West Virginia State Tax Department Business Franchise Registration Certificate. Proper completion of an application is a condition precedent to the finance director having any duty to issue a license. Upon proper completion of a license application and payment of the tax, the finance director shall issue the requested license to the applicant. The form of the license and information thereon shall be such as the finance director may reasonably prescribe. The finance director, or his designated agent, shall have the power to examine activities and locations of each business to determine compliance with this article. 
(b)  The finance director shall further have the power to deny the renewal of any license issued hereunder to any person who is delinquent in the payment of business and occupation taxes pursuant to article 787 of the Codified Ordinances. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.10 - CHANGE IN NAME OR PARTNERS. 
    A change in the name under which a person does business shall not require the person to seek any new license for any activity licensed under a prior name; nor shall the withdrawal or addition of partners to a partnership require the partnership to obtain a new license, provided that the partnership always retains at least one partner who was a member of the firm at the time the license was granted. Provided that a written notification of the change in partnership or change in business name be provided to the director of finance. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.11 - APPLICABILITY OF ARTICLE 726. 
    The provisions of article 726 (business registration), where inconsistent with this article or with general law, shall have no applicability to this article or the licenses provided for herein. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.12 - DISPLAY OF CERTIFICATE. 
    The licenses provided for in this article shall be evidenced by license certificates. The holder of a license shall display the license certificate in a prominent place at or near the location of the licensed activity or device, and shall make the license certificate available for inspection by city police, compliance inspector, codes enforcement officer, the finance director or his/her designated agent. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.13 - CONSTRUCTION; SEVERABILITY. 
    The provisions of this article shall be construed so as to make them consistent with state law and consistent with the correlative statutes providing for state licensing tax. If any section or sections of this article shall, even when so construed, be found to be in violation of the laws or constitutions of the State or the United States, or shall be found to be an attempted exercise of power not granted to the city, the resulting invalidity of that section or those sections shall not mean the remaining sections of this article shall not be enforced. It is the intent of council that each license tax imposed herein should be imposed, even if other license taxes provided for herein could not have been imposed. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.14 - FALSE STATEMENTS PROHIBITED. 
    No person shall knowingly make any false statement in any application for a city license provided for in this article, or in any report or other statement relating to any activity licensed by the city and which is required to be made to any city officer or agency. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.15 - PROSECUTION; INJUNCTIONS. 
    If any person engages in or prosecutes any business, activity, trade or employment contrary to any of the provisions of this Code, whether without first obtaining a license therefor or by continuing the same after the termination of the effective period of such license, or by any violation of the terms and conditions of such license, he shall be subject to immediate prosecution in the municipal court and in, addition, the city attorney may, in the name of the city, seek such injunctive relief as may be appropriate in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.16 - EFFECTIVE DATE. 
    The provisions of this article shall be in full force and effect beginning July 1, 2013. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
735.99 - PENALTY. 
(a)  Whoever engages in any activity contrary to the provisions of this article, whether without obtaining a license required therefor before commencing the same or by continuing the same after the termination of the effective period of any such license, may, in addition to paying the license tax, be liable for a penalty of $50 for each month or fraction thereof during which he has been in default of the license tax. It shall be the duty of the director of finance to collect the full amount of the license tax and penalty imposed and he shall not issue any license until the license tax and the penalty have been paid in full. 
(b)  In addition to the foregoing and except as may herein be otherwise expressly provided, whoever violates any provision under this article shall be fined not less than $50 nor more than $500 and each day or part thereof that any violation continues shall be deemed to constitute a distinct and separate offense and be punishable accordingly. 
(c)  Whoever knowingly makes a false statement in any license tax application shall be fined not less than $200 nor more than $500. Each false statement, whether made with or without other false statements on any one application shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2013(8)) 
ARTICLE 739 - GENERAL LICENSE TAXES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted May 13, 2013, amended article 739 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article 739, §§ 739.01-739.25, pertained to similar subject matter. See Comparative Section Table for complete derivation. 
State Law reference- Authority to tax, W. Va. Code, §§ 8-13-4, 11-12-4. 

739.01 - HAWKERS AND PEDDLERS. 
    The annual license fee to act as a hawker or peddler, if the person licensed travels without a motor vehicle, shall be $20; if he travels with a motor vehicle of not more than one-half ton capacity, $20; if he travels with a motor vehicle of not more than one ton capacity, $20; if he travels with a motor vehicle of not more than two tons' capacity, $20; and if he travels with a motor vehicle of more than two tons' capacity, $20, plus $20 for each additional ton or fraction thereof over two tons' capacity. The person licensed shall pay at the same rate for each motor vehicle so used. Such person shall carry his license in some conspicuous place in his vehicle or about his pack; and in addition thereto he shall cause to be painted or stenciled in a conspicuous place on the left-hand side of his vehicle the number of such license and the words "City of Huntington" and the license year for which such license is issued, which information shall be in black letters on a white background, and the whole thereof shall be at least eight by 20 inches in size. 
    When used in this section, "sale" means and includes both sales for money payment or for barter, and offers to make any such sale and offers to render service or the rendering thereof. 
    Any person who shall carry goods, wares or merchandise from place to place, either in person or by agent or employee, and sell, for delivery at the same time, any such goods, wares or merchandise to any purchaser, at wholesale or retail, and any person who shall solicit for the purpose of rendering any service, shall be deemed a hawker or peddler under this section. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
739.02 - HAWKERS AND PEDDLERS; EXEMPT PERSONS. 
    The provisions of section 739.01 shall not apply to any person who sells any goods, wares or merchandise to be delivered in the future or to any of the following who offer immediate delivery of the goods, wares or merchandise being sold: 
(a)  Any person engaged within the city in the business or calling of agriculture, horticulture or grazing, who sells, individually or collectively, one or more for the other, the products derived from his business or calling. 
(b)  Any person engaged in the maintenance or operation of a retail merchandise store to exchange goods, wares or merchandise from such store for agriculture, horticultural or grazing products or to resell any such products received in due course of such business; nor to any other retail business concern, established and operating continuously for one year or more within this city in the sale of any product or products over regular routes. 
(c)  Any wholesaler or jobber selling soft drinks or nonintoxicating beer for which he is duly licensed under other provisions of this chapter three. 
(d)  Any person who sells petroleum products, ice, wood, meat, milk, ice cream, bread, cakes, pies and other bakery products, butter and eggs, manufactured, grown or produced by any such person and not purchased by him for resale. 
(e)  Any sales by societies, groups or organizations acting for charitable, religious or benevolent purposes. 
(f)  Any agent or salesman selling manufactured products, except green groceries and canned or bottled fruit products, produced by his employer, who sells the same to retail dealers for the purpose of resale. Any items sold by said person at retail, or directly to the consumer, shall not be exempt from this section. 
(g)  Any person having a stock of goods or merchandise or a manufacturing or processing plant kept or operating at a fixed situs in the city, and declared for taxation in the city, and using a vehicle over a fixed route for the purpose of selling or distributing, at wholesale, his merchandise, stock of goods or plant products. 
    Any person exempt from license as above provided, shall obtain from the director of the division of finance a license receipt, without cost, showing that he is so exempt, which shall be effective for the period as provided for annual licenses in this chapter three and shall be coextensive with the entire city; but to obtain such license receipt, he shall make an affidavit and produce such other evidence as to the fact entitling him to such exemption as the director, in his discretion, may require, which shall be on a form to be prescribed by the director. 
(h)  Any person selling products other than food or drink from a vehicle, trailer or other form of conveyance, or from any type of stand temporarily located on a public parking space or any part of the public way shall be considered an itinerant vendor under section 739.03 of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7); Ord. of 12-12-16(1) ) 
739.03 - ITINERANT VENDORS; DEFINED. 
    When used in sections 739.04 to 739.07, "itinerant vendor" means and includes all persons who engage in or conduct within this city, either in one locality or in traveling from place to place, a temporary or transient business of selling good, wares and merchandise; and who, for the purpose of carrying on such business, use, lease or occupy, either in whole or in part, a room, building or other structure; or who use, lease or occupy for such purposes a room in any hotel or lodging house, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise; or who lease or occupy any vacant lot, or parking lot to park any motor vehicle or trailer which is used for the exhibition and sale of goods, wares and merchandise. Itinerant vendors shall include any person who sells any product other than food or drink from a vehicle, trailer or other form of conveyance, or from any type of stand temporarily located on a public parking space or any part of the public way. The person so engaged shall not be relieved from the provisions of sections 739.04 to 739.07 by reason of association temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer or by conducting such temporary or transient business in connection with or as part of the business of or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7); Ord. of 12-12-16(1) ) 
739.04 - ITINERANT VENDORS; FEE. 
    The annual license fee to carry on the business of itinerant vendor shall be $500. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
739.05 - STATEMENT REQUIRED. 
    No itinerant vendor shall advertise, represent or hold forth a sale of goods, wares or merchandise as a bankrupt, insolvent, assignee, trustee, estate, executor, administrator, receiver, attorney, manufacturer's wholesale or closing-out or a sale of any goods damaged by smoke, fire, water or otherwise unless before so doing he shall state in writing, under oath, to the director of the division of finance at the time he makes application for a license, provided for by this article, all the facts relating to the reason and character of such special sale as advertised, held forth or represented, including a statement of the names of the persons from whom such goods, wares or merchandise were purchased, and the date of the delivery of the same to the person applying for license; the place, if any, where such goods, wares or merchandise were previously exposed for sale; and such details as are necessary to exactly locate and fully identify all such goods, wares and merchandise proposed to be sold. Such itinerant vendor shall also include in such statement the name and residence of the owner in whose interest the business is conducted, to be kept on file in the office of the director. A record shall be kept by the director of all such statements, in convenient form and open to public inspection. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
739.06 - BOND. 
    Every itinerant vendor shall execute a continuing bond in the form prescribed by the director of the division of finance with satisfactory corporate surety in the penalty of $5,000 payable to the city, conditioned that such itinerant vendor will pay all damages accruing to anyone by reason of any act or action done, performed or taken by such itinerant vendor in or about the conduct of his business and further conditioned that such itinerant vendor will pay all taxes, fees and penalties imposed by this city; provided, that the aggregate liability of the surety for all such damages, taxes, fees and penalties shall in no event exceed the sum of such bond. Such bond shall be filed with the director and shall be open to inspection during business hours to any person desiring to inspect the same. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
739.07 - PROHIBITED ACTS OF ITINERANT VENDORS. 
    No itinerant vendor shall sell or exhibit for sale at public or private sale, any goods, wares or merchandise without first obtaining a license therefor and in all other respects complying with the provisions of this Chapter Three, make any false statement in reference to the matter set out in section 739.05, or fail to comply with the requirements of any of the sections of this chapter, and no person, whether principal or agent, shall by circular, handbill, newspaper or in any manner advertise such sale, as described in section 739.05, before proper licenses are issued to the vendor and before he has complied with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
739.08 - APPLICABILITY TO CERTAIN PERSONS. 
    The provisions of sections 739.03 to 739.07 shall not apply to sales made to persons by commercial travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business, nor to sales made at trade shows or trade conventions, nor to sales by hawkers or peddlers in the streets, roads or highways from packs or vehicles, to arts and crafts shows and the like, to flea markets conducted at a regular established location at which the owner holds a store license, nor to persons selling meat or the products of the farm, garden or dairy, nor to sales of goods, wares or merchandise on the grounds of any agricultural association during the continuance of any annual fair held by such association, not to any sales by societies acting for charitable, religious or benevolent purposes, nor to judicial sales directed by law or under the orders of any court, nor to the sales of the common necessities of life in any public marketplace. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
739.09 - PAWN BROKERS AND SECOND HAND DEALERS. 
(a)  The annual license fee to engage in the business of pawnbroker or secondhand dealers (i.e., flea markets, antique and consignment store) shall be $20 and said license shall be conspicuously displayed. 
(b)  "Pawnbroker" includes any person engaged in the business of lending money on deposit or pledge of personal property or other valuable thing, other than securities or printed evidence of indebtedness, or in the business of purchasing personal property such as articles made of or containing gold, silver, platinum or other precious metal or precious or semi-precious stones whether real or faux or other valuable thing for the purpose of either reworking the same or providing them for resale either in their original form or in a different form from their construction when purchased. 
(c)  "Secondhand dealer" shall include any flea market, consignment shop, or individual who sells items when not purchased directly by the seller from either a licensed retail establishment or from a licensed wholesale supplier. 
(d)  Any law enforcement officer may issue a citation to any proprietor and/or any employee of said pawnbroker or secondhand dealer engaging in the secondhand sale or pawnbroking or secondhand sale activities without a license. Fines shall be not less than $25 nor greater than $100 for the first offense. The second offense shall not be less than $100 nor greater than $250 and the third offense may include a fine not less than $250 nor greater than $500 and/or up to 30 days in jail. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
739.10 - DAILY REPORT TO POLICE BY PAWNBROKERS AND SECONDHAND DEALERS. 
    Any person doing business as a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer in clothing, bicycles, jewelry or other personal property, including dealers in old gold, silver or platinum, shall, every day before the hour of 12:00 noon, prepare and deliver to the chief of police of the city, a legible and correct copy of the description of all such personal property of any kind or description received, pledged or purchased during the preceding day, together with the hour when the property was received and a description of the person by whom the same was left, pledged or from whom the same was purchased. Such information shall be recorded on a pawn card, forms for which shall be available at the police department and each pawn card shall contain only one item. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
739.11 - PRIVATE CLUBS. 
(a)  The annual license fee for any private club, as defined, regulated and licensed by the state under W. Va. Code, Art. 60-7, shall be as follows: 
(1)  For a license issued to a fraternal or veterans' organization or a nonprofit social club - $375. 
(2)  For a license issued to a private club other than a private club of the type specified in subsection (a)(1) hereof - $500 if such private club has less than 1,000 members and $1,250 if such private club has 1,000 or more members. 
(3)  The fee for any such license issued following January 1 of any year and to expire on June 30 of such year shall be one-half of the annual license fee prescribed by subsection (a)(1) and (2) hereof. 
(4)  All such fees shall be paid to the director of the division of finance and shall be credited to the general revenue of the city. 
(b)  In the event the license fees authorized to be charged by the city under the provisions of W. Va. Code, Art. 60-7 are modified after the fiscal year commencing July 1, 1972, the annual municipal license fee for such private clubs shall be the maximum amount authorized thereunder for each of the various categories prescribed by state law. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
739.12 - STREET ARTISTS. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  "Perform" includes, but is not limited to the following activities: acting, singing, playing musical instruments, pantomime, juggling, magic, dancing and reciting. This shall not include performances by participants in any parade. 
(2)  "Performer" means an individual who owns a permit pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(3)  "Public areas" includes all public access areas within the city. This includes all parks, sidewalks, temporarily closed streets, plazas and all other public ways. Public areas shall not include privately owned property that is generally accessible to the public. 
(b)  License requirement. 
(1)  Upon application and the payment of a license fee of $20, the mayor or his designee may issue a license to an individual for performances in public places. 
(2)  A completed application for a license shall contain the applicant's name, address and telephone number and such other information as may be required. 
(3)  A license shall contain the name and license number of the applicant plus the period for which the license is valid. A license shall be issued for any period up to one year in the discretion of the finance director or his designee. 
(c)  Display of license. A performer shall carry the license on his or her person at all times that he or she is performing. The performer shall make available the permit upon request from any police officer. 
(d)  Permitted performances. 
(1)  Performances shall be limited to areas designated in rules and regulations issued by the mayor. Such rules and regulations shall also contain the time periods during the day in which performances may take place. 
(2)  Performers are prohibited from blocking the passage of the public through a public area. 
(e)  Legal conduct. 
(1)  A performer may accept contribution of money or property at a performance. Contributions may be received in any receptacle. 
(2)  A performer who performs under the provisions of this section shall not be guilty of disorderly conduct, loitering or disturbing the peace. 
(f)  Violations. 
(1)  Violations of any of the provisions of this section may result in revocation of the license. 
(2)  Any person performing without a license shall be guilty of a violation of this section and shall be fined not more than $100. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
739.13 - RETAIL LIQUOR LICENSE FEE. 
(a)  Pursuant to the provisions of W. Va. Code, §§ 60-3A-12(e) and 8-13-4 respectively, on and after January 1, 2000 any person, firm or corporation desiring to conduct retail sales of liquor within the corporate limits of the City of Huntington, West Virginia shall, after first being licensed by the State of West Virginia shall, after first being licensed by the State of West Virginia pursuant to the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 60-3A-I et seq., thereafter file as an applicant for retail liquor Director of Finance of the City of Huntington. 
(b)  The annual retail liquor license period shall be from the first day of July to the 30th day of June of the following year. The annual municipal retail liquor license fee if an applicant holds a Class A retail license under the state law shall be the sum of $1,000 per outlet. The annual municipal retail liquor license fee if an applicant holds a Class B retail license shall be $1,000 per outlet. Provided that the initial license period for retail liquor licenses issued pursuant to this section shall be from January 1, 2000 to June 30, 2000. The fee for this initial license period will be prorated to 50% of the regular annual license fee prescribed herein. 
(c)  A retail liquor license shall expire on the 30th day of June of each year and may be renewed only upon the submission of an application and payment of the required annual fee to the Director of Finance of the City of Huntington, West Virginia on or before July 1 of each year, on such forms as the director of finance may prescribe. 
(d)  No person may sell liquor at any retail outlet within the city if the state retail liquor license applicable to such outlet has been suspended or revoked or has expired. 
(e)  All retail liquor licenses issued under the provisions of this ordinance shall expire and be of no further force or effect as of the first day of July, the year after they are issued, unless renewed from year to year, as hereinbefore provided. 
(f)  Violations of the provisions of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to $500. 
(Ord. of 5-13-13(7)) 
ARTICLE 747 - REAL ESTATE BROKERS AND SALESMEN[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Real estate brokers and salesmen, W. Va. Code, Art. 47-12. 

747.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
    Unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different intention, the following terms shall, for the purposes of this article, have the meanings indicated in this section: 
(a)  "Real estate broker" means a person who, for compensation or consideration, sells, buys, negotiates the purchase or sells, exchanges, leases, rents or manages any real estate or any improvement on real estate, or who offers, advertises or holds himself out to do any of such things for another or others. 
(b)  "Real estate business" means the performing or attempting to perform or the holding out to perform any of the things usually done by a real estate broker or a real estate salesman as hereinafter defined. 
(c)  "Real estate salesman" means any person who, for compensation or consideration, is employed either directly or indirectly by a real estate broker to engage in the real estate business or to do any of the things set out herein in the definition of the term "real estate broker." 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-55) 
747.02 - BROKER'S AND SALESMAN'S LICENSE REQUIRED. 
    No person shall act as a real estate broker or as a real estate salesman or shall engage in the real estate business without a license as provided for by this article. No license shall be issued to a real estate broker unless every employee who acts for such broker as a salesman secures a license as a real estate salesman. However, if such broker is a partnership, association or corporation, then every bona fide member of such partnership or association and every officer of such corporation shall be licensed as a real estate salesman when and after such broker shall have been granted a broker's license. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-56) 
747.03 - ISSUANCE, SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF LICENSES. 
    Licenses, as provided in this article, shall be issued by the director of the division of finance in such form as council may determine to applicants who are found to be of good character and to be competent to carry on the business for which the license is bought. 
    Council may investigate the actions of any real estate broker or real estate salesman or any person who shall assume to act in either capacity, in the city, and shall have the power to suspend or revoke any license issued by the director that has been fraudulently procured, or when the licensee, in the course of his licensed business, has done or is doing any one or more of the following things: 
(a)  Made any substantial misrepresentations; 
(b)  Made any false representation of a character likely to influence, persuade or induce; 
(c)  Pursued a continued and flagrant course of misrepresentation, or made false representations through agents or salesmen or advertising or otherwise; 
(d)  Acted for more than one party in a transaction without the knowledge of all parties for whom he acts; 
(e)  Accepted a commission or valuable consideration as a real estate salesman for the performance of any of the acts specified in this article, from any person, except his employer, who must be a licensed real estate broker; 
(f)  Represented or attempted to represent a real estate broker other than the employer, without the express knowledge and consent of the employer; 
(g)  Failed, within a reasonable time, to account for or to remit any money coming into his possession which belongs to others; 
(h)  Been unworthy or incompetent to act as a real estate broker or salesman in such manner as to safeguard the interest of the public; 
(i)  Paid a commission or valuable consideration to any person for acts or service performed in violation of this article; 
(j)  Conducted himself in any manner constituting improper, fraudulent or dishonest dealing. 
    The revocation of a broker's license shall automatically suspend every real estate salesman's license granted to any person by virtue of his employment by the broker whose license has been revoked, pending a charge of employers and the issuance of a new license. Such new license shall be issued without charge, if granted during the same year in which the original license was granted. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-57) 
747.04 - LICENSE FEES. 
    The original fee and annual renewal fee for each real estate broker's license shall be $25. 
    The original fee and annual renewal fee for each real estate salesman's license shall be $10. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-58) 
747.05 - EXPIRATION AND RENEWAL OF LICENSE. 
    The fiscal year shall constitute the license year under this article. All licenses under this article shall expire at midnight on June 30 of each year. The director of the division of finance shall issue a new license for each ensuing year, in the absence of any reason which might warrant the refusal of the granting of a license upon the receipt of the annual fee therefor, as herein required. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-59) 
747.99 - PENALTY. 
    Any person who shall engage in the real estate business in the city, without a license as provided in this article, or who shall violate any provision of this article, shall, in addition to any other penalty imposed for the violation of this article, be liable for the payment of the license tax, together with a penalty of 10% of such license tax for each month or part thereof during which he has been in default, which penalty shall be assessed and collected in the same manner as the license tax. Such license tax and penalty may be collected by action or suit in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-60) 
ARTICLE 748 - INDOOR SHOOTING RANGE 

748.01 - DEFINITION. 
    The definition of an "Indoor Shooting Range" may be found in section 1315.02. 
( Ord. of 2-22-16(2) ) 
748.02 - LICENSE REQUIRED. 
    No person shall engage in the operation of an indoor shooting range in the city unless such person has obtained an annual indoor shooting range license from the city. The fee shall be $90 annually. 
( Ord. of 2-22-16(2) ) 
748.03 - CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATING STANDARDS FOR INDOOR SHOOTING RANGE LICENSE. 
(a)  Any person wishing to obtain a license to establish an indoor shooting range, in addition to general license requirements, must first establish an indoor range which meets or exceeds safety regulations, including safety precautions and proper ventilation, set up by the National Rifle Association and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration current as of the date the building permit was issued and show approved liability insurance of a minimum of $1,000,000 coverage. 
(b)  All indoor shooting ranges shall comply with all local, state, and/or federal regulations related to indoor shooting ranges. 
(c)  Application for a business license shall be made and may be approved only after a certificate of occupancy has been obtained. 
(d)  No person under the age of 18 years shall be permitted to enter a range unless accompanied by an adult. 
(e)  It shall be the responsibility of the licensee or instructor to brief patrons concerning the rules and regulations in the range before they are permitted to use the firing range. The licensee shall keep posted in a conspicuous place inside the building and outside the building a sign stating the rules and regulations of the range. 
(f)  Adherence to all requirements of sections 545.14 and 1341.52 shall be maintained at all times in addition to the requirements herein. 
( Ord. of 2-22-16(2) ) 
748.99 - PENALTY. 
    Every person charged with violating any provision of this article shall be fined not more than $500 or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both. Each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
( Ord. of 2-22-16(2) ) 
ARTICLE 751 - JUNK DEALERS AND YARDS[9] 
GENERALLY 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Salvage yards, W. Va. Code, Art. 17-23; receiving stolen goods, W. Va. Code, § 61-3-18. 

751.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
(a)  "Fence" means an enclosure at least six feet in height, constructed and maintained so as to obscure the junk in such enclosure from ordinary view to those persons passing upon the streets, sidewalks or avenues within the city. 
(b)  "Itinerant junk collector" includes only such persons who gather junk from place to place with the aid of a cart or vehicle hand-drawn or propelled, who have no fixed place of business. 
(c)  "Junk" means used or salvaged base metal or metals and their compounds or combinations, used or salvaged, rope, bags, paper, rags, batteries, glass, rubber, lumber, millwork, brick and similar property; dismantled plumbing fixtures, including, but not limited to, bathtubs, commodes, tanks, septic tanks, hot water tanks and other similar items; used or dismantled kitchen equipment, including, but not limited to, refrigerators, ranges, cabinets and similar items; used motor vehicles, bodies, chassis and other parts thereof; and any other machinery or equipment used, owned or possessed for the purpose of wrecking or salvaging parts therefrom. 
(d)  "Junk dealer" means any person engaged in the business of buying or selling junk. 
(e)  "Junk dealer's agent" means any person who buys or sells junk for or on behalf of a junk dealer, but such term shall not be construed to include any persons regularly employed upon a salary by a regularly licensed junk dealer engaged in such business within the city. 
(f)  "Junkyard" means an establishment or place of business which is maintained or operated for the purpose of storing, keeping, buying, selling, salvaging, dismantling or reducing junk. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-61) 
JUNK DEALERS 
751.02 - LICENSE REQUIRED; RESIDENT LICENSE NOT ISSUED TO CERTAIN PERSONS. 
    No person within the city shall engage in the business of junk dealer, junk dealer's agent or itinerant junk collector without a city license therefor, which license shall be issued as provided in sections 751.02 to 751.10 provided, that no resident license shall be issued to any junk dealer, junk dealer's agent or itinerant junk collector who has not been a resident of the city for a period of at least one year prior to the application of such license. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-62) 
751.03 - LICENSE FEES; SPECIAL REGULATIONS AS TO NONRESIDENTS AND ITINERANTS. 
    The annual license fee to act as a resident junk dealer shall be $20; to act as a junk dealer's agent, $20; to act as a nonresident junk dealer or his agent who buys or solicits for the purchase of junk within the city, $20; to act as an itinerant junk collector, $20. Such licenses shall be coextensive with the city, but no nonresident licensee shall be permitted to maintain a fixed place of business within the city; provided, that any nonresident junk dealer may purchase junk from any resident junk dealer without complying with the provisions of sections 751.02 to 751.10, but if such nonresident junk dealer comes into the city in any motor vehicle or horse-drawn vehicle, such nonresident junk dealer shall not be permitted to transport from the city in such vehicle or horse-drawn wagon, junk purchased from resident junk dealers, unless there is a compliance with this sections 751.02 to 751.10. 
(1964 Code Sec. 20-63; Ord. of 5-13-13(2)) 
751.04 - PREREQUISITES TO LICENSE ISSUANCE.
