    Any new or existing business that locates or relocates at Kinetic Park and satisfies the requirements as a qualifying business pursuant to section 788.02 of this article, shall be granted a partial exemption on their retail sales or services from the business and occupation tax set forth in this article. 
(a)  Tax credits granted under this subsection shall be granted to new or relocating businesses solely on their retail sales as follows: 
(1)  Seventy-five percent of the amount of tax computed under the provisions of this article during the first full year, or portion thereof, of the new or relocating business' operations. 
(2)  Fifty percent of the amount of tax computed under the provisions of this article during the second full year, or portion thereof, of the new or relocating business' operations. 
(3)  Twenty-five percent of the amount of tax computed under the provisions of this article during the third full year, or portion thereof, of the new or relocating business' operations. 
(4)  Twenty-five percent of the amount of tax computed under the provisions of this article during the fourth full year, or portion thereof, of the new or relocating business' operations. 
(5)  Twenty-five percent of the amount of tax computed under the provisions of this article during the fifth full year, or portion thereof, of the new or relocating business' operations. 
(6)  There shall be no further tax credits under this section for the sixth full year, or portion thereof, and for each successive year thereafter, of the new or relocating business' operations. 
(Ord. 6-14-04.) 
788.07 - ADDITIONAL TAX ABATEMENT. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of section 788.06 of this article, any prospective business locating within Kinetic Park who invests $10,000,000 or more in new real estate and structure, equipment and corporate property, and who has a minimum of 150 employees and increased their employment by 20% shall be entitled to a 50% reduction of the amount computed under the provisions of this article during the first full year or portion thereof, of the new or relocating business operations and for 19 successive years thereafter. 
(Ord. 6-14-04) 
788.08 - OTHER DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES. 
(a)  In addition to, or in lieu of, tax abatements, the city will consider on a case-by-case basis other financial/development incentives. Such incentives include but are not limited to: 
(1)  Waiving of building permit fees, in whole or in part. 
(2)  In-kind services such as infrastructure improvements by the city related to the development project, for example, road widening, storm drainage improvements and sidewalk construction. 
(3)  Extension of water and/or sanitary sewer lines; waiving of hookup charges. 
(4)  Direct grants to the applicant for infrastructure improvements. 
(b)  Any and all decisions to grant an incentive, pursuant to the terms of this section, shall be granted by the Mayor of the City of Huntington and/or his designee subject to approval of the city council by resolution. 
(Ord. 6-14-04) 
ARTICLE 790 - TAX AND FEE APPEAL BOARDS 

790.01 - APPEAL BOARD. 
    The appeal board shall sit under the authority of section 773.08 entitled Municipal Service Fee Board and section 772.08 entitled city service fee appeal board. 
(Ord. 3-24-03) 
790.2 - PROTEST AND APPEAL. 
    Any user who feels aggrieved by any charge to his municipal service fee account, refuse service fee account or city service fee account may protest the same by filing written notice of such protest with the director of the division of finance, setting forth his objections thereto and the reasons therefor, on or before the due date of his next quarterly installment payment. The director shall review such citizen's account, render a decision on the protest and forthwith notify the user of such decision in writing within 15 days of the filing of the protest. If the user is still aggrieved, he may, within 15 days of the date of the director's decision, petition the appeal board which shall set a date and time for hearing on the protest, which hearing shall be held within 30 days from the filing of such appeal. 
    The appeal board shall hear evidence relevant to the protest and shall render its decision on the issues raised at such hearing within 20 days after the hearing, giving notice of its decision in writing to the user and to the director. The user may, within 30 days from the date of the decision of the appeal board, file a petition, duly verified, with a court of competent jurisdiction, requesting a review of the board's decision. If no such petition is filed within 30 days, the decision of the appeal board shall become final and conclusive. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the accrual during the course of the appeal process of any penalty upon the balance of any account ultimately found to be properly charged. A user's appeal shall not be deemed to be upheld if the city or board fails to meet a deadline contained herein. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
790.03 - MEMBERS. 
    The board shall consist of five members: three members chosen by the mayor and two chosen by city council. The terms of the board members shall be for a period of two years. Once a member's term is ended, the individual shall not be considered a member of the board unless reappointed and shall not be eligible to vote upon any issue before the board. Members may serve additional terms in accordance with the provisions of state law and the Charter of the City of Huntington. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
PART NINE - STREETS, UTILITIES AND PUBLIC SERVICES CODE 
CHAPTER ONE - STREET AND SIDEWALK AREAS 
ARTICLE 905 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Street obstructions, § 311.01. 
State Law reference- General power to regulate, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-5(1); special charges for street cleaning, etc., W. Va. Code, § 8-13-13; connection to state road system, W. Va. Code, § 17-4-26 et seq.; action for damages occasioned by defective streets, etc., W. Va. Code, § 17-10-17. 

905.01 - PERMITS TO PLACE BUILDING MATERIAL IN STREETS. 
    Any person desiring to place any building material in any of the streets, sidewalks or alleys of the city for the purpose of erecting a building or repairing the same shall make an application in writing to the director of public works, setting forth what part of the street, alley or sidewalk is to be used, and for what purpose and how long. If the director finds that the application is reasonable, and that the use is proper under the circumstances, a written permit shall be given by the director to the applicant to use the street, alley or sidewalk, or adjacent thereto as set out in the written permit, in the manner and for the period therein prescribed. Such written permit shall not be of any effect or force until the applicant signs a contract agreeing to make the street, alley or sidewalk so used in as good a condition as it was before, and to erect, at the applicant's expense, barriers by day and lights and barriers by night, to prevent injuries to the public while such obstruction is in the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city, and agreeing to indemnify the city for all damages that anyone injured by reason of such use made by the applicant may recover against the city. 
    The director shall cause all such applications to be numbered and filed and a record kept of every such permit granted, numbered to agree with the application; and the contract shall be numbered to agree with the application and consent, and shall be filed. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-1) 
905.02 - DUTIES OF OFFICERS SEEING BUILDING MATERIAL IN STREETS. 
    The director of public works or any police officer seeing anyone placing any building material in any street, alley or sidewalk shall immediately ascertain whether the person has the authority to do so. The person so placing building material in the street, alley or sidewalk shall show his authority for so doing to the director or the police officer when demanded. All persons without authority for so using the streets shall be stopped by the director or any police officer. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-2) 
905.03 - PLACING BUILDING MATERIAL SO AS TO INTERFERE WITH ONE-WAY TRAFFIC. 
    Nothing contained in these Codified Ordinances shall be construed to permit any person to place any building or other material in any street or alley of the city in such a manner as to interfere with or prevent one-way vehicular traffic. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-3) 
905.04 - REMOVAL OF DEBRIS BY BUILDING CONTRACTOR. 
    Within ten days after the roof is placed upon any building, the contractor or builder thereof shall cause the removal of all dirt, rubbish or material remaining upon any street, avenue, alley or public place caused by or belonging to any bricklayer or stonemason; and within ten days after the completion of any building, the contractor or builder shall cause the removal of all other dirt, rubbish or material caused by or belonging to any other mechanic or person who may have been engaged in the construction of such building. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-4) 
905.05 - PERMIT FOR STORING CONSTRUCTION MACHINERY ON STREET. 
    Machinery used in connection with the construction of buildings shall not be stored or placed on any street, sidewalk or parkway if there is room therefor upon the lot on which the building is being erected, or upon any adjoining lot belonging to the same owner, without a permit from the director of public works. No person shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with this section. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-5) 
905.06 - PLACEMENT OF GOODS AND MERCHANDISE UPON SIDEWALKS, STREETS AND ALLEYS. 
    No person shall place upon the city sidewalks, streets or alleys, any goods or merchandise for the purpose of exposing them for sale, or for the purpose of advertising or attracting the attention of the general public. 
    Provided, however, that all property owners or their lessees shall have the right to place their goods and merchandise, which shall mean all things commonly sold in retail business establishments, immediately in front of their respective businesses after complying with the provisions of this section. Provided, however, that in no case may a merchant's display occupy more than 50% in length of the total front footage of his respective business. Provided further, that no display shall operate to disrupt the free flow of pedestrian traffic; block designated sidewalks as designated by the director of public works; or cause congestion of designated fire lanes as designated by the city's fire chief. 
    All property owners or their lessees who desire to make displays of their goods and merchandise in front of their businesses shall first secure a permit from the mayor and furnish evidence of insurance coverage by submitting a certificate of insurance naming the city as an additional insured party with a minimum of $100,000 property damage/$300,000 bodily injury; however, the city reserves the right to require greater insurance coverage depending upon the type of display offered. In no case may the mayor issue a permit until such is approved by a majority of the sidewalk display review board. There shall be no fee charged for permits to merchants displaying in front of their own businesses. 
    There shall be a sidewalk display review board consisting of a council member, a downtown merchant and a business person, all of whom shall be city residents and who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of council for a term of three years. This board shall have the authority to: 
(a)  Deny or revoke permits to merchants whose proposed or current displays impede pedestrian traffic, block designated sidewalks and fire lanes or do not supply adequate insurance coverage; 
(b)  Approve permits for special events lasting no longer than five days; 
(c)  Approve permits to merchants whose displays will not be in front of their own businesses; and 
(d)  Establish written rules and regulations to carry out the purposes of this section, all of which must first be approved by council. 
    Permits shall also be issued to special events groups and to merchants whose displays will not be in front of their own businesses, provided that the board shall approve such permit and adequate insurance coverage is provided naming the city as an additional insured. There shall be no fee charged for permits to special events groups. There shall be a $50 permit fee per year for merchants whose displays will not be in front of their own businesses. 
    The city reserves the right to determine the exact location of any display permitted; and the right to determine the exact number of permits issued to special events groups. All merchants shall have the right to file written objections with the board objecting to any display within the immediate vicinity of their businesses, which objections shall thereafter be acted upon by the board. 
    Provided further, that no penalty shall be imposed upon any person in the immediate act of moving or removing merchandise or any other commodity in the way of his trade or business or for the use of his family, if the same shall not at any time be so placed as to obstruct free passage along and over any street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Ord. 2-28-84) 
905.07 - DISTURBING BARRIERS ON CLOSED STREETS. 
    When any street or alley in the city has been closed for the purpose of constructing, repairing, paving, sewering or otherwise improving it no unauthorized person shall take down or disturb any barriers that may have been erected on any such streets or alleys. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-7) 
905.08 - LANTERNS AND GUARDS FOR VAULT AND CELLAR OPENINGS. 
    The owner or occupant of any house or lot before which any vault or opening for cellar doors, areas or steps is being constructed shall fence off the pavement on the right and left, and the street in front of the construction, and, during the whole of every night while such vault or opening is not securely covered, shall cause a lighted lamp or lantern to be placed at some convenient spot, so as to cast its light upon such vault or opening. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-8) 
905.09 - KEEPING DOORS IN SIDEWALK CLOSED. 
    Doors in sidewalks shall not remain open except when in actual use. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-9) 
905.10 - LIGHT OR GUARD AT OPEN CELLAR DOOR DURING THE NIGHT. 
    No person occupying or using any cellar the door of which is in any street, alley, walk or public square shall allow such door to remain open at any time from twilight in the evening until daylight in the morning without having a light at such door unless the same is properly guarded by a railing. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-10) 
905.11 - OBSTRUCTING SIDEWALKS. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in these Codified Ordinances or other city ordinances, no person shall encumber or obstruct a free passage along any sidewalk in the city by placing any object thereon or by moving snow or ice onto the right-of-way so as to obstruct sidewalks or any ramps leading from the roadway to sidewalks. This provision does not alter any obligation of a property owner with respect to the clearing and removal of snow and ice from sidewalks adjacent to his or her property existing under common law, any ordinance or any state statute. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions contained in subsection (a) above, the following will not be considered to be violations of this ordinance: 
(1)  The placement of freight or other objects on sidewalks with the intention of immediate loading or unloading; 
(2)  The placement of tables, chairs and related objects for the purpose of outdoor dining when the property owner has obtained the necessary permit from the City of Huntington; 
(3)  The placement of obstructions for legitimate emergency purposes. 
(c)  Violation of the provisions set forth herein shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $250 for the first offense and not more than $500 for the second and subsequent offenses. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-11; Ord. of 4-13-15(1) ) 
905.12 - SIGNS OBSTRUCTING STREET INTERSECTIONS. 
    No portable sign, parasite sign or other device of such a nature as to obstruct vision may be located within a 50-foot triangular space at any street intersection; it being understood that such triangular space shall be determined by a diagonal line connecting two points measured 50 feet along each of the projected street curblines, or approximation thereof, equidistant from the projected and intersecting curblines at the street corner; it being further understood that this section shall not include alley intersections. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-11.1) 
905.13 - OBSTRUCTING GUTTERS. 
    No person shall obstruct or cause to be obstructed in any way whatever the gutters of any street or public alley so as to prevent the free passage of water along the same. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-12) 
905.14 - OBSTRUCTING DRAINAGE DITCHES. 
    No person shall obstruct or cause to be obstructed, in any way whatsoever, the drainage ditches of any street, avenue, road or alley or other public place so as to prevent the free passage of water along the same. When it is found that any such drainage ditch is obstructed so as to interfere with the drainage of water, then the obstruction shall be immediately removed or altered as the case may be by the person obstructing the same; and unless the same is so removed or altered as the case may require, then the city shall remove or alter the same and the cost thereof shall be charged to the owner abutting thereon. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-13) 
905.15 - WATER, GAS AND SEWER CONNECTIONS WHEN STREET IS TO BE PAVED. 
    When any street, alley or public place of the city is about to be improved by paving, macadamizing or by any other method, the director of public works shall give ten days' notice thereof to the owners or the agents of the owners of any lots or pieces of ground on which buildings have been erected on the line of such street, alley or public place, or adjacent thereto, directing them to make connection with the water and gas mains and public sewers, if any exist and underlie the street, avenue, alley or public place, for the purpose of conducting water or gas into the buildings or drawing the wastewater therefrom. Such connections shall be made and completed within 20 days after the giving of the notice. Upon the failure of the owner to comply with such notice, the city shall do the work and the expense thereof shall be charged to such owner. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-14) 
905.16 - REPAIR OF RAILROAD TRACKS AND ADJACENT PAVING. 
    Railroad companies shall make such repairs to their tracks which cross or are located in public ways and the paving adjacent thereto as may be required by the director of public works, within 30 days of receipt of notice from the director. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-15) 
905.99 - PENALTY. 
Editor's note- See section 101.99 for general Codified Ordinances penalty. 
ARTICLE 907 - EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Street obstructions, § 311.01; loads dropping or leaking, § 347.04; disturbing barriers, § 905.07. 
State Law reference- Power to regulate street excavations, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-5(2). 

907.01 - POWERS AND DUTIES OF MAYOR. 
    In order to expedite the opening and closing of public ways and to protect the traveling public from inconvenience or injury, the mayor is authorized to promulgate such rules, regulations and orders on behalf of the city relating to the opening of the public right-of-way, use of the public way during the duration of such opening and closing of openings in the public right-of-way. Such rules and regulations without limitation on the generality thereof shall have the same force and effect as if fully set forth in this article. 
(Ord. 6-28-82) 
907.02 - PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS. 
    No person shall open the surface of any street, alley or way of the city or shall make an excavation so near the line of any street, alley or sidewalk so as to endanger public travel, unless a permit is obtained for that purpose in the manner described in this article; provided, that it shall not be necessary for the corporate authorities of the city to obtain a permit or for any railway company to obtain a permit for the purpose of repairing the roadbeds of its railway or the pavements between its tracks and one foot outside thereof, where such railway company shall repair and keep in repair that portion of the highway. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-16) 
907.03 - PERMIT APPLICATION. 
(a)  Any person desiring a permit required by section 907.02 shall file with the director of public works a written application for each and every opening, which application shall be signed by the person desiring such permit. Such application shall set forth the purpose for which such opening or excavation is to be made, the extent, size, and location of the same, the dates during which such opening or excavation is to be permitted and shall provide that the applicant will faithfully comply with each and every provision contained in this article. 
(b)  Such application shall also specify the name of the owner of the property served or to be served by the facility located in the street opening. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall in no event apply to the repair of a sidewalk by any adjoining property owner. The repair, opening or excavation of any public sidewalk shall be governed by the provisions of article 909. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-17; Ord. 6-13-83) 
907.04 - PERMIT FEES. 
    The following permit fees are to be paid for the issuance of a street opening permit: $10 and $0.25 per square foot of opening. 
(Ord. 6-28-82) 
907.05 - BOND PREREQUISITE TO ISSUANCE. 
    No permit required by section 907.02 shall be granted until the applicant therefor shall have executed and delivered to the city a bond in the amount hereinafter fixed, with good surety, which surety shall be an approved surety or indemnity company licensed to do business in the city. The amount of such bond shall be $1,000 for each opening or $5,000 for an indefinite number of openings for a 12-month period. The bond shall be given upon the condition that the principal will indemnify and save harmless the city from any loss, damages or expenses whatsoever, in any manner occasioned by or arising from the opening of any street, or way, or the work done in consequence thereof, or the manner of doing such work, and the bond shall remain in force for a period of 12 months after the permanent resurfacing of each opening. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-19) 
907.06 - PAYMENT OF MONEY DUE CITY PREREQUISITE TO PERMIT ISSUANCE. 
    No permit required by section 907.02 shall be granted to any applicant therefor unless such applicant pays to the city all money then due to the city from such applicant for prior openings or excavations made or for any loss, damage or expense in any manner occasioned by or arising from the opening or excavations under prior permits issued to such applicant. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-20) 
907.07 - PERMIT ISSUANCE. 
    A permit required by section 907.02 shall be issued by the director of public works when the person applying for such permit shall have complied with sections 907.03 to 907.06. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-21) 
907.08 - SUPERVISION AND INSPECTION OF WORK; STREET REPAIR. 
    All work done under the authority of any permit issued pursuant to this article shall be supervised and inspected by the director of public works. The director shall have the right to inspect all work done under any permit issued pursuant to this article. All questions arising under any of the provisions of this article as to the amount of work reasonably required to be done to insure a permanent repair shall be determined by the director, his agents or employees, and such work shall at all times be under his supervision, inspection and direction. 
    In the event the opening is not closed to the satisfaction of the director, the city may replace the surface in a satisfactory manner and charge the costs to the person who obtained the permit. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-22) 
907.09 - DUTIES OF OFFICER OBSERVING EXCAVATING IN OR NEAR STREETS. 
    The director of public works or any police officer seeing anyone making any excavation in the street, alley or sidewalk, or so near thereto as to endanger the traveling public, shall immediately ascertain whether the person has the authority to do so. The person so making an excavation in or near the street, alley or sidewalk shall show his authority for so doing to the director or the police officer when demanded. All persons without authority for so excavating shall be stopped by the policeman or the director. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-23) 
907.10 - TUNNELS. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to permit the issuing of a permit for the making of a tunnel under any street, alley or way in the city. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-24) 
907.11 - INTERFERENCE WITH ONE-WAY TRAFFIC. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to permit any person to excavate within any street or alley in the city in such a manner and to such an extent as to interfere with or prevent one-way vehicular traffic at all times. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-25) 
907.12 - ENFORCEMENT OF ARTICLE. 
    The director of public works shall see that all the provisions of this article are strictly enforced, and shall prosecute every person violating any of the provisions of this article and shall bring suit to restrain any person from opening the surface of any street or way of the city in violation of the provisions of this article, as well as any person making an excavation so near the line of any street, alley or sidewalk as to endanger public travel. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-26) 
907.99 - PENALTY. 
Editor's note- See section 101.99 for general Codified Ordinances penalties. 
ARTICLE 909 - CURB TO PROPERTY LINE IMPROVEMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- General powers relative to curbs, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-5(1) et seq.; powers generally, W. Va. Code § 8-12-5(1) et seq.; low cost improvements, W. Va. Code, Art. 8-17; street assessment, W. Va. Code, Art. 8-18. 

909.01 - SIDEWALK REPAIRS; PERMIT; APPLICATION; FEE. 
(a)  No person shall make a repair, opening or excavation to any public sidewalk for any purpose without first making application to the director of public works for a sidewalk repair permit. Such application shall specify the exact location of the proposed repair and the adjoining property owners to be served by such repair. 
    Fees for sidewalk repair permits shall be paid in the amount specified in section 909.02, and in accordance with the procedure established in section 909.02. 
(b)  All repairs or additions to any sidewalk within the City of Huntington shall comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). Failure to comply with the ADA shall be viewed as a criminal act by the owner, lessor and/or contractor and shall be cited and subject to a fine of up to $500 and/or up to 30 days in jail. 
(c)  No person shall destroy, deface, pave over, use for parking any sidewalk within the City of Huntington. Violators shall be subject to a fine of up to $500 and/or up to 30 days in jail. 
(d)  No city official or employee shall approve any work on any sidewalk that is not in compliance with section 909.01(a), (b) and (c), and if such approval is given it shall constitute malfeasance in office. The city official or employee approving such work may be removed from office by council and shall be personally subject to a fine of up to $500 and/or up to 30 days in jail. 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
909.02 - SIDEWALK REPAIR APPLICATION FEE. 
    The following permit fee is to be paid for the issuance of a permit required by the provisions of this article: 
Sidewalk repair permit: $25. 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
909.03 - LOCATION AND CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS. 
    All sidewalks in the city shall be located as required by the director of public works and constructed in accordance with his specifications; provided, that no sidewalk shall be constructed of asphaltic concrete. No sidewalk shall be constructed except upon notice to the director. The director shall set stakes and give grades for all sidewalks. 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
909.04 - PAVING BETWEEN CURB LINE AND PROPERTY LINE WHEN CURB CUT IS MADE. 
    All persons who have obtained permits for the purpose of making curb cuts shall pave with concrete between the portion of the curbing removed and the property line adjacent thereto. Such paving shall be made in such manner and in accordance with specifications approved by the director of public works. 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
909.05 - FUNDING CURBS AND SIDEWALKS. 
(a)  The director of public works and the director of development and planning shall aid residents to secure a method of funding curb and sidewalk repairs using federal and state funding sources, when available. 
(b)  When other outside funding is not available, the mayor, upon recommendation of the director of public works shall provide a resolution to council in compliance with W. Va. Code, § 8-18. 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
909.06 - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- This section is saved for future use. 
909.07 - RESOLUTIONS REQUIRING PLANTING AND CARE OF SHADE TREES. 
    Council may, by resolution, require the owners or occupiers of the land, lots or parts of lots abutting or facing upon any street or alley in the city, to plant, replant and care for shade trees along such street or alley, at such points, and in such manner, as council may determine by such resolution and may require the owners or occupiers of such land, lots or parts of lots facing or abutting upon such streets or alleys to keep the sidewalks clean and in good repair, to grade the plot of ground on either side of the sidewalk between the street curb and the property otherwise in good condition and repair, and may require such owners or occupiers of the land, lots or parts of lots abutting or fronting upon such streets or alleys, to keep the same free from foregoing requirements served, as provided by this article, shall be served upon the owners or occupiers of such land, lots or parts of lots. 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
909.08 - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- This section is saved for future use. 
909.09 - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- This section is saved for future use. 
909.10 - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- This section is saved for future use. 
909.11 - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- This section is saved for future use. 
909.12 - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- This section is saved for future use. 
909.13 - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- This section is saved for future use. 
909.14 - SUPERVISION OF WORK DONE BY CITY OR BY CONTRACTOR. 
    All work done under section 909.01 whether done by the city directly or through contractors, shall be under the supervision of the city engineer. 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
909.15 - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- This section is saved for future use. 
909.16 - DUTY OF ADJACENT PROPERTY OWNER/OCCUPIER/LESSEE. 
    It shall be the duty, responsibility and obligation of the owner, occupier and/or lessee of property to maintain, repair and keep all adjacent sidewalks in good order and free and clear of any and all encumbrances and obstructions, to include snow, ice and leaves. Any property owner, occupier and/or lessee who fails to keep any such sidewalk in repair shall be liable to reimburse the city for any and all losses it may sustain, or any damages, costs or expenses that may be imposed on or incurred by the city by reason of the failure to perform this duty and shall be subject to a fine of up to $500 and/or up to 30 days in jail. 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
909.20 - ADOPTION OF WEST VIRGINIA CODE 8-18. 
    The Municipality of the City of Huntington adopts W. Va. Code, § 8-18 in its entirety as to the authority, funding and assessment of costs to improve streets and sidewalks. 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
909.21 - PER SAY DISREPAIR. 
    Any sidewalk which has a two-inch deviation in height at any point shall be in disrepair and must be repaired by the abutting property owner or the director of public works shall take action in accordance with article 909, city ordinances and W. Va. Code, § 8-18 causing the repair and assessing cost to the abutting property owner. 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
909.99 - PENALTY. 
    If any person shall fail, neglect or refuse to put down a suitable curb of concrete or other material along and for the footways and sidewalks of any of the avenues, streets, roads or alleys of the city, or to lay, relay or repair any sidewalks and gutters in, on or along any of such streets or alleys, or to plant, replant and care for shade trees along any of such streets or alleys at the points and in the manner as council may have determined, or shall fail to keep such sidewalks clean and in good repair, or to grade the plot of ground on either side of such sidewalks between the street curb and property line, and to keep the same sodded with grass and free from weeds and obstructions and otherwise in good condition and repair, or keep any land, lots, or parts of lots abutting or fronting upon such streets or alleys of the city free from weeds and other vegetation which may be unsightly or noxious, within 20 days after service of any notice to do so, as provided for in sections 909.05 to 909.07, such person shall be punished and subject to fine of not more than $500 and/or up to 30 days in jail 
(Ord. 11-13-01) 
ARTICLE 911 - NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS 

911.01 - GENERAL PROVISIONS. 
    Every owner or lessee of a house or building on any street or avenue within the city shall place the proper number of such house or building in a conspicuous place in the front of the house or building. The figures of such numbers shall be not less than three inches in length and shall be painted or shall be made of metal, porcelain or other durable material. The numbers shall be maintained upon such house or building at all times and no number other than the one assigned thereto shall be placed or permitted to remain upon any such house or building. All broken or defective figures shall be promptly replaced or restored to their proper condition so that they may at all times be distinctly read. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-41) 
911.02 - ASSIGNMENT OF NUMBERS; DUTIES OF DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS. 
    The director of public works shall assign the proper numbers to each lot, house or building within the city, in accordance with the provisions of this article, and with the general plan or map of block numbers now on file in the office of the director, and the director shall from time to time cause detailed maps or other suitable records of houses, buildings or lot numbers to be placed and kept on file in his office. The director shall require such numbers to be affixed as provided by this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 31-42) 
911.99 - PENALTY. 
Editor's note- See section 101.99 for general Codified Ordinances penalty. 
ARTICLE 913 - FRANCHISES AND SPECIAL PRIVILEGE PERMITS[4] 
DEFINITIONS 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Curb cuts, § 909.04. 
State Law reference- Granting of franchises, W. Va. Code, Art. 8-31. 

913.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
    The following terms, when used in any of the sections of this article, shall, for the purposes of this article, have the meanings indicated in this section: 
(a)  "Area charge" means a charge based on the square feet area of the city property used. 
(b)  "Building encroachment" means the occupancy of a public street, sidewalk, alley, way or other public place on, under or above the street surface by a construction constituting a part of a building, such as a stairway, vault, loading platform, balcony, bay window, marquee or similar construction. 
(c)  "Council" means the council of the city. 
(d)  "Franchise" means an exclusive or nonexclusive right granted by the city for the use of any part of a street, sidewalk, alley, way or other public place within the city for the rendering of a public service. 
(e)  "Permittee" means a person to whom is granted a special privilege. Where the special privilege granted is directly appurtenant to the abutting real estate, "permittee" means the owner of such real estate or the lessee thereof whose lease term extends in time beyond the term of the special privilege. 
(f)  "Privileged premises" means the lot or parcel of real estate to which a special privilege is appurtenant. 
(g)  "Public utility" means a person engaged in any business for the rendering of a public service. 
(h)  "Special privilege" means a private use, other than for the rendering of a public service, of any part of a street, sidewalk, alley, way or other public place within the city separate and distinct from the general public use thereof. 
(i)  "Vault" means any open space below the surface of a street, sidewalk, alley, way or other public place that is covered over and used or available for use, for private purposes. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-17) 
FRANCHISES 
913.02 - APPLICATIONS. 
    Application for franchises under this article shall be made in the manner prescribed by the laws of the state relating thereto, including the publication of notice, public hearing and other preliminaries required by such laws. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-1) 
913.03 - GRANTING. 
    Following the public hearing on an application for a franchise, council shall grant the franchise upon such conditions and upon payment of such annual fees as to it seem proper and to which the applicant shall agree, or shall deny such application, no later than the next regular meeting of council unless consideration thereon is deferred by motion of council to a subsequent regular or special meeting. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-2) 
SPECIAL PRIVILEGE PERMITS 
913.04 - HOW APPLICATIONS TO BE MADE. 
    Application for special privilege permits under this article shall be made by the prospective permittee in the manner prescribed by regulations promulgated by the mayor and approved by resolution of council. Copies of such regulations, as amended from time to time, shall be filed in the city clerk's office and copies shall be available to interested parties at all reasonable times. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-3) 
913.05 - INVESTIGATION AND REPORT OF APPLICATIONS. 
    All applications for special privilege permits shall be referred to the director of public works for investigation and report and to determine the annual fee payable if the special privilege should be granted. The application, with the recommendation of the director shall be referred to the mayor for authorizing or refusing the special privilege permit if it is in compliance with the then existing requirements. If the special privilege applied for is not in compliance with the then existing requirements, the mayor shall refer the application, together with his recommendation thereon, to council for authorizing or refusing the special privilege. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-4) 
913.06 - APPEALS FROM ADVERSE RULINGS. 
    Any applicant for a special privilege permit may appeal to council from an adverse ruling by the mayor. Any applicant for a franchise or special privilege permit may proceed by certiorari to the Circuit Court of Cabell County from an adverse ruling by council. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-5) 
913.07 - PERMITS TO PROVIDE FOR PAYMENT OF ANNUAL FEE. 
    Every permit granting and conveying any special privilege in, under and over any street, sidewalk, alley, way or other public place within the city shall provide for the payment of an annual fee as set forth in this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-6) 
913.08 - PERMIT FEES TO BE IN ADDITION TO OTHER FEES. 
    All fees, established by this article for the enjoyment of special privileges by permits granted pursuant to the provisions hereof, shall be separate from and in addition to all other fees required by law. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-7) 
913.09 - SCHEDULE OF FEES. 
    The annual fees for special privileges granted pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be as follows: 
(a)  Vaults: Area charge of $0.02 per square foot. Minimum fee: $10. 
(b)  Covered street or sidewalk openings ten square feet or less in area: $10 for ten square feet or less, $15 for more than ten square feet. 
(c)  Stair or steps leading up or down from sidewalk level excluding covered cellar steps classified under subsection (b) hereof: Area charge of $0.15 per square foot. 
(d)  Open areaways, light wells and similar construction: Area charge of $0.05 per square foot. Minimum fee: $10. 
(e)  Balconies: $10 each for one floor, plus $5 for each additional floor. 
(f)  Bays: $10 each for one floor, plus $5 for each additional floor. 
(g)  Marquees: Area charge of $0.05 per square foot. Minimum fee: $10. 
(h)  Fire escapes: $1 each for first floor, $0.50 for each additional floor. Minimum fee: $5. 
(i)  Projecting show windows or showcases: Area charge of $0.15 per square foot. Minimum fee: $25. 
(j)  Curb cuts: The fee for all curb cuts used for access to commercial, industrial and apartment properties, and for all access other than one- and two-family residences, shall be an annual franchise fee charged as follows: First ten feet, no charge except the minimum as prescribed below. 
Over ten feet, $0.75 per foot of curb. Minimum fee: $5. 
The measure of the curb cut shall be the beginning of the approach radius; that is, at the point at which the curb is disturbed; provided, that in the event that two or more curb cuts are granted for the benefit or use of the same property abutting on more than one street, the first ten feet of such curb cut on each street shall be free. 
The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to private driveways providing access to single or double family residences involving curb cuts of not more than 20 feet in width. 
(k)  Loading platforms: Area charge of $0.15 per square foot of space occupied, including steps and ramps. Minimum fee: $25. 
(l)  Sidewalk loading space: A franchise for sidewalk space to be regularly used by vehicles for loading and unloading shall provide for the payment of such license fee as may be fixed by council after consideration of all facts involved. No sidewalk space shall be regularly used by vehicles for loading or unloading without a franchise therefor. 
(m)  Street scales: $10 each. 
(n)  Poles used to carry or support wires, etc: $1 each. 
(o)  Tunnels, including conduits or pipes more than two feet in diameter: $0.10 per cubic foot in the central business zone, $0.05 per cubic foot elsewhere. Minimum fee: $10. 
(p)  Underground pipelines or conduits two feet in diameter or less: $0.05 per running foot in the central business zone, $0.02 per running foot elsewhere. Minimum fee: $10. 
(q)  Driven wells for water supply purposes: $25 for the first year or part thereof and $10 for each year thereafter. 
(r)  Railroad switch tracks: $0.10 per lineal foot. No railroad switch tracks shall hereafter be constructed, maintained, operated or used without a franchise therefor. Minimum fee: $10. 
(s)  Overhead pipe, conduits, beams and other overhead construction: $0.10 per lineal foot for each overhead pipe, conduit, beam or other overhead construction. Minimum fee: $10. 
(t)  Planters: Area rate of $0.15 per square foot. Minimum fee: $10. 
    Where no other minimum fee is specified for a franchise, a minimum fee of $10 shall be charged. 
    Any special privilege not specifically covered by the foregoing provisions of this section shall be classified by the director of public works according to the classification it most resembles and shall be subject to a special privilege fee accordingly. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-8) 
913.10 - WHEN FEE IS PAYABLE; PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO PAY. 
    All initial fees for special privileges shall be payable on or before the date the permit is effective. Thereafter, those desiring to renew such privilege whose permit was granted between January 1 and June 30 shall make each yearly fee, and such is due on or before April 1. Permits granted between July 1 and December 31 shall make each yearly fee, and such is due on or before October 1. Permits initially granted between April through June or October through December shall be given credit for such period of time remaining upon their initial permit when applying for renewal. Additionally, permits initially granted between January through March or July through September will be required to pay an extra fee to compensate for the period of time which exceeds their anniversary date upon applying for renewal. 
    Failure to pay the required permit fee within 60 days after the date on which such fee is due and payable shall subject the permittee to a penalty charge of 10% of the annual fee for each month or fraction of a month that such fee is delinquent. 
(Ord. 12-13-82) 
913.11 - TERM. 
    No special privilege permit shall be granted for a term of more than ten years; except, that permits granted under the provisions of section 913.09(l), (r) and (s) may be granted for such term as council, in its discretion, may determine. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-10) 
913.12 - INDEMNIFICATION OF CITY; LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED. 
    It shall be a condition to the use or enjoyment of any special privilege which is granted pursuant to the provisions of this article that the permittee shall save and hold the city harmless from any and all liability, claims or expenses of any kind, caused by or growing out of the construction maintenance, operation, relocation, discontinuance or abandonment of such special privilege. 
    Whenever the city grants or renews a permit for a special privilege over, along, above or below a street, sidewalk, alley, way or other public place within the city, the permittee shall deposit with the city a policy of insurance conditioned to indemnify and save the city harmless from any and all liability, claims or expenses of any kind, by reason of injury to any person or property caused by or growing out of the construction, maintenance, operation, relocation, discontinuance or abandonment of such special privilege. The minimum liability of such policy of insurance shall be $100,000 for injury to one person, $300,000 per occurrence and $25,000 for damage to property. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-11) 
913.13 - RIGHTS EXTEND TO PERMITTEE; ASSIGNMENT AND TRANSFER. 
    The special privilege granted by any permit issued under the provisions of this article shall extend only to the permittee in whose name such permit is granted; however, all permits shall be subject to transfer and assignment in the discretion of the mayor upon application by the permittee or the person to whom he proposes to assign or transfer the permit. When any assignment or transfer has been approved by the mayor, the assignee or transferee shall succeed to all rights and obligations of the original permittee. There shall be no charge for assignments or transfers authorized pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-12) 
913.14 - DISCONTINUANCE OR ABANDONMENT. 
    Any permittee may at any time discontinue any special privilege by giving at least 30 days' notice in writing to the mayor and by providing for all necessary street and sidewalk restorations and other adjustments, subject to the supervision and approval of the director of public works. When all necessary steps as to discontinuance or abandonment have been completed, the director shall report such fact to council, who shall instruct the director of the division of finance to refund to the permittee 50% of the unused portion of the permit fee paid; provided, that no refund shall be paid for a fraction of a month. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-13) 
913.15 - USE OF SPECIAL PRIVILEGE WITHOUT PERMIT; PENALTY. 
    No person shall exercise a special privilege, as defined in this article, unless and until such use is permitted in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
    When a special privilege is used or exercised without obtaining a permit or renewal of an expired permit, the person unlawfully exercising such special privilege shall be required to pay twice the amount of the fees specified for the legal exercise of such privilege, but the payment of such double fees shall not entitle the person to exercise the special privilege and shall not relieve the person from fully complying with the requirements of this article and from any other penalties prescribed in these Codified Ordinances. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-14) 
913.16 - NOTICE TO PERSONS EXERCISING SPECIAL PRIVILEGES WITHOUT PERMITS. 
    The mayor shall cause notice to be sent to all persons exercising special privileges who do not have permits therefor, advising them of the necessity of applying for permits or renewal thereof as a condition to continuing such special privileges. The failure of any user to receive such notice shall not excuse noncompliance with the terms of this article or otherwise confer any right on such user. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-15) 
913.17 - SERVICE OF NOTICE. 
    All notices required by this article to be given by the city shall be served upon the permittee or his agent in charge of the privileged premises, and all notices to be given by the permittee shall be served upon the mayor, in any one or more of the following ways: 
(a)  By personal service as provided by law for service of legal process. 
(b)  By registered letter addressed to the last-known place of business or residence of the person to be served. 
(c)  By notice published once a week for two weeks in a newspaper of general circulation published in the city. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-16) 
GENERAL PROVISIONS 
913.18 - AUTHORITY AND DUTIES OF MAYOR. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, the mayor shall have full control of the supervision, inspection and enforcement of franchises and special privilege permits authorized and granted pursuant to the provisions of this article, and when the public safety or welfare requires the temporary or permanent discontinuance or modification of a revocable franchise or special privilege permit, he shall take all action necessary for the public safety and welfare. If action by council is required, the mayor shall advise council and instruct the city attorney to prepare the necessary legislation. The mayor shall promulgate and submit to council for approval reasonable rules and regulations to govern the carrying out of the provisions of this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-18) 
913.19 - STREET AND SIDEWALK RESTORATION; OTHER ADJUSTMENTS. 
    All street and sidewalk restoration and other adjustments made necessary by the construction, maintenance, operation, relocation, discontinuance or abandonment of any franchise or special privilege shall be performed in accordance with the provisions of existing ordinances, by the franchise holder or permittee at whose instance the adjustment is made or, at the option of the mayor, by the city, but at the expense of the franchise holder or permittee for whom such adjustment is made. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-19) 
913.20 - CHANGES IN CONSTRUCTION OR LOCATION REQUIRED BY CHANGES IN STREETS OR UTILITY LINES. 
    A franchise holder or permittee may be required at any time by the mayor to make any necessary change in the construction or location of a franchise or special privilege which may be required in connection with any change of street by the city, or in connection with the authorized location or change of location of public utility service lines, pipes, poles or other equipment. Any change in construction or location required by the city shall be paid for by the city, and any change in construction or location required by a public utility shall be paid for by the public utility for whose benefit such change is required. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-20) 
913.21 - ENCROACHMENTS REGULATED BY BUILDING CODE. 
    Encroachments by building structures on public streets, sidewalks, alleys, ways and other public property shall continue to be regulated in accordance with the provisions of the Building Code and other applicable provisions of law. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-21) 
913.22 - EFFECT OF ARTICLE ON EXISTING FRANCHISES OR PERMITS. 
    The provisions of this article shall not in any way alter, amend or change the provisions of existing franchises or special privilege permits heretofore designated as franchises. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-22) 
913.23 - CERTAIN PUBLIC UTILITIES EXEMPTED. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any public utility whose rates are regulated by the Public Service Commission of the state and who has heretofore been, or may hereafter be, granted by separate ordinance a franchise for a period in excess of ten years under which there is a stipulated annual or monthly franchise fee. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-23) 
913.24 - USE OF PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY; FLASHING SPOTLIGHT SIGNS PROHIBITED. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation within the city limits shall use or utilize any city-owned property or city right-of-way, or any state-owned property or state right-of-way located within the city limits, in any manner to advertise or otherwise conduct any private business, or display any insignia or signs relating thereto, except to the extent that such use is authorized under applicable city ordinances and provided that the requirements of such city ordinances are met. 
(b)  No franchise shall be granted or issued to any person, firm or corporation which shall in any way authorize any signs of the flashing spotlight type, however mounted, to be located between the sidewalk and curb, regardless of its size and shape, and any person, firm or corporation so doing shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to the fine and penalties prescribed by section 101.99. 
(1964 Code Sec. 15-24; Ord. 9-26-94) 
913.99 - PENALTY. 
Editor's note- See section 101.99 for general Codified Ordinances penalty. 
ARTICLE 915 - TREES AND SHRUBS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Shade trees, § 909.07. 
State Law reference- Power to regulate, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-5(29). 

915.01 - PERMIT FOR PLANTING IN PUBLIC PLACE. 
    No person shall plant or set out any tree, shrub or vine, or cause, authorize or procure any person to plant or set out any tree, shrub or vine in or upon any part of any public street or public place, without first obtaining from the director of public works a written permit to do so and without complying in all respects with such conditions as are set forth in such written permit. 
    All applications for the permits required by the provisions of this section shall be made on blanks furnished by the city and shall describe the work to be done and shall state the variety, size and exact location of each tree, shrub or vine. After the receipt of such an application, the director shall investigate the locality where the tree, shrub or vine is to be placed and shall take into consideration, in considering the application, the normal growth and development of such tree, shrub or vine. Each permit issued by the director shall specify the location, variety and size of each tree, shrub or vine and method of planting, and shall be good only for the period stated therein. There shall be no charge for such permits, but before any permit is issued for planting more than ten trees, shrubs or vines, the director may request from the applicant a detailed declaration of intentions, either in the form of a planting plan or a written statement containing such information as the director may require. 
(1964 Code Sec. 36-1) 
915.02 - TRIMMING. 
    Trees, vines, bushes, shrubbery or flowers standing in or upon any public street or public place, or on any lot or land adjacent to any public street or public place, and having branches, limbs, trunks or other parts projecting into the public street or place shall, under the supervision of the director of public works, be kept trimmed by the owner or occupant of the adjoining property so as not to interfere with the free and safe passage along such public way by pedestrians and vehicular traffic. 
(1964 Code Sec. 36-2) 
915.03 - PLANTING IN PUBLIC PLACES. 
    The following regulations are hereby established for the planting of trees, shrubs or vines in or upon the public streets and public places of the city: 
(a)  No tree shall be planted at the intersection of two or more streets or within 20 feet of such intersection. 
(b)  No tree, shrub or vine shall be planted where the clear space between the curb and the sidewalk is less than three feet. 
(c)  No tree, shrub or vine shall be planted nearer than two feet from the curb line or outer line of the sidewalk. 
(1964 Code Sec. 36-3) 
915.04 - POWER OF DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS TO TRIM OR REMOVE. 
    The director of public works shall have the right to trim or remove such trees and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, lands and public grounds as may be necessary to insure safety to pedestrians and vehicular traffic and he, under the power granted by this section, may remove, cause or order to be removed any tree, shrub or part thereof, which is in an unsafe condition or which, by reason of its location, may be hazardous to pedestrians or vehicular traffic. The director shall have the power to enter upon any private grounds for the purpose of trimming or removing trees and shrubbery in order to prevent danger therefrom to person or property, in the event the owner or occupant of such premises does not comply with the orders of the director relative to the trimming or removal of trees or shrubbery which, in his opinion, are hazardous to pedestrians or vehicular traffic. 
(1964 Code Sec. 36-4) 
915.05 - INJURING SHADE TREES. 
    No person shall cut, saw, tear or break down any ornamental or shade trees, along the sidewalk or in any other public place in the city, or injure the same in any manner. 
(1964 Code Sec. 36-5) 
915.99 - PENALTY. 
Editor's note- See section 101.99 for general Codified Ordinances penalty. 
ARTICLE 917 - URBAN FORESTRY REGULATIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-5(29). 

917.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural. 
(a)  "Municipality" means the City of Huntington, Cabell and Wayne Counties, West Virginia. 
(b)  "Urban forestry advisory committee" means the body which advises the city on matters affecting the Urban Forest. 
(c)  "Urban forester" means the person designated within the department of public works who administers the provisions of this article under the supervision and direction of the mayor. The urban forester shall have experience in urban forestry. 
(d)  "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(e)  "Street" or "highway" means the entire width of every public way or right-of-way when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular and pedestrian traffic, and extending from property line to property line. 
(f)  "Park" includes all public parks, the ownership and control of which are vested in the City of Huntington, Cabell and Wayne Counties, West Virginia. 
(g)  "Public places" includes all grounds owned by the City of Huntington, the County of Cabell, the County of Wayne and the State of West Virginia, situated within the City of Huntington. 
(h)  "Tree or street tree" includes any tree or other plant in a public place as indicated by subsequent provisions of this article. 
(i)  "Public trees" are all shade and ornamental trees now or hereafter growing on any street or any public right-of-way or in any other public areas. 
(j)  "Principal thoroughfare" means any public street upon which trucks are not prohibited. 
(k)  "Property owner" means the person(s) owning designated property as shown by the county assessor's plat of Cabell or Wayne County, as the case may be. 
(l)  "Remove" means the cutting down or damaging, whether by deliberate or negligent act or omission, or any act which causes the tree to die within three years. 
(m)  "Tree" means: 
(1)  Any self-supporting woody plant which has a well defined stem with a diameter of at least four inches at 4.5 feet from the ground; 
(2)  Any conspicuously flowering woody plant as designated by the urban forester which has a well defined stem at least two inches diameter at 4.5 feet from the ground; or 
(3)  Any small seedling or sapling planted or protected specifically to become a large tree as described in subsections (m)(1) or (2) above. 
(n)  "Urban forest" means trees located on city-owned or controlled property. 
(o)  "Urban forest regulations" means regulations promulgated by the mayor or enacted in ordinance form by council and regulating or dealing with the urban forest. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.02 - URBAN ADVISORY FORESTRY COMMITTEE. 
    There is hereby created an urban forestry advisory committee consisting of seven members. One of these members shall be the president of the Huntington Council of Garden Clubs. One member shall be appointed by the president of Marshall University. One member shall be appointed by the Greater Huntington Parks and Recreation District and one member shall be the Cabell County Extension Service Agent. Two members shall be appointed by the mayor and one member shall be appointed by council. All such members shall be appointed for three-year terms, except that the initial appointments shall as follows: 
Years Huntington Council of Garden Clubs 1 President of Marshall University 2 Greater Huntington Parks and Recreation Board 2 Cabell County Extension Agent 3 Mayor's representatives 3 Council's representative 3  
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.03 - DUTIES OF THE URBAN FORESTER. 
    The urban forester shall assist in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and for recommending new or modified rules and regulations governing the planting, maintenance, removal, fertilization, pruning and bracing of public trees, emergency procedures, stump removal and sale/disposal of wood products on the streets or other public sites, and shall oversee the planting, maintenance and removal of trees growing now or hereafter planted in any public area of the city. The urban forester shall work at the direction of, and report to the mayor. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.04 - AUTHORITY OF THE URBAN FORESTER. 
    The urban forester shall: 
(a)  Supervise or inspect all work done under a permit issued in accordance with the terms of this article. 
(b)  Coordinate the formulation of a Master Urban Tree Plan, in cooperation with the urban forestry advisory committee, the mayor and council. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.05 - PERMITS REQUIRED. 
(a)  No person shall commence or proceed with any operation involving a public tree without first obtaining a permit from the city. Activities covered by this section include, but are not necessarily limited to, planting, spraying, preserving, pruning, removing, cutting above ground or otherwise disturbing any street or municipally-owned property. 
(b)  Application for a permit shall be made in the form prescribed by the city by: 
(1)  The public utility company or its authorized agent, if the work is to be done by a public utility company pursuant to its regular operations; and 
(2)  The abutting property owner, or such owner's agent, if the work is to be performed within a street on behalf of the abutting property owner. 
(c)  Application for permits shall be made at the public works office not less than 48 hours in advance of the time the work is to be done. 
(d)  The director of public works shall cause the permit to be issued if, in the judgment of the urban forester, the proposed work is desirable and the proposed method and workmanship thereof are of a satisfactory nature. Any permit granted shall contain a definite date of expiration and the work shall be completed in the time allowed on the permit and in the manner as therein described. Any permit may be revoked if its terms are violated. The city may charge a fee to cover the cost of printing and processing the permits referred to in this section. 
    Notice of completion shall be given within five days to the department of public works for inspection by the urban forester. 
(e)  Planting: 
(1)  Application data: The application required herein shall state the number of trees to be set out; the location, grade, species, cultivar or variety of each tree; the method of planting, and such other information as is reasonably necessary for a fair determination of whether a permit should be issued. 
(2)  Improper planting: Whenever any tree is planted or set out in conflict with the provisions of this section, the city shall remove or cause removal of the same, and the exact cost thereof shall be assessed to and paid by the owner responsible for the improper planting of such tree. 
(f)  Maintenance. Application data: The application required herein shall state the number and kinds of trees to be sprayed, fertilized, pruned or otherwise preserved; the kind of treatment to be administered; the composition of the spray material to be applied; and such other information as shall be reasonably necessary for a fair determination of whether a permit should be issued. 
(g)  Removal, replanting and replacement: 
(1)  Wherever it is necessary to remove a tree or trees in connection with the paving of a sidewalk, or the paving or widening of the portion of a street or highway used for vehicular traffic, whenever possible, the city shall replant such trees or replace them. Provided that when conditions prevent planting between the curb and the sidewalk, any equivalent number of trees of the same size and species as provided for in the arboricultural specifications may be planted in an attractive manner on the adjoining property with the consent of the adjoining property owner. 
(2)  No person or property owner shall remove a tree from the city right-of-way for the purpose of construction, or for any other reason, without first filing an application and procuring a permit from the city, and without replacing the removed tree or trees in accordance with the adopted arboricultural specifications. Such replacement shall meet the standards of size, species and placement as provided for in a permit issued by the city. The person or property owner shall bear the cost of removal and replacement of all trees so removed and replaced. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.06 - OBSTRUCTION-TREES PRUNED. 
    Any person or persons owning or occupying real property abutting on any street upon whose property there may be trees, shall prune such trees in such a manner that they will not obstruct or shade the street lights, obstruct the passage of pedestrians on sidewalks, obstruct vision of traffic signs or obstruct the view of any street or alley intersection. Public utilities shall have the right to properly trim and prune trees interfering with utilities that extend services and/or construct lines for the benefit of the general public. The minimum clearance of any overhanging portion thereof shall be ten feet over sidewalks, and 14 feet over all streets. 
(a)  Notice to prune. Should any person or persons owning real property bordering on any street fail to prune trees as provided above, the city shall order such person or persons, within 45 days after receipt of written notice, to so prune such trees, except that, in the case of an emergency situation, the city shall order such person or persons, within five days after receipt of written notice, to so prune such trees. 
(b)  Order required. The order required herein shall be served by mailing a copy of the order to the last known address of the property owner, by certified mail. 
(c)  Failure to comply. When a person to whom a lawful order, as provided above, is directed fails to comply with the terms thereof within the specified time, the city shall prune such trees, and the exact cost thereof shall be assessed to, and paid by, the abutting property owner to whom such order was issued. 
(Ord. 9-14-92) 
917.07 - ORDERS. 
    Any tree or shrub located on private or public property which obstructs a street or sidewalk, or which suffers from a communicable disease or insect infestation, as determined by the city, which threatens the public welfare or the health of public trees, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
    When such a public nuisance exists as to a tree or shrub located on private property, the city may cause a notice to be mailed by certified mail to the owner of the property on which the tree or shrub is located specifying what corrective work is necessary and directing the owner to perform such corrective work to eliminate the nuisance. 
    Should any ordered correction not be made within 45 days of the date such notice is received, the city shall cause such tree to be pruned, treated or removed as necessary to eliminate the public nuisance. All expenses involved in such work shall be recorded by the city and collected from the owner of the property on which the tree or shrub is located. Payments for noncompliance with such orders shall be made to the finance department. 
    The city may revoke for cause any permit previously approved and no refund of the permit fee shall be made. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.08 - ABUSE OR MUTILATION OF PUBLIC TREES. 
    Unless specifically authorized by the city, no person shall damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any public tree; attach any rope, wire, nails, advertising posters or other contrivance to any trees, allow any gaseous liquid or solid substance which is harmful to such trees, to come in contact with them; or set fire or permit any fire to burn when such fire or heat thereof will injure any portion of any tree. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.09 - APPEALS. 
(a)  Any person affected by an order, grant or denial of a permit, or other decision of the city when such decision is based upon the provisions of this article, may appeal such order, grant, denial or revocation of a permit, or other decision to the urban forestry appeals committee. 
(b)  Such appeal shall be filed in writing with the urban forester within 15 days of the date of notification of the ruling. 
(c)  Unless continued at the request of the applicant, any appeal shall be heard and decided by the urban forestry appeals committee. Action by the city shall be stayed until the decision is rendered and the applicant notified. 
(d)  The urban forestry appeals committee may, in conformity with the provisions of this article, reverse, affirm or modify wholly or partly the order, grant, denial or revocation of any permit, or other decision of the city. The decision of the urban forestry appeals committee shall be final, unless appealed to council. The action taken by council on any such appeal shall be final. All appeals shall be taken in writing and shall state clearly the factual basis for such appeal. 
(e)  The right of appeal shall be clearly stated on all permits. 
(f)  The urban forestry appeals committee shall consist of three members, one appointed by the mayor, one appointed by council and one appointed by the urban forestry advisory committee. Each member shall serve for three years with the term beginning December 1 of the year in which the appointment is made. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.10 - INTERFERENCE WITH URBAN FORESTER. 
    No person shall hinder, prevent, delay or interfere with the city in carrying out the execution or enforcement of this article; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed as an attempt to prohibit the pursuit of any remedy, legal or equitable, in any court of competent jurisdiction for the protection of property rights by the owner of any property within the municipality. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.11 - PLACING MATERIALS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY. 
    No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain upon any public property of the municipality, any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other material which may impede the free passage of water, air and fertilizer to the roots of any tree growing therein, except by written permit of the city. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.12 - EMERGENCIES. 
    No permit shall be required to remove any tree or part thereof which by reason of damage by fire, windstorm or other calamity poses a threat to the public health or safety or which obstructs any public way. 
    In the event of windstorm, fire, flood or other calamity, the mayor may declare a state of emergency and exempt operations necessary to remove threats to public safety from the permit requirements imposed by this article. 
    The city may determine that a public tree is hazardous and order that it be treated or removed immediately to protect the public health or safety or that any other tree poses a threat to the public health or safety within or obstructing any public way and shall be removed or treated immediately. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.13 - COMPENSATORY PAYMENTS. 
    No person shall remove any public tree without first securing a permit as provided by this article or without being required to replace such tree(s) with tree(s) of equivalent dollar value in the vicinity of the removed tree(s) taking into consideration the circumstances. The value of trees shall be determined by the city in accordance with published guidelines of the International Society of Arboriculture (Guide For Establishing Values of Trees and Other Plants, Sixth Edition). If no suitable location exists in the vicinity of the tree removed or if the replacement tree is of lesser value, the person causing the tree to be removed shall make a compensatory payment to the city equal to the difference in value between the tree removed and any replacement tree. Any public tree that is determined by the city to be damaged, but not sufficiently to justify its removal, shall be considered to be devalued. The amount of devaluation shall be paid to the city by the person causing the damage. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.14 - DISPOSAL OF WOOD PRODUCTS. 
    The city may sell without competitive bidding, wood and other forest products generated during urban forestry operations on public property. Proceeds from such sales shall be paid in within 24 hours to the finance department. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
917.99 - PENALTY. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be fined a sum of up to $500 and imprisoned for up to a maximum of 30 days. 
(Ord. 11-14-88) 
CHAPTER THREE - UTILITIES[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Article 933 was revised and reenacted by an Ordinance passed March 10, 1997. Subsequent amendments to Article 933 will be indicated by legislative histories at the end of the affected sections. 

ARTICLE 930 - HUNTINGTON WATER QUALITY BOARD 

930.01 - PURPOSE. 
    The purpose and intent of this article is to protect the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the City of Huntington, and protect and enhance the water quality of watercourses and water supplies located in or running through the city by establishing the Huntington Water Quality Board whose duty it will be to supervise and manage the Huntington Sanitary Board established under the provisions of Article 169 and the Huntington Stormwater Utility established under the provisions of Article 935 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington. 
(Ord. of 6-23-14(1)) 
930.02 - CREATION; MEMBERS. 
(a)  Upon the effective date of this ordinance [June 23, 2014], control and operation of the Huntington Sanitary Board established under the provisions of Article 169 and article 933 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington, and control and operation of the Huntington Stormwater Utility established under article 935 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington, shall be vested in the Huntington Water Quality Board (the "board"), created as of the effective date of this ordinance [June 23, 2014], and appointed and functioning as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  The board shall consist of the three members of the Huntington Sanitary Board established under the provisions of article 169 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Huntington, and W. Va. Code § 16-13-1 et seq. 
(Ord. of 6-23-14(1)) 
930.03 - POWERS AND DUTIES. 
    The board shall have full and complete supervision, management and control of the stormwater collection, conveyance, storage, treatment, and disposal system (the "stormwater system") and the sanitary sewage collection, transportation and treatment system (the "sanitary sewer system") of the city, including the maintenance, operations, improvements and extensions of each respective system, which shall be combined for operational purposes as a single water quality system (the "system"). Bills for stormwater service and sanitary sewer service may be rendered on the same form where appropriate but revenues and expenses shall be collected and accounted for separately by the board in the manner and form required by law, the Public Service Commission of West Virginia and/or the ordinances of the city. All disbursements and accounts of the system shall be ordered paid out only upon approval of the board from the appropriate separate account maintained for the stormwater system or the sanitary sewer system; provided however, that all supervision, management and control of the respective systems and the collection and accounting for bills for stormwater service and sanitary sewer service shall be consistent and in accordance with any ordinance pursuant to which the city may have authorized and issued any bonds from time to time which are outstanding, and which by their terms are payable from and secured by the revenues of either the stormwater system or the sanitary sewer system. The board shall have the power and authority to make all contracts and agreements, and to take any and all other actions necessary or proper for the full and complete supervision, management and control of the system. 
(Ord. of 6-23-14(1)) 
930.04 - EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR AND OTHER EMPLOYEES. 
    The board shall have power to employ, fix the compensation of and discharge an executive director of the system and shall direct, employ, fix the compensation of and discharge all other employees of the system. The executive director, upon his appointment and taking office, shall furnish and file with the city clerk, a bond in the amount of $50,000, the cost of such bond to be payable from revenues of the system and such bond shall be payable to the board and conditioned as to the faithful performance of the executive director's duties as are fixed by the board. 
(Ord. of 6-23-14(1)) 
930.05 - STORMWATER SYSTEM AND SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM ACCOUNTS; PERSONNEL POLICIES. 
    All assets and liabilities of the system, including accounts receivable and accounts payable, shall be under the management and control of the board. Personnel policies and practices and other matters affecting employees of the board, except pensions, shall be determined by the board. 
(Ord. of 6-23-14(1)) 
ARTICLE 933 - SEWER REGULATIONS AND CHARGES[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) ---
