(a)  The International Building Code 2015 adopted as the Official Building Code of the State of West Virginia, as promulgated by the State Fire Commission pursuant to W. Va. Code §§ 29-3-5b, 8-12-13, and 7-1-3n, as amended, together with any amendments and modifications thereto as may hereafter be adopted and promulgated from time to time by the Commission, is hereby adopted as the Official Building Code of the City. 
(b)  The City of Huntington does not adopt any of the additional appendices authorized pursuant to the W. Va. Legislative Rule identified as § 87-4-1, et seq. and specifically authorized in § 87-4-7(7.3). 
(c)  The City of Huntington does adopt the provisions of the national codes with respect to the penalty for imprisonment, but the penalty for any violation shall be limited to a maximum of $500 and/or 30 days imprisonment for any single violation. 
(d)  The City of Huntington does not reject the International Property Maintenance Code and hereby incorporates said Code in its adoption of the Official Building Code. 
(Ord. of 11-27-06; Ord. of 6-28-10(1); Ord. of 10-15-13(1); Ord. of 9-12-16(2) ) 
1711.02 - COMPLIANCE. 
    No person, firm, corporation or other entity shall fail, refuse or neglect to comply with the provisions of the Official Building Code of the city adopted by this article. The supervisor of building inspection shall have all those powers necessary to enforce the provisions of the Official Building Code of the city. 
(Ord. 4-28-03) 
1711.03 - COPIES. 
    One copy of the Official Building Code adopted by this article shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and the office of the division of building inspection and made available to the public for inspection and copying for a reasonable fee or charge. 
(Ord. 4-28-03) 
1711.04 - FIRE ZONES. 
    Deleted in its entirety. 
(Ord. 4-28-03) 
1711.05 - PERMIT REQUIRED. 
    Any owner or authorized agent who intends to construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish, or change the occupancy of a building or structure, or to erect, install, enlarge, alter, repair, remove, convert or replace any electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system, the installation of which is regulated by code, or to cause any such work to be done, shall first make application to the building official and obtain the required permit. 
(Ord. 12-27-05) 
1711.06 - NON-CONTRACTOR WORK EXEMPT FROM PERMIT. 
    Exemptions from permit requirements of this code shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the provisions of this code or any other laws or ordinances of this jurisdiction. Permits shall not be required of non-contractors for the following: 
(a)  Building. 
(1)  One story detached accessory structures used as tool and storage sheds, playhouses and similar uses, provided the floor area does not exceed 120 square feet. 
(2)  Fences not over six feet high. 
(3)  Oil derricks. 
(4)  Retaining walls which are not over four feet in height measured from the bottom of the footing to the top of the wall, unless supporting a surcharge or impounding Class I, II or II-A liquids. 
(5)  Water tanks supported directly on grade if the capacity does not exceed 5,000 gallons and the ratio of height to diameter or width does not exceed 2 to 1. 
(6)  Sidewalks and driveways not more than 30 inches above grade and not over any basement or story below which is not part of an accessible route. 
(7)  Painting, papering, tiling, carpeting, cabinets, counter tops and similar finish work. 
(8)  Temporary motion picture, television and theater stage sets and scenery. 
(9)  Prefabricated swimming pools accessory to a group R-3 occupancy, as applicable in section 101.2, which are less than 24 inches deep, do not exceed 5,000 gallons and are installed entirely above ground. 
(10)  Shade cloth structures constructed for nursery or agricultural purposes and not including service systems. 
(11)  Swings and other playground equipment accessory to detached one- and two-family dwellings. 
(12)  Window awnings supported by an exterior wall which do not project more than 54 inches from the exterior wall and do not require additional support of group R-3, as applicable in section 101.2 and group U occupancies. 
(13)  Movable cases, counters, and partitions not over five feet nine inches in height. 
(b)  Electrical. 
(1)  Minor repair work, including the replacement of lamps or connection of approved portable electrical equipment to approved permanently installed receptacles. 
(2)  The provisions of this code shall not apply to electrical equipment used for radio and television transmissions, but do not apply to equipment and wiring for power supply, the installation of towers and antennas. 
(3)  A permit shall not be required for the installation of any temporary system required for the testing or servicing of electrical equipment or apparatus. 
(c)  Gas. 
(1)  Portable heating appliance. 
(2)  Replacement of any minor part that does not alter approval of equipment or make such equipment unsafe. 
(d)  Mechanical. 
(1)  Portable heating appliance. 
(2)  Portable ventilating equipment. 
(3)  Portable cooling unit. 
(4)  Steam, hot or chilled water piping within any heating or cooling equipment regulated by code. 
(5)  Replacement of any part which does not alter its approval or make it unsafe. 
(6)  Portable evaporative cooler. 
(7)  Self-contained refrigeration system containing ten pounds or less of refrigerant and actuated by motors of one horsepower or less. 
(e)  Plumbing. 
(1)  The stopping of leaks in drains, water, soil, waste or vent pipe provided, however, that if any concealed trap, drain pipe, water, soil, waste or vent pipe becomes defective and it becomes necessary to remove and replace the same with new material, such work shall be considered as new work and a permit shall be obtained and inspection made as provided in this code. 
(2)  The clearing of stoppages or the repairing of leaks in pipes, valves or fixtures, and the removal and installation of water closets, provided such repairs do not involve or require the replacement or rearrangement of valves, pipes or fixtures. 
(Ord. 12-27-05) 
1711.07 - REPAIRS. 
    Application or notice to the building official is not required for ordinary repairs to structures, replacement of lamps or the connection of approved portable electrical equipment to approved permanently installed receptacles. Such repairs shall not include the cutting away of any wall, partition or portion thereof, the removal or cutting of any structural beam or load-bearing support, or the removal or change of any required means of egress or rearrangement of parts of a structure affecting the egress requirements; nor shall ordinary repairs include addition to, alteration of, replacement of or relocation of any standpipe, water supply, sewer drainage, drain leader, gas, soil, waste, vent or similar piping, electrical wiring or mechanical or other work affecting public health or general safety. 
(Ord. 12-27-05) 
1711.08 - FEES. 
    The fee schedule is set forth in Section 108.2 of the International Building Code 2000, and requires a fee for each plan examination, building permit and inspection shall be paid in accordance with the fee schedule as follows:

ARTICLE 1723 - UNIFORM HOUSING CODE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- By an Ordinance passed April 9, 1990, Council provided that the provisions of this article insofar as they conflict with the provisions of the West Virginia State Building Code adopted under Article 1711 are hereby repealed. 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Art. 1109; unsafe buildings, Art. 1739. 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, W. Va. Code, § 8-11-4; building enforcement agency, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-16. 

1723.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following abbreviations, terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall be construed as specified in this section. Terms, words, phrases and their derivatives used but not specifically defined in this article shall have the meaning defined in the Uniform Building Code. 
(a)  "Boardinghouse" means a lodginghouse in which meals are provided. 
(b)  "Ceiling height" means the clear vertical distance from the finished floor to the finished ceiling. 
(c)  "Dormitory" means a room occupied by more than two guests. 
(d)  "Dwelling unit" means a suite of two or more habitable rooms which are occupied or which are intended or designed to be occupied by one family with facilities for living, sleeping, cooking and dining. 
(e)  "Efficiency living unit" means any room having cooking facilities used for combined living, dining and sleeping purposes and meeting the requirements of Section H-503 (b), Exception, of the Uniform Building Code. 
(f)  "Guest" means any person hiring or occupying a room for living or sleeping purposes. 
(g)  "Guest room" means any room or rooms used, or intended to be used, by a guest for sleeping purposes. Every 100 square feet of superficial floor area in a dormitory is a guest room. 
(h)  "Habitable room" means any room meeting the requirements of this article for sleeping, living, cooking or dining purposes excluding such enclosed places as closets, pantries, bath or toilet rooms, service rooms, connection corridors, laundries, unfinished attics, foyers, storage, cellars, utility rooms and similar spaces. 
(i)  "Health officer" means the director of the Cabell-Huntington Health Department. 
(j)  "Hot water" means water at a temperature of not less than 120 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(k)  "Hotel" means any building containing six or more guest rooms intended or designed to be used, or which are used, rented or hired out to be occupied, or which are occupied for sleeping purposes by guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor or otherwise. It does not include any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, prison, detention home or other institutions in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. 
(l)  "Kitchen" means a room used or designed to be used for the preparation of food. 
(m)  "Lodginghouse" means any building or portion thereof containing not more than five guest rooms which are used by not more than five guests where rent is paid in money, goods, labor or otherwise. A lodginghouse shall comply with all of the requirements of this article for dwellings. 
(n)  "Nuisance". The following are defined as "nuisances": 
(1)  Any public nuisance known at common law or in equity jurisprudence. 
(2)  Any attractive nuisance which may prove detrimental to children whether in a building, on the premises of a building, or upon an unoccupied lot. This includes any abandoned wells, shafts, basements or excavations; abandoned refrigerators and motor vehicles; or any structurally unsound fences or structures; or any lumber, trash, fences, debris, or vegetation which may prove a hazard for inquisitive minors. 
(3)  Whatever is dangerous to human life or is detrimental to health, as determined by the Health Officer. 
(4)  Overcrowding a room with occupants. 
(5)  Insufficient ventilation or illumination. 
(6)  Inadequate or unsanitary sewerage or plumbing facilities. 
(7)  Uncleanliness, as determined by the health officer. 
(8)  Whatever renders air, food or drink unwholesome or detrimental to the health of human beings, as determined by the health officer. 
(o)  "Occupied space" means the total area of all buildings or structures on any lot or parcel of ground projected on a horizontal plane excluding permitted projections, as allowed by the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(p)  "Rooming house". See "lodginghouse." 
(q)  "Service room" means any room used for storage, bath or utility purposes, and not included in the definition of habitable rooms. 
(r)  "Superficial floor area" means the net floor area within the enclosing walls of the room in which the ceiling height is not less than five feet excluding built-in equipment such as wardrobes, cabinets, kitchen units or fixtures. 
(s)  "Uniform Building Code" means the city's Building Code, adopted by section 1711.01. 
(t)  "Used" means "used or designed or intended to be used." 
(u)  "Vent shaft" means a court used only to ventilate or light a water closet, bath, toilet or utility room or other service room. 
(v)  "Window" means a glazed opening, including glazed doors, which open upon a yard, court or recess from a court, or a vent shaft open and unobstructed to the sky. 
(w)  "Yard" means an open, unoccupied space, other than a court, unobstructed from the ground to the sky, except where specifically provided by the zoning ordinance of the city, on the lot on which a building is situated. 
(1964 Code Sec. 7-16) 
1723.02 - ADOPTION; HOUSING INSPECTOR. 
(a)  The Uniform Housing Code, 1985 Edition, promulgated by the International Conference of Building Officials, is hereby adopted by reference, insofar as such Uniform Housing Code is not in conflict with the laws of the state and of the city. 
(b)  For the purposes of effectuating this article only, the term "building official" shall mean the housing inspector. 
(c)  Insofar as the Uniform Housing Code, 1985 Edition, promulgated by the International Conference of Building Officials, conflicts with the Official Building Code adopted under article 1711, it is hereby repealed. 
(1964 Code Sec. 7-17; Ord. 2-22-88; Ord. 4-9-90) 
1723.03 - ENFORCEMENT AGENCY. 
    There shall be an enforcement agency which shall consist of the mayor, the housing inspector and one member at large, to be selected by and to serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor. The health officer and the fire chief shall serve as ex-officio members of such enforcement agency. The Housing Code enforcement agency shall have all those powers necessary and convenient to enforce the provisions of this article as well as those powers granted to the building official in the Uniform Housing Code. 
(1964 Code Sec. 7-18) 
1723.04 - AMENDMENTS. 
    The Uniform Housing Code, adopted by section 1723.02, is hereby amended as follows: 
(a)  Section 203 shall read as follows: 
In order to provide for reasonable interpretation of the provisions of this article, there is hereby created a housing advisory and appeals board, consisting of five members who are qualified by experience and training to pass upon matters pertaining to housing. The building official shall be an ex-officio member and shall act as secretary of the board. The housing advisory and appeals board shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall hold office at his pleasure. The board shall adopt reasonable rules and regulations for conducting its investigation and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the building official with a duplicate copy to the appellant and may recommend to the City Council such new legislation as is consistent therewith. 
(b)  Section 204 shall read as follows: 
No person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, lessee, sublessee or occupant, shall erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, demolish, equip, use, occupy or maintain any building or premises, or cause or permit the same to be done, contrary to or in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any order issued by the building official hereunder. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in Section 1705.99 of the Codified Ordinances. 
(c)  Section 301 shall read as follows: 
No person, firm or corporation shall erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move or demolish any building or structure or cause or permit the same to be done without first obtaining a separate building permit for each such building or structure from the building official in the manner and according to the applicable conditions prescribed in the Uniform Building Code; providing that no person, firm or corporation shall be granted a permit for the purpose of demolishing any building or structure until such person, firm or corporation shall have paid a minimum fee to the Department of Public Works in the amount Of: Single Family Residence one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); Commercial, Industrial, Multi-Family Residential one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) plus $0.05/square feet of floor space, to cover cost of inspections, and shall have caused to be filed with the Building Official, a public liability policy of insurance issued by an insurance company licensed and authorized to do business in the State, the limits of such policy to be not less than two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) for an injury to any person, not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for all injuries in any one accident and two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) for property damage which may be sustained by any person as a result of the issuance of such permit. If a re-inspection is required, a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) will apply. Permits will be valid for thirty (30) days. Extensions may be granted as the discretion of the Public Works Director. Costs of an extension shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). Extermination treatment shall be done when, in the opinion of the Health Officer or his authorized representative, there is a suspected infestation of rodents, roaches, vermin, insects or other pests in or on the premises to be demolished. Extermination treatment shall be done only by a reputable bonded exterminator at least ten days before demolition commences and such extermination treatment shall be carried out with the utmost safety precautions to protect children, persons, and domestic animals by properly sealing the premises being exterminated and only approved insecticides, rodenticides or any other methods approved by the Health Officers shall be used. Upon completion of such extermination treatment, demolition or removal, the Director of Public Works shall cause an inspection of the premises to be made, and if such work is found be unsatisfactory, the permittee shall be subject to the criminal provisions found in Sections 1723.08 and 1705.99. 
(Ord. of 5-28-02; Ord. of 7-28-14(1)) 
1723.05 - UTILITY SERVICE TO VACANT DWELLING. 
    No person shall provide, or permit another to provide, utility services such as water, gas, electricity, sewerage or similar services to any vacant substandard dwelling unit until such dwelling unit has been inspected, brought into compliance with the Codified Ordinances and the Uniform Housing Code, hereinbefore mentioned, and a valid certificate of occupancy, as required, has been issued; provided, however, the building official shall permit the temporary use of such utility service as may be necessary for repair or alteration of a vacant substandard dwelling unit and shall, in writing, notify the supplier of such utility service of the time during which and the conditions under which such temporary service may be furnished. 
(1964 Code Sec. 7-20) 
1723.06 - REPAIR OF SUBSTANDARD DWELLING; PERMIT. 
    No building, plumbing, electrical, gas or other permit required by the Codified Ordinances or the Uniform Building Code, hereinbefore mentioned, for the alteration or repair of an existing substandard unit shall be issued until the building official or other designated employee of the city has made an inspection of the property to determine the feasibility of such alteration or repair and shall have issued a statement, in writing, to the effect that the proposed alteration or repair of such substandard dwelling unit is feasible. 
(1964 Code Sec. 7-21) 
1723.07 - RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNER. 
    Every owner remains liable for violations of duties imposed upon him by this article even though an obligation is also imposed on the occupants of his building, and even though the owner has, by agreement, imposed on the occupant the duty of furnishing required equipment or of complying with this article. 
    Every owner or his agent, in addition to being responsible for maintaining his building in a sound structural condition, shall be responsible for keeping that part of the building or premises which he occupies or controls in a clean, sanitary and safe condition, including the shared or public areas in a building containing two or more dwelling units. 
    Every owner shall, where required by this article, the health ordinances of the city or the health officer, furnish and maintain such approved sanitary facilities as required, and shall furnish and maintain approved devices, equipment or facilities for the prevention of insect and rodent infestation, and where infestation has taken place, shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests when such extermination is not specifically made the responsibility of the occupant by law or ruling. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling unit, in addition to being responsible for keeping in a clean, sanitary and safe condition that part of the dwelling or dwelling unit or premises which he occupies and controls, shall dispose of all his rubbish, garbage and other organic waste in a manner required by the health ordinances of the city and approved by the health officer. 
(1964 Code Sec. 7-22) 
1723.08 - VIOLATIONS. 
    No person shall erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, convert, demolish, equip, use, occupy or maintain any building or structure in the city or cause or permit the same to be done contrary to or in violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(1964 Code Sec. 7-32) 
1723.99 - PENALTY. 
    Commencement of work prior to obtaining a permit will result in a doubling of the cost of the permit. Said persons who begin work without obtaining a permit will also be subject to the fines as outlined in section 1705.99 of the Building and Housing Code. 
(Ord. 5-28-02) 
ARTICLE 1731 - ELECTRICAL STANDARDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, W. Va. Code, § 8-11-4; authority to regulate electrical wiring standards, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-13(2); certification of electricians, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-14a; municipal inspection, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-15. 

1731.01 - APPOINTMENT OF CHIEF ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR. 
    There is hereby created the office of chief electrical inspector who shall hereinafter be referred to as the electrical inspector. The mayor shall appoint the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.02 - QUALIFICATIONS OF CHIEF ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR. 
    The person chosen to fill the office of chief electrical inspector shall be a competent electrician of good moral character, and have at least ten years' experience in electrical construction and shall be possessed of such executive ability as is required for the faithful performance of his duties, and shall have a thorough knowledge of standard materials and methods used in the installation of electrical wiring, devices, appliances and equipment. He shall be well versed in approved methods of electrical construction for safety to life and property, the laws of the state and ordinances of the city relating to electrical work, the rules and regulations issued under authority of the statutes, the National Electrical Code, the National Electrical Safety Code and the provisions of other installation and safety codes approved by the National Fire Protection Association. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.03 - CHIEF ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR NOT TO ENGAGE IN ELECTRICAL BUSINESS. 
    Neither the chief electrical inspector nor any of his assistants or agents shall engage in the business or sale, installation or maintenance of electric wiring, devices, appliances or equipment, either directly or indirectly, nor shall such persons have any financial interest in any concern engaged in such business in the city at any time during the chief electrical inspector's term of office. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.04 - ENFORCEMENT OF CHAPTER. 
    The chief electrical inspector shall see that the provisions of this article are enforced and shall enforce within the city the laws of the state and other ordinances of the city relating to the installation of electric wiring, devices, appliances and equipment. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.05 - RECORDS. 
Editor's note- Former Section 1731.05 was repealed by Ordinance 1-27-97, passed January 27, 1997. 
1731.06 - LIST OF APPROVED ELECTRICAL APPLIANCES. 
Editor's note- Former Section 1731.06 was repealed by Ordinance 1-27-97, passed January 27, 1997. 
1731.07 - PERMITS FOR INSTALLATION OR ALTERATION OF ELECTRICAL WIRING. 
Editor's note- Former Section 1731.07 was repealed by Ordinance 1-27-97, passed January 27, 1997. 
1731.08 - INSPECTION; USE OF ELECTRICAL INSTALLATION BEFORE INSPECTION; INSPECTION FEES. 
    All electrical wiring, apparatus and appliances hereafter installed in the city, shall be inspected by the chief electrical inspector. No person shall use any new electrical installation in any building before the same has been inspected and approved by the chief electrical inspector. For making such inspections, the city shall be entitled to charge and receive from the owner of property inspection fees in accordance with the schedule of such fees set out in the Official Building Code of the city. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.09 - NOTICE OF INTENTION TO INSTALL WIRING OR TO MAKE ALTERATIONS REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS. 
    No electric wiring, devices, appliances or equipment shall be installed within or on any building, structure or premises, nor shall any alterations be made in any such existing wiring, devices, appliances or equipment without notifying the electrical inspector, except as stated in the following paragraphs: 
(a)  No inspection shall be required for minor repair work such as repairing flush and snap switches, replacing fuses, changing lamp sockets and receptacles, taping joints and repairing drop cords or appliances, providing the appliance can be installed without additions to electric wiring. 
(b)  No inspection shall be required for the installation of wiring, devices or equipment for telephone, telegraph, district messenger or telegraph systems or any signalling system, other than radio systems, operating at 50 volts or less. 
(c)  No inspection shall be required for maintenance and repair work on the premises of a firm or corporation regularly employing one or more journeymen electricians for the purpose. 
(d)  No inspection shall be required for the installation of electric wiring, devices or equipment installed for or by a public utility corporation operating under a franchise from the city to transmit and sell or use electrical energy, provided such wiring, devices or equipment are for use of the corporation in its operation as a public utility and installed in accordance with all other provisions of this article. 
(e)  No inspection shall be required for the installation of household appliances that have been approved by Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., where the appliance can be plugged into the existing receptacle, provided the installation of the appliance meets the requirements of the National Electrical Code. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.10 - APPLICATIONS FOR ELECTRICAL INSPECTION SERVICE. 
Editor's note- Former Section 1731.10 was repealed by Ordinance 1-27-97, passed January 27, 1997. 
1731.11 - CHIEF ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR'S RIGHT OF ENTRY. 
    The chief electrical inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building or premises in the discharge of his official duties, or for the purpose of making any inspection, reinspection or test of the electrical equipment contained therein or its installation. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.12 - SCHEDULE OF INSPECTION FEES. 
    Before any permit is granted for the installation or alteration of electric wiring, or devices, appliances or equipment, the person making application for such permit shall pay to the city a fee in such amount as specified in the schedule of fees as set forth in the Official Building Code of the city. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.13 - WHEN INSPECTION FEES TO BE PAID. 
Editor's note- Former Section 1731.13 was repealed by Ordinance 1-27-97, passed January 27, 1997. 
1731.14 - REPAIR OF DEFECTIVE ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT OR EQUIPMENT DEFECTIVELY INSTALLED. 
Editor's note- Former Section 1731.14 was repealed by Ordinance 1-27-97, passed January 27, 1997. 
1731.15 - DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE. 
    The chief electrical inspector shall have the authority to order the discontinuance of electric service supply to defective electrical equipment or electrical equipment that is defectively installed. In cases where the immediate disconnection of electrical equipment is necessary for the safety of persons or property, or where electrical equipment may interfere with the work of the fire department, the chief electrical inspector shall have the authority to order the immediate discontinuance of electric service supply to such electrical equipment. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.16 - COMPLIANCE WITH OFFICIAL BUILDING CODE OF THE CITY. 
    All electrical wiring and installation of electrical apparatus and appliances for furnishing light, heat and power, done in the city, shall comply in all respects with the rules and regulations of the Official Building Code of the city, as set forth in article 1711 of these Codified Ordinances. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.17 - WORK DONE BY OWNER OF DWELLING. 
    Nothing is this article shall prevent any property owner of an owner/occupied dwelling from installing or maintaining electrical wiring, devices, appliances and equipment within his own dwellling providing such work shall be done by himself and does not otherwise violate this article. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
1731.18 - BOARD OF APPEALS. 
    Any person aggrieved by the enforcement against him of any of the provisions of this article shall have the right of appeal to the board of appeals. Application for such appeal shall be made to the board of appeals, in writing, within ten days from the date of such alleged adverse decision. 
(Ord. 1-27-97) 
ARTICLE 1735 - PLUMBING REGULATIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted December 9, 2013, amended article 1735 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article 1735, §§ 1735.01-1735.37, pertained to similar subject matter. See Comparative Section Table for complete derivation. 

1735.01 - PURPOSE OF ARTICLE. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide minimum plumbing standards to safeguard life, health, property and public welfare by regulating and controlling the design, construction and quality of materials used in all plumbing systems within the city. Section 1735.10 is considered a basic concept of this article and the proper functioning of the code of board appeals is as essential as the standards included herein. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.02 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purposes of this article the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
(a)  "Plumber (apprentice)" means a person who is undergoing an apprenticeship or course of training, of not less than five years, for the purpose of learning the trade of plumbing. An apprentice, as herein defined, shall perform no work regulated by this article or amendments thereto, except as an assistant under the direct supervision of a master plumber, and in the immediate presence of a qualified master plumber or qualified journeyman plumber. 
(b)  "Plumber (journeyman)" means a person who is skilled in the work of installing and maintaining plumbing, drainage, gas fittings and special waste, under the direction, of a master plumber; and who has served at least five years time as an apprentice at the trade of plumbing. 
(c)  "Plumber (master)" means a person who maintains an established place of business for contracting, selling and installation of plumbing, gas piping and drainage work; who is skilled in the planning, superintending, practical installation and maintenance of plumbing and drainage; who obtains necessary permits; and who has served at least two years time as a licensed journeyman plumber. 
Additional definitions are found in Chapter 2 of the Plumbing Code. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.03 - CERTIFICATE OF COMPETENCY REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS. 
    A certificate of competency will not be required for: 
(a)  A property owner performing work as set forth in section 1735.17. 
(b)  Qualified employees of public utilities under the jurisdiction of the state public service commission when performing work for the employer. 
(c)  Qualified employees of manufacturing or chemical processing concerns when performing work for the employer. 
(d)  Qualified employees of firms or establishments engaged in selling and installing appliances, heating or air conditioning where a normal connection to an existing supply line is made. A normal connection is to be construed as being five feet or less in length to a supply line which is already existing in the room where the installation is being performed. 
    The items of appliances covered under this provision shall be designated by the director of public works. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.04-1735.10 - RESERVED. 
1735.11 - ESTABLISHMENT OF PERMANENT UTILITY SERVICE. 
    Gas or water utility companies shall not provide permanent meter connections to supply water or gas to any new or remodeled building until a proper notification from the plumbing inspector that water, gas, soil, waste, sewer and vent piping has complied with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.12 - PLACE OF BUSINESS OF MASTER PLUMBER. 
    Every certified master plumber shall have a bona-fide place of business, and shall display on the front of his place of business a sign, "Registered master plumber," bearing the name or names of the person in letters not less than three inches high. Such place of business shall be open to the public during regular business hours, and the master plumber's certificate shall be prominently displayed in such place of business. Vehicles used in the conduct of such business shall display on each side a sign bearing the name or names of the person, and the word "Registered" in letters not less than three inches high. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.13 - APPLICABILITY OF ARTICLE. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all plumbing work performed after February 25, 1965, subject to the exceptions outlined in section 106.2 of the Plumbing Code as set forth in the BOCA National Building Code, current edition as adopted by city ordinance, said Code being the Official Building Code of the city. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.14 - CHIEF PLUMBING INSPECTOR; APPOINTMENT; ASSISTANT. 
    Subject to necessary appropriations by council, the mayor shall appoint one competent person to be known as chief plumbing inspector and such assistants as may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this article. Such plumbing inspector and assistant plumbing inspectors shall be a bona-fide registered master or journeyman plumber with at least five years experience and who maintains a residence in the city. Such chief plumbing inspector and assistants shall satisfactorily pass an examination as set up by the board of plumbing examiners. The chief plumbing inspector and assistant plumbing inspectors shall have no interest in the plumbing industry except in the official capacity of plumbing inspector. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.16 - PERMITS REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS. 
    Before any plumbing, drainage or sewer work is undertaken in connection with any structure within the city, a permit for such work shall be secured by the master plumber or the owner or his agent as outlined in section 107.3 of the BOCA Code. Before a permit is issued which involves plumbing work, the drawings will be reviewed and approved by the chief plumbing inspector; provided, however, that no such permit shall be required for repairs to existing plumbing fixtures such as replacement of parts, stoppage of leaks, removal of stoppage and obstructions in drain lines, replacement of pipes and fixtures where no change in the location of the supply or drain line is involved. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.17 - PERMIT NOT REQUIRED FOR WORK DONE BY PROPERTY OWNER; EXCEPTIONS. 
    Nothing in this article shall prevent any property owner of an owner-occupied dwelling from installing or maintaining plumbing within his own dwelling, providing such work is performed by himself. Such privilege does not convey the right to violate any provision of this article. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.18 - PROCEDURE FOR OBTAINING PERMITS; FEES. 
    Permits for all plumbing work shall be obtained as outlined in Section 107.0, Application for Permit of the BOCA Code. The master plumber who will do all plumbing work must be identified on the permit application. Permits will not be issued without a master plumber being identified. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.27 - REPAIR OR INSTALLATION OF HOUSE SEWER. 
    No person other than a master plumber or his employee duly certificated under the requirements of this article shall establish, repair or discontinue any sewer or drain connection to any public sanitary, combination or storm sewer. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.28 - SEWER TAPPING PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION. 
    No master plumber or his employee shall establish a new connection to any public sanitary, combination or storm sewer without first making application to the sanitary board for a sewer tapping permit. 
    Such application shall specify the exact location of the point at which the public sewer is to be tapped and the name of the owner of the property to be served by the sewer or drain connection. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.29 - BACKFILLING SEWER. 
    No sewer in any street or alley or on private property shall be backfilled until the chief plumbing inspector shall have made an inspection of the sewer tap and the new branch piping. Upon issuance of a certificate of approval by the chief plumbing inspector, the master plumber may properly backfill and cover the sewer. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.30 - SEWER TAP FEES. 
    Fees for sewer taps shall be paid in the amounts specified, and in accordance with the procedure established in section 1735.18 of this article. Such fees shall be paid directly to the sanitary board. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.31 - UNAUTHORIZED USE OF SEWER TAP PERMIT. 
    No master plumber shall obtain a sewer tapping permit unless he is to perform the work himself or under his supervision. Assignment of such permit to another person will subject the master plumber to revocation of his certificate. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.32, 1735.33 - RESERVED. 
1735.34 - CONFORMITY WITH REGULATIONS. 
    No person shall engage in the business of plumbing or do work at the trade of plumbing in the city, or outside the boundaries of the city, if such plumbing is or will be connected to the municipal sewerage system, except in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.35 - BOCA PLUMBING CODE ADOPTED. 
    The Plumbing Code contained in the Official Building Code of the city as set forth in article 1711 of these Codified Ordinances, shall, in all respects, be strictly observed, followed and enforced by the chief plumbing inspector. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.36 - INTERPRETATION OF ARTICLE. 
    It is the intention of this article that interpretation of the provisions of this article shall be the responsibility of the code official. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
1735.37 - NONCONFORMITY WITH ARTICLE. 
    No person shall perform any plumbing which does not conform to or exceed the minimum requirements of material, design and installation as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. of 12-9-13(1)) 
ARTICLE 1739 - UNSAFE BUILDINGS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted September 25, 2017, repealed the former Art. 1739, §§ 1739.01-1739.99, and enacted a new Art. 1739 as set out herein. The former Art. 1739 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Cross reference- Burnt structures, Art. 539; public nuisances, § 1109.01. 
State Law reference- Building enforcement agency, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-16. 

1739.01 - DECLARATION. 
    It is hereby declared that any dwelling or other building that is unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous or detrimental to the public safety or welfare whether used for human habitation or not, shall be subject to regulation by the City of Huntington and may be abated by repair, alteration or improvement, or the vacating and closing or removal or demolition, or any combination thereof, as provided in this article. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.02 - DEFINITIONS. 
(a)  "Code enforcement agency" means the inspections division and/or the unsafe buildings commission. 
(b)  "Code enforcement agency official" means any lawful agent of a code enforcement agency, including, but not limited to, any city inspector, fire marshal, or health officer. 
(c)  "Inspections division" for the purposes of this article shall include all building inspectors, electrical inspectors, plumbing inspectors, and fire marshals for the City of Huntington. 
(d)  "Owner" or "landowner" means a person who individually or jointly with others: 
(1)  Has legal title to the property, with or without actual possession of the property; 
(2)  Has charge, care or control of the property as owner or agent-of the owner; 
(3)  Is an executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner; 
(4)  Is the agent of the owner for the purpose of managing, controlling or collecting rents; or 
(5)  May control or direct the management or disposition of the property. 
(e)  "Remediate" or "remediation" may mean either the repair or demolition of an unsafe building. 
(f)  "Unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous or detrimental to the public safety or welfare" means: 
(1)  Any door, aisle, passageway, stairway, exit or other means of egress that does not conform to the approved building or fire code of the jurisdiction as related to the requirements for existing buildings; 
(2)  The walking surface of any aisle, passageway, stairway, exit or other means of egress is so warped, worn loose, torn or otherwise unsafe as to not provide safe and adequate means of egress; 
(3)  Any portion of a dwelling, building, structure or appurtenance that has been damaged by fire, earthquake, wind, flood, deterioration, neglect, abandonment, vandalism or by any other cause to an extent that it is likely to partially or completely collapse, or to become detached or dislodged; 
(4)  Any portion of a structure or building, or any member, appurtenance or ornamentation on the exterior that is not of sufficient strength or stability, or is not so anchored, attached or fastened in place so as to be capable of resisting natural or artificial loads of one and one-half the original designed value; 
(5)  The dwelling, building or structure, or part of the building or structure, because of dilapidation, deterioration, decay, faulty construction, the removal or movement of some portion of the ground necessary for the support, or for any other reason, is likely to partially or completely collapse, or some portion of the foundation or underpinning of the building or structure is likely to fail or give way; 
(6)  The dwelling, building or structure, or any portion, is clearly unsafe for its use; 
(7)  The dwelling, building or structure is neglected, damaged, dilapidated, unsecured or abandoned so as to become an attractive nuisance to children, becomes a harbor for vagrants, criminals, criminal activity or enables persons to resort to the dwelling, building or structure for committing a nuisance or an unlawful act; 
(8)  Any dwelling, building or structure constructed, exists or maintained in violation of any specific requirement or prohibition applicable to any dwelling, building or structure provided by the approved building or fire code of the jurisdiction or of any law or ordinance that presents either a substantial risk of fire, building collapse or any other threat to life and safety; 
(9)  A dwelling, building or structure, used or intended to be used for dwelling purposes, because of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, decay, contamination by any hazardous substance or material including, but not limited to, substance resulting from the illegal manufacture of drugs, damage, faulty construction or arrangement, inadequate light, ventilation, mechanical or plumbing system, or otherwise, is determined by the code enforcement agency to be unsanitary, unfit for human habitation or in such a condition that is likely to cause sickness or disease; 
(10)  Any dwelling, building or structure, because of a lack of sufficient or proper fire resistance-rated construction, fire protection systems, electrical system, fuel connections, mechanical system, plumbing system or other cause, is determined by the code official to be a threat to life or health; or 
(11)  Any portion of a building that remains on a site after the demolition or destruction of the building or structure, or whenever any building or structure is abandoned. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.03 - APPLICATION. 
    This article shall only apply to such dwellings, structures or buildings which meet the definition of unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous, or detrimental to the public safety or welfare as set forth in subsections (a) or (b) below: 
(a)  A dwelling, structure or building shall be deemed unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous, or detrimental to the public safety or welfare if any one of the following definitions are met: 
(1)  Any portion of a dwelling, building, structure or appurtenance that has been damaged by fire, earthquake, wind, flood, deterioration, neglect, abandonment, vandalism or by any other cause to an extent that it is likely to partially or completely collapse, or to become detached or dislodged; 
(2)  The dwelling, building or structure, or part of the building or structure, because of dilapidation, deterioration, decay, faulty construction, the removal or movement of some portion of the ground necessary for the support, or for any other reason, is likely to partially or completely collapse, or some portion of the foundation or underpinning of the building or structure is likely to fail or give way; 
(3)  Any dwelling, building or structure constructed, exists or maintained in violation of any specific requirement or prohibition applicable to any dwelling, building or structure provided by the approved building or fire code of the jurisdiction or of any law or ordinance that presents either a substantial risk of fire, building collapse or any other threat to life and safety. 
(b)  Alternatively, a dwelling, structure or building shall be deemed unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous, or detrimental to the public safety or welfare when subsections (1), (2), and (3), as set forth below, are met: 
(1)  The dwelling, building or structure meets any one of the following definitions: 
(A)  The dwelling, building or structure, or any portion, is clearly unsafe for its use; 
(B)  The dwelling, building or structure is neglected, damaged, dilapidated, unsecured or abandoned so as to become an attractive nuisance to children, becomes a harbor for vagrants, criminals, criminal activity or enables persons to resort to the dwelling, building or structure for committing a nuisance or an unlawful act; 
(C)  A dwelling, building or structure, used or intended to be used for dwelling purposes, because of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, decay, contamination by any hazardous substance or material including, but not limited to, substance resulting from the illegal manufacture of drugs, damage, faulty construction or arrangement, inadequate light, ventilation, mechanical or plumbing system, or otherwise, is determined by the code enforcement agency to be unsanitary, unfit for human habitation or in such a condition that is likely to cause sickness or disease; 
(D)  Any portion of a building that remains on a site after the demolition or destruction of the building or structure, or whenever any building or structure is abandoned. 
(2)  The building is (A) vacant, (B) abandoned, or (C) has been lawfully declared unfit for human habitation; and 
(3)  The reasonable estimated cost of repair, rehabilitation or corrective action exceeds the fair market value of the building. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.04 - UNSAFE BUILDINGS COMMISSION. 
    There is hereby created an enforcement agency to be known as the unsafe buildings commission. Such agency shall be composed of the mayor or his or her designee, the chief building inspector, the chief electrical inspector, the chief plumbing inspector, the City of Huntington Fire Chief, the City of Huntington Police Chief or designee, a sanitation officer from the Cabell-Huntington Health Department and one member at large, to be selected by and to serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor. The fire chief may designate the fire marshal to serve upon the commission in his or her stead. In the event any member is unable to attend a regular or special meeting of the commission, the mayor may designate and appoint an alternate member to serve in the absent member's place at such meeting. The mayor shall serve as chairperson, or may designate a chairperson, and a majority of the commission shall constitute a quorum. A permanent record shall be kept in the planning and development office and shall be open to inspection by any party in interest. The commission shall have the authority to make rules and regulations, not contrary to law, for the purpose of carrying out the intent of this article. 
    The purpose of the unsafe buildings commission is to act as an instrument of oversight for the repair, alteration, improvement, vacating and closing, or removal or demolition, or any combinations thereof, of dwellings, buildings, structures, or appurtenances that have been deemed unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous or detrimental to the public safety or welfare by the inspections division. Except in emergency situations as otherwise provided in this code or in state law, the authority to order a dwelling, building, structure, or appurtenance to be vacated and closed, removed or demolished rests solely with the unsafe building commission. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.05 - INSTIGATION OF INSPECTION. 
    Upon reasonably reliable notice of the potentially unsafe or unsanitary condition of a dwelling, structure, or building, a code enforcement agency official shall conduct an outdoor visual inspection from the right of way to determine whether an on-site and/or indoor inspection is necessary. When an on-site and/or indoor inspection is deemed necessary, code enforcement agency official shall conduct such inspection in accordance with subsection 1739.06 herein. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.06 - RIGHT OF INSPECTION. 
    In order to perform its duties effectively and protect the public interest, a member of the code enforcement agency, or any person delegated by the code enforcement agency for the purposes of this article, shall have authority to go upon and inspect any dwelling or other building or any part thereof, provided, that such entrance and inspection shall be made in such a manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession and shall be consistent with the following: 
(1)  Except in exigent circumstances and as permitted by law, the enforcement agency shall provide reasonable advance notice to the owner and request permission from the owner to enter the property. 
(2)  If the owner cannot be located after reasonable inquiry by the code enforcement agency as required by this section, or if the owner refuses entry, the code enforcement agency may obtain an administrative search warrant from either the municipal court or the magistrate court located in the jurisdiction of the municipality or county where the structure, dwelling or building is located. Before obtaining an administrative search warrant, a code enforcement agency official is required to make a sworn statement and prima facie case showing that the code enforcement agency was unable to gain access to the structure, dwelling or building after reasonable and good faith efforts, and that there is a legitimate and substantial safety concern involving the structure, dwelling or building that supports the requested entry. 
(3)  If granted by the court, and if the owner can be located, the code enforcement agency shall provide the owner a copy of the administrative search warrant five days before entering the property. If applicable, the code enforcement agency shall also provide the same notice to any tenant or other person in possession of the structure, dwelling or building. 
(4)  Entry is for the sole purpose of inspection of the structure, dwelling or building for unsafe or unsanitary conditions and not for the purpose of criminal prosecution or gathering evidence for use in any criminal charge or proceeding unrelated to the unsafe or unsanitary condition of the structure, dwelling or building. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.07 - REMEDIATION OF UNSAFE BUILDINGS. 
(1)  If, upon inspection, the inspections division determines a dwelling, structure or building is unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous or detrimental to the public safety or welfare as set forth herein, the member of the Inspections Division shall provide lawful notice to the owner of the condition(s) and provide a list of actions needed and a reasonable timeline for completion. 
(2)  If an owner: 
(a)  Fails to cause the remediation of the structure within the given time for completion, or 
(b)  Does not agree to remediate the unsafe building, the supervisor of the inspections division shall recommend the unsafe building for hearing before the unsafe buildings commission. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.08 - NOTICE TO OWNERS TO SECURE AND STABILIZE A VACANT AND/OR ABANDONED STRUCTURE OR BUILDING. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this article, whenever a building is deemed by the inspections division to be unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous or detrimental to the public safety or welfare, as defined herein, a code official or the fire marshal may require the owner of said real property to secure the structure or building in a manner fitting with the condition of the building prior to any determination by the unsafe buildings commission. Said code official or fire marshal shall provide the owner with a written description of the method of securing the subject dwelling or building deemed appropriate for the circumstances. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.09 - HEARING BEFORE COMMISSION. 
(1)  Upon the recommendation of the supervisor of the inspections division, the unsafe buildings commission may issue a complaint against any building deemed by the inspections division to be unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous or detrimental to the public safety or welfare, as defined herein, and the owner thereof. Such complaint shall definitely locate the building, shall describe the conditions complained of and shall set a date and place for a hearing. Any complaint or order shall be served upon the owner in accordance with this article. 
(2)  At such hearing, the owner may appear in person or by agents or counsel, and may examine any witnesses who testify and may offer evidence in his own behalf. Either the commission or the owner may have the entire evidence recorded at their own expense, however, such shall not be mandatory. A lessee whose interests are substantially affected may appear and be heard in the same manner as the owner. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.10 - FINDINGS; ORDERS; PERFORMANCE. 
(a)  If the majority of the members of the unsafe buildings commission present at such hearing commission find that any dwelling, structure, or building meets the criteria for an unsafe building set in subsection 1739.03 herein, and the owner requests time to remediate the property, the commission may grant a continuance to the owner under the following circumstances: 
(1)  In order for the commission to grant a continuance of the hearing to provide time for an owner to remediate the unsafe building, the owner or agent must provide documentary evidence of the remediation plan to the commission. If documentary evidence is not provided, the commission may grant one 30-day continuance for the purposes of providing documentary evidence. Acceptable documentary evidence includes, but is not limited to, designs, contractor agreements, and receipts of materials purchased for the remediation. Evidence of a valid building permit or demolition permit shall be required in order to receive a continuance from the commission every time a continuance is requested unless the supervisor of building inspections represents that one is not required for the work to be performed. A building permit alone shall not be considered acceptable documentary evidence and no additional time shall be granted based solely on the acquisition of a building permit or demolition permit. 
(2)  If an owner request time to perform remediation and supplies documentary evidence adequate to convince the commission that said remediation is impending, the commission may grant a reasonable continuance not to exceed six months. At each continued hearing, the owner must provide additional documentary evidence showing the progress of the remediation in order to obtain another continuance. 
(3)  If, at any lawfully noticed or continued hearing, the owner fails to appear or fails to provide the required additional documentary evidence, the commission may use any and all powers within its authority to remediate the unsafe building including but not limited to causing such work to be done either by contract or by the purchase of necessary materials and the employment of workers and equipment. 
(b)  If the majority of the members of the commission present at such hearing find that any dwelling, structure, or building meets the criteria for an unsafe building set in subsection 1739.03 herein, and that lawful notice was provided to the owner, and reasonable efforts were undertaken to seek agreement from the owner prior to taking action, regardless of whether the owner appears at the hearing, the commission has the power to order the vacating, closing, removal or demolition of the subject dwelling, structure or building by the municipality in the absence of owner agreement or court order. 
(c)  Any order issued by the commission shall include the following: 
(1)  The date of the last inspection, 
(2)  The name of the inspector, 
(3)  A reasonable description of the unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous, or detrimental condition(s), 
(4)  The corrective measures required, 
(5)  The allotted time permitted to correct, and 
(6)  The allotted time to apply to circuit court for a temporary injunction. 
(d)  Within 15 days of issuing an order, the commission shall cause such order to be filed with the county clerk of the county in which the property is located. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.11 - INJUNCTION; HEARING BY CIRCUIT COURT. 
(a)  The owner of the property shall have the right to apply to the circuit court of the county for a temporary injunction restraining the unsafe buildings commission pending final disposition of the cause. In the event such application is made, a hearing thereon shall be had within 20 days, or as soon thereafter as possible, and the court shall enter such final order or decree as the law and justice may require. 
(b)  Continuances of the hearing provided for in this subsection may be made for cause only. If a continuance is granted upon request by the owner, the owner is required to pay into court, in the form of a bond, any reasonable and necessary costs related to the property likely to be incurred by the municipality during the continuance. 
(c)  At the conclusion of a hearing held under this subsection, if the court finds that the property is unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous, or detrimental to the public safety or welfare, the court shall make and enter an order granting the relief as requested by the municipality. The court may disburse any moneys paid into court by the owner in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.12 - NOTICE. 
(a)  Any complaint or order issued by the commission shall be noticed as follows: 
(1)  By conspicuously posting and attaching a copy of the complaint or order to the subject property; and 
(2)  By serving the complaint or order upon the owner or landowner in accordance with the law of the State of West Virginia concerning the service of process in civil actions, except that personal service of a complaint or order may be made by a code enforcement agency official. If service is made by certified mail under Rule 4(d)(1)(D) of the West Virginia Rules of Civil Procedure and delivery of the complaint or order is refused, the code enforcement agency official, promptly upon the receipt of the notice of the refusal, shall mail to the person or entity being noticed, by first class mail, postage prepaid, a copy of the summons and complaint. If the first class mailing is not returned as undeliverable by the U.S. Postal Service, service of the complaint or order is presumed to have been effectuated. 
Upon service of the complaint or order consistent with this subsection, the violation may be prosecuted consistent with state and local law. 
(b)  If the code enforcement agency cannot effect personal service on the owner, a code enforcement agency official shall subscribe a written affidavit, to be maintained for a minimum of two years, that demonstrates the structure, dwelling or building falls within one of the categories set forth in section 1739.03 of this article sets forth the basis in reasonable detail including documentation of same, and memorializes the code enforcement agency official's efforts to contact or get permission for entry and corrective action from the owner; and the code enforcement agency shall publish notice of its intent to enter the property for the purpose of demolition or correction, along with the address of the property, the name of the owner(s) and the date of the proposed action, as a class II legal advertisement consistent with the requirements of W. Va. ch. 59, art. 3, § 2, the first of which shall run at least thirty days before the date of the proposed action by the enforcement agency, and the last being no later than 20 days before the date of the proposed action by the enforcement agency. 
(c)  If there is no response to the notice by the owner or landowner in the time specified in the notice, then the municipality shall have the authority to proceed in correction or demolition of the subject dwelling, building or structure. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.13 - ASSESSING AND COLLECTING COSTS. 
(a)  Liens. The owner or owners of any dwelling or building under determination of the state fire marshal, as provided in W. Va. Code, § 29-3-12, or under order of the code enforcement agency shall pay for the costs of repairing, altering, or improving or vacating and closing, removing or demolishing any dwelling or building. 
Within 90 days of the completion of any remediation work performed by the municipality, the code enforcement agency shall file a lien against the real property in question for an amount that reflects all costs incurred by the municipality for repairing, altering or improving, or of vacating and closing, removing or demolishing any dwelling or building. 
(b)  Civil actions to recover costs. The municipality has the right to institute a civil action in circuit court against the landowner or other responsible party to get an order to take corrective action up to and including demolition of any structure, dwelling or building that is unsafe, unsanitary, dangerous or detrimental to the public safety or welfare; and to recover all reasonable costs and expenses incurred by the municipality with respect to the property and for reasonable attorney fees and court costs incurred in the prosecution of the action: 
(1)  Not less than ten days prior to instituting a civil action as provided for in this section, the municipality shall send notice to the landowner by certified mail, return receipt requested, advising the landowner of the governing body's intention to institute such action. 
(2)  The notice shall be sent to the most recent address of the landowner of record in the office of the assessor of the county where the subject property is located and to any other address for the landowner as may exist on record with the municipality. If, for any reason, such certified mail is returned without evidence of proper receipt thereof, the municipality shall resend the notice(s) by first class mail, postage prepaid, and shall also post notice on the front door or other conspicuous location on the subject property. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.14 - REGULATIONS NOT EXCLUSIVE. 
    The authority and the procedure set forth in this article shall not be construed as exclusive, but shall be in addition to other police powers possessed by the city for dealing with conflagrations, health conditions and other problems affecting the safety and welfare of the residents of the city. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.15 - LESSOR VIOLATIONS. 
    To the extent not otherwise authorized by state law, all notices of violation or correction for violations that do not fall within one of the categories set forth in section 1739.03 issued by the code enforcement agency shall be served in accordance with the process set forth in the state building code. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
1739.99 - PENALTY. 
    Any violation of this article may be prosecuted by the municipality consistent with state and local laws. Unless otherwise authorized by state law, prosecution of a violation shall be initiated by a complaint presented to and sworn or affirmed before a municipal judge. Unless otherwise provided by statute, the presentation and oath or affirmation shall be made by a code enforcement agency official or municipal attorney showing reason to have reliable information and belief. If from the facts stated in the complaint the municipal judge finds probable cause, the complaint becomes the charging instrument initiating a criminal proceeding. A complaint lawfully authorized by this subsection along with a summons setting forth the date, time and place of appearance before a municipal judge shall be served in accordance with the law of the State of West Virginia concerning the service of process in civil actions, except that personal service of a summons and complaint may be made by a code enforcement agency official. If service is made by certified mail under Rule 4(d)(1)(D) of the West Virginia Rules of Civil Procedure and delivery of the summons and complaint is refused, the code enforcement agency official, promptly upon the receipt of the notice of the refusal, shall mail to the person or entity being noticed, by first class mail, postage prepaid, a copy of the summons and complaint. If the first class mailing is not returned as undeliverable by the U.S. Postal Service, service of the summons and complaint is presumed to have been effectuated. Upon service of the summons and complaint consistent with this subsection, the violation may be prosecuted consistent with state and local law. 
(Ord. of 9-25-17(1) ) 
ARTICLE 1741 - VACANT COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted September 26, 2016, amended article 1741 title to read as herein set out. Formerly, such article pertained to vacant buildings. 

1741.01 - PURPOSE. 
(a)  The city has determined that uninspected and unmonitored vacant buildings (i) present a fire hazard; (ii) are often utilized by vagrants and transients (including drug abusers and traffickers) as dangerous and unsafe temporary shelters; (iii) detract from private and/or public efforts to rehabilitate or maintain surrounding buildings; and (iv) require additional regulation and services to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(b)  Owners of vacant buildings shall register such vacant buildings with the city, make payment of a fee as set forth herein, and otherwise conform to the requirements of this vacant structure code. 
(c)  It is the intent of this article that, through a registration, inspection, and monitoring process, and other improved public safety efforts, vacant buildings will be kept weather tight and secure from trespassers, will provide safe entry to police officers and firefighters in times of emergency, will not impede private and/or public efforts to rehabilitate or maintain surrounding properties, and will not otherwise present a public hazard. 
(d)  It is the city's further intent for the provisions of this article to streamline and consolidate the existing procedure (that is, complaint, research, notification, inspection, orders, fines, liens, appeals and lien enforcement) by placing the responsibility to register and maintain a vacant structure on the owner of a building before a condition of the building falls into disrepair or otherwise necessarily warrants a complaint. 
( Ord. of 1-25-16(1) ) 
1741.02 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purpose of this section, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them as follows: 
(a)  BOARDED: "Boarded" shall mean a building or structure subject to the provisions of this section and shall be deemed to be "boarded" if in place of one or more exterior doors, other than a storm door, or of one or more windows, there is a sheet or sheets of plywood or similar material covering the space for such door or window. 
(b)  BUSINESS DISTRICT: Solely for the purposes of this article, the "Business District" shall include the following: 
(1)  All parcels fronting Veterans Memorial Boulevard from 6th Street to 13th Street; 
(2)  All parcels fronting Third Avenue from 6th Street to Hal Greer Boulevard; 
(3)  All parcels fronting Fourth Avenue from 1st Street to Hal Greer Boulevard; 
(4)  All parcels fronting Fifth Avenue from 6th Street to Hal Greer Boulevard; 
(5)  All parcels fronting Sixth Avenue from 6th Street to 12th Street; 
(6)  All parcels fronting Seventh Avenue from 6th Street to 12th Street; 
(7)  All parcels south of 21/2 Alley from Hal Greer Boulevard to 22nd Street, west of 22nd Street from 21/2 Alley to 51/2 Alley, north of 51/2 Alley from Hal Greer Boulevard to 22nd Street, and east of Hal Greer Boulevard from 21/2 Alley to 51/2 Alley; 
(8)  All parcels fronting Hal Greer Boulevard from 51/2 Alley to Washington Boulevard; 
(9)  All parcels fronting 14th Street West from Washington Avenue to the railroad track underpass; 
(10)  Any and all properties fronting an alley that is bounded both to the north and the south avenues listed herein. 
The planning office shall maintain a map of the business district described herein which shall be available for public inspection during normal business hours. 
(c)  COMMERCIAL BUILDING: Any structure used or intended to be used in whole or in part for purposes other than residential purposes on which the property user or employees are engaged in work for which it is intended that compensation be received for goods or services. Examples include, but are not limited to, offices, retail shops, restaurants, service establishments, wholesales, warehousing, and production of goods. In order to be a commercial building for the purposes of this ordinance, the business use or activity must be at a scale greater than a home occupation. All buildings located within the "business district," defined herein, are deemed "commercial buildings" for the purposes of this article. 
(d)  DIRECTOR: Solely for the purposes of this article, the term "director" shall mean the mayor or designee. 
(e)  EXTERIOR MAINTENANCE AND MAJOR SYSTEMS: The phrase "exterior maintenance and major systems" shall mean the safe and lawful maintenance of the facade, windows, doors, roof and other parts of the exterior of the building and the maintenance of its major systems consisting of the roof, the electrical and plumbing systems, the water supply systems, the sewer system, and the sidewalk, driveway, if any, area of the lot, as applicable. 
(f)  OCCUPIED: Any building or structure shall be deemed to be "occupied" if one or more persons actually conducts a lawful business or resides in all or any part of the building as the licensed business-occupant, or as the legal or equitable owner/occupant(s) or tenant(s) on a permanent, non-transient basis, or any combination of the same. For purposes of this section, evidence offered to prove that a building is so "occupied" may include, but shall not be limited to, the regular receipt of delivery of regular mail through the U.S. Postal Service; proof of continual telephone, electric, gas, heating, water and sewer services; a valid city business license, or the most recent, federal, state, or city income tax statements indicating that the subject property is the official business or residence address of the person or business claiming occupancy; or proof of pre-rental inspection. 
(g)  OPEN: A building or structure subject to the provisions of this section shall be deemed to be "open" if any one or more exterior doors other than a storm door is broken, open and, or closed but, without a properly functioning lock to secure it, or if one or more windows is broken or not capable of being locked and secured from intrusions, or any combination of the same. 
(h)  OWNER: "Owner" or "property owner" shall mean a person who individually or jointly with others: 
(1)  Has legal title to the property, with or without actual possession of the property; 
(2)  Has charge, care or control of the property as owner or agent of the owner; 
(3)  Is an executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner; 
(4)  Is the agent of the owner for the purpose of managing, controlling or collecting rents; or 
(5)  Is entitled to control or direct the management or disposition of the property. 
For the purposes of this article, an "agent" shall not include a person contracted with the property owner solely for the sale or listing for sale of the property, commonly referred to as a "real estate agent." 
(i)  REGISTRATION FEE: "Registration fee" shall mean, accordance with W. Va. Code § 8-12-16c, the fee exacted from vacant building owners for the maintenance and upkeep of said property. 
(j)  VACANT: 
(1)  A building shall be deemed to be vacant if no person or persons actually, currently conducts a lawfully licensed business, or lawfully resides or lives in any part of the building as the legal or equitable owner(s) or tenant-occupant(s), or owner-occupants, or tenant(s) on a permanent, nontransient basis. 
(2)  A building or structure shall be deemed vacant and subject to the registration and possible penalty provisions provided herein if the exterior maintenance and major systems of the building and the surrounding real property thereof, as defined in this section, are in violation of the building codes or health and sanitation codes and if there is not proof of continual utility service evidencing actual use of electric, gas (i.e., applicable heating sources), water service, etc. "Continual" means having no interruption of service lasting 30 days or more in any given 360-day period. In order for such continual utility service to be considered as being actually in use as described in this section, it must be more than merely registered to the owner for purposes of billing and must be utilized, at a minimum, in order to keep the property and the major systems of the building in compliance with building and safety codes. The person or entity asserting that there has been continued utility service has the burden to produce actual bills evidencing utility service for the relevant period. 
(3)  A new building under construction or a building that has been granted a waiver under section 1741.07 of this article is not deemed a vacant building. 
( Ord. of 1-25-16(1) ; Ord. of 9-26-16(1) ) 
1741.03 - APPLICABILITY. 
    The requirements of this section shall be applicable to each owner of any commercial building, as defined herein, that has been vacant for more than 30 consecutive days. Each such owner shall cause to be filed a registration statement in conformity with section 1741.04(a). For the purposes of this section, "owner" include: 
(a)  If the owner is a corporation, the registration statement shall provide the names and residence addresses of all officers and directors of the corporation and shall be accompanied by a copy of the most recent annual franchise tax report filed with the secretary of state. 
(b)  If an estate, the name and business address of the executor of the estate. 
(c)  If a trust, the names and address of all trustees, grantors, and beneficiaries. 
(d)  If a partnership, the names and residence addresses of all partners with an interest of 10% or greater. 
(e)  If any other form of unincorporated association, the names and residence addresses of all principals with an interest of 10% or greater. 
(f)  If an individual person, the name and residence address of that individual person. 
    The requirements of this section shall not be applicable to any building owned by city, state, or federal government or any of their respective agencies or political subdivisions. 
( Ord. of 1-25-16(1) ; Ord. of 9-26-16(1) ) 
1741.04 - REGISTRATION STATEMENT; LOCAL AGENT; AND FEES. 
(a)  Registration statement: Each such owner shall cause to be filed a registration statement, which shall include the street address and parcel number of each such vacant building, the names and addresses of all owners, as hereinafter described, and any other information deemed necessary by the director and/or designee. Beginning with the first anniversary of the initial registration of each vacant building, the property owner of a registered vacant building shall pay the registration fee required by subsection 1741.04(c). All property owners of properties registered under this article shall remit payment of the fee imposed herein by the last day of the month in which the property was originally registered. 
    Registration shall be required for all vacant buildings, whether vacant and secure, vacant and open or vacant and boarded, and shall be required whenever any building has remained vacant for 30 consecutive days or more. In no instance shall the registration of a vacant building and the payment of registration fees be construed to exonerate the owner, agent or responsible party from responsibility for compliance with any other Building Code or Housing Code requirement. 
(b)  Local agent: If none of the persons outlined in section 1741.03 is shown at an address within the state, the registration statement also shall provide the name and address of a person who resides within the state and who is authorized to accept service of process on behalf of the owners and who shall be designated as a responsible, local party or agent, both for purposes of notification in the event of an emergency affecting the public health, safety or welfare and for purposes of service of any and all notices or registration statements as herein authorized in connection herewith.
